questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for gallbladder cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Polyp <10 mm

Explanation:

  • Gallbladder polyps smaller than 10 mm are generally not considered a significant risk factor for gallbladder cancer, while other conditions like porcelain gallbladder, primary sclerosing cholangitis, and large gallstones are associated with an increased risk.

Risk Factors For Carcinoma GB

Gallstones:
  • 90% of carcinoma cases are associated with gallstones.
  • The risk of developing carcinoma in gallstone disease is 7-10 times higher than in the general population.
  • Relative risk based on stone size:
  • Less than 2 cm: Lower risk
  • 2-3 cm: Relative risk of 2.5
  • More than 3 cm (Option D): Relative risk of 10 or more

Other Conditions:
  • Choledochal cyst
  • Anomalous pancreaticobiliary duct junction (20%)
  • Gallbladder polyps (more than 1 cm in size, more than 3 in number, or adenomatous polyps)
  • Porcelain gallbladder (Option A): 25% risk of malignant transformation, with 90% being inoperable tumours
  • Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (Option B)

Infections and Inflammatory Conditions:
  • Chronic typhoid carriers
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Hepatitis B and hepatitis C virus infections

Other factors:
  • Polypoid lesions (GB polyp)
  • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis
  • Nitrosamines
  • Carcinogens

questions.text: A young female presents with pain and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling lateral and below the pubic tubercle. X-ray shows intestinal obstruction. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Strangulated Femoral Hernia

Explanation:

  • The swelling lateral and below the pubic tubercle and the presence of intestinal obstruction are most likely indicative of a strangulated femoral hernia.
  • In an indirect inguinal hernia (Option B), the neck of the hernia is above and medial to the pubic tubercle.
  • In contrast, the neck of the hernia in a femoral hernia is located below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. The femoral ring and canal are relatively rigid, which increases the risk of strangulation in these cases.

Femoral Hernia:

A groin hernia occurs when abdominal contents, typically a portion of the intestine or fatty tissue, protrude through the femoral canal in the lower abdominal wall.

  • Location: Appears as a bulge in the upper thigh, just below the groin crease.
  • Demographics: More common in women, especially older and overweight females.
  • Risk: Higher risk of incarceration and strangulation compared to inguinal hernias.
  • Symptoms:
    • Lump in the groin or upper thigh, which may be painless or painful.
    • Discomfort when standing, lifting, or straining.
    • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain if the hernia becomes incarcerated or strangulated.

 

Adhesions (Option A): While adhesions can cause intestinal obstruction, they do not typically present with swelling.

Appendicular Mass (Option D): An appendicular mass can cause swelling but is usually located in the right iliac fossa, not lateral and below the pubic tubercle.

questions.text: Estimate the extent of injury for a patient with burns involving the chest, abdomen, right upper limb, and the whole of the right thigh.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 36%

Explanation:

According to Wallace's rule of 9

  • Chest and abdomen = 18% (9% on each side)
  • Right upper limb = 9%
  • Right thigh = 9%

questions.text: Which classification system is used for bile duct injury, taking location, injury to the duct, and vessel involvement into account?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hannover

Explanation:

The Hannover classification is a comprehensive system for bile duct injuries, particularly post-cholecystectomy, that accounts for:

  • Location of injury

  • Type of duct injury (partial or complete)

  • Presence of vascular injury (e.g., to the right hepatic artery)

It provides a more detailed description compared to older systems and is especially useful in surgical planning.

  • Type A: Cystic duct or gallbladder bed leak.
  • Type B: Incomplete or complete stenosis.
  • Type C: Lateral tangential injuries.
  • Type D: Complete bile duct injury with vascular injuries.
  • Type E: Late bile duct stenosis.

Bismuth Classification: (Option A)

Describes strictures of the biliary system, particularly benign biliary strictures after surgery. It is based solely on the location of the stricture relative to the hepatic duct confluence.

Bismuth classification for biliary strictures

Type I
  • Common hepatic duct stump >2cm
  • Stricture is Low

Type II
  • Common hepatic duct stump <2cm
  • Stricture is mid

Type III
  • Hilar stricture with intact confluence
  • Stricture is high

Type IV
  • Hilar stricture with destroyed confluence

Type V
  • Stricture involving aberrant right sectoral duct with or without stricture of common hepatic duct

 

Strasberg classification (Option B) divides bile duct injuries into five main classes:

Type A (M/C)

Cystic duct stump leak or leak from sub-vesical duct of Luschka

Type B

Ligation or occlusion of aberrant right sectoral duct

Type C

Transection without occlusion of the aberrant right sectoral duct

Type D

Injury to the lateral wall of the Common hepatic duct

Type E

E1 to E5 Bismuth classification

Stewart-Way Classification (Option C):

Focuses on mechanisms of injury and surgeon-related errors, useful for root cause analysis rather than guiding surgical repair.

Stewart-Way Classification:

  • Class I: Incomplete injury.
  • Class II: Lateral injury with bile leak and stenosis.
  • Class III: Complete transection of the common bile duct (most common, 60%).
  • Class IV: Duct branch injuries with involvement of the right hepatic artery.

questions.text: Post-orchidectomy, the specimen shows Reinke's Crystals. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Leydig Cell Tumor

Explanation:

  • Reinke's Crystals are typically seen in Leydig cell tumours, which is a type of sex cord-stromal tumour.

Sexcord stromal tumors:

 

Leydig cell tumour

Sertoli cell tumour

Hormonal involvement

It often involves androgens, oestrogens, and corticosteroids.

Hormonally silent.

Conditions associated with
  • Klinefelter syndrome.
  • Cryptorchidism.
  • Renal cell carcinoma.
  • Carney complex.
  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis.

Malignancy

10% (in adults)

10%

Gross
  • Circumscribed nodules, usually < 5 cm in diameter.
  • They have a distinctive golden brown, homogeneous appearance on cut surfaces.

Firm, small nodules with a homogeneous

grey-white to yellow cut surface.

 

Histology
  • The tumour cells resemble their normal counterparts.
  • They are large in size and have round or polygonal cell outlines, abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a round central nucleus.
  • The cytoplasm frequently contains lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment and, most characteristically, rod-shaped Reinke crystalloids (25% of the tumours).
  • The tumour cells are arranged in distinctive trabeculae that tend to form cord-like structures and tubules.

 

Image

Seminoma: (Option A)

  • Reinke's Crystals are not present in seminomas.
  • Seminoma is the most common testicular tumour, typically seen in the 3rd and 4th decades of life.
  • Tumor markers associated with seminomas include beta-HCG, which is commonly elevated, along with markers related to disease bulk, such as:
    • LDH
    • PLAP
    • GGT

Metastasis (Option C): Reinke's Crystals are not found in metastatic testicular disease.

Yolk sac tumor: (Option D)

  • The tumour marker for yolk sac tumours is alpha-fetoprotein.
  • Yolk sac tumours are the most common testicular tumours in children, particularly between 1-3 years of age.
  • Yolk sac tumours are also associated with the best prognosis among testicular tumours.

questions.text: A patient underwent cholecystectomy, and the histopathology reveals carcinoma with invasion into the muscular layer. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Extended Cholecystectomy

Explanation:

  • T1b lesions refer to gallbladder cancer that invades the muscular layer but not beyond the deeper layers. The next best step is extended cholecystectomy to ensure an R0 resection, which includes removal of the surrounding lymph nodes (e.g., hepatoduodenal, gastrohepatic) and possibly part of the hepatic parenchyma to achieve clear margins.

TNM Staging of Gall bladder Carcinoma:

Category

Description

Tis

Carcinoma in situ

T1

Tumor invades lamina propria or muscle layer

T1a

Tumor invades lamina propria

T1b

Tumor invades muscle layer

T2

Tumor invades perimuscular connective tissue

T2a

Tumor does not extend to serosa

T2b

Tumor extends to serosa, but does not invade the liver

T3

Tumor perforates serosa and/or invades liver/adjacent organs

T4

Tumor invades main portal vein/hepatic artery/multiple extrahepatic organs

Lymph node

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastases to 1-3 regional lymph nodes

N2

Metastases to >3 regional lymph nodes

Metastasis

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

Gallbladder Cancer Treatment:

  • Gallbladder Polyp:
    • Adenomatous polyps have malignant potential.
    • Risk factors for malignancy: Single polyp, size >1 cm, age >50 years.
    • Management: Cholecystectomy is recommended for polyps >1 cm. Polyps <1 cm may undergo surveillance, except in PSC (where earlier cholecystectomy is advised).
  • Gallbladder Cancer Post-Cholecystectomy:
    • T1a Lesions (mucosa, lamina propria): Cholecystectomy
    • T1b Lesions (muscular invasion): Extended cholecystectomy is recommended, especially with vascular, perineural, or lymphatic invasion.
    • T2 Lesions (past muscularis): Radical cholecystectomy with lymph node removal as more than 40% have nodal metastasis.
    • T3/T4 Lesions (extensive): Extended surgery, including liver resection, may be needed for R0 margins.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in subclinical acute myocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Elevated pro-BNP, Trop T

 

Criteria

Histological confirmation

Biomarker, ECG, or imaging abnormalities consistent with myocarditis

Possible subclinical acute myocarditis

In the clinical context of possible myocardial injury without cardiovascular symptoms (Option A) but with at least one of the following:

  • Biomarkers of cardiac injury raised
  • ECG findings suggestive of cardiac injury
  • Abnormal cardiac function on echocardiogram or cardiac MRI

Absent

Needed

Probable acute myocarditis

In the clinical context of possible myocardial injury with cardiovascular symptoms and at least one of the following:

  • Biomarkers of cardiac injury raised
  • ECG findings suggestive of cardiac injury
  • Abnormal cardiac function on echocardiogram or cardiac MRI

Absent

Needed

Definite myocarditis

Histological or immunohistological evidence of myocarditis

Histological or immunohistological evidence of myocarditis

Not Needed

Options C and D are incorrect as they are not found in subclinical acute myocarditis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with menorrhagia and excessive bleeding after a minor surgery. She gave the history of her father and sister having the same bleeding issues and the pattern of inheritance was determined to be autosomal dominant. What is the most likely disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Von Willebrand disease

  • Von Willebrand disease is the most common bleeding disorder with an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.
  • It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (vWF), a glycoprotein crucial for platelet adhesion and stabilizing factor VIII in the coagulation cascade.

Functions of vWF:

  • Platelet Adhesion: Mediates binding of platelets to subendothelial collagen at sites of vascular injury.
  • Stabilization of Factor VIII: Protects Factor VIII from degradation, prolonging its half-life.

Clinical manifestation:

  • Superficial bruising, epistaxis, menorrhagia and gastrointestinal haemorrhage
  • Excessive haemorrhage might only be observed after trauma or surgery
  • Heavy menstrual bleeding
  • Might first manifest with dental extractions, particularly wisdom tooth extraction, or tonsillectomy

Investigation:

Types

In general, increase in aPTT and BT, but normal PT and platelet count. (Option A)

Treatment:

  • Desmopressin (DDAVP)
  • Tranexamic acid or epsilon-aminocaproic acid for mucosal bleeding or non-serious bleeding
  • Factor VIII concentrates are given to manage serious or persistent bleeding
  • Bleeding in type 3 patients responds only to factor VIII/vWF concentrate

Hemophilia A (Option B) and Christmas Disease (Option C) have X-linked recessive patterns of inheritance and are not autosomal dominant.

Factor 10 deficiency (Option D) has both autosomal dominant and recessive inheritance but AD pattern of inheritance is less common in Factor 10 deficiency.

questions.text: Which ion channels are affected in cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option C) Cl-

Explanation:

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive monogenic disorder.

The CFTR ΔF508 mutation (cystic fibrosis transmembrane-conductance regulator gene), located on chromosome 7 is the most common mutation causing cystic fibrosis.

This mutation leads to defective CFTR protein, which impairs chloride transport across epithelial cells.

Na+ (Option A): CFTR does not directly function as a sodium channel. Hence, this option is incorrect.

Ca2+ (Option B) and K+ (Option D): CFTR does not regulate Ca2+ and K+ transport. Hence, these options are incorrect.

questions.text: Windkessel effect is not shown by which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option C) Radial artery

Explanation:

Radial artery :

       It is a muscular artery (resistance vessel) that has a thick muscle coat and less elastic fibre in its wall. Due to less elastic fibres, recoiling property will not be seen.

  • It does not exhibit the same level of elasticity and compliance as large elastic arteries like the aorta

Windkessel Vessels:

  • The aorta and large arteries have more elastic elements in their wall (Options A, B & D ruled out). They have higher compliance
  • Windkessel effect: During systole, their wall stretches to accommodate the blood ejected by ventricles, and during diastole, their wall recoils back to the presystolic position .
  • The Windkessel or the recoiling effect pushes blood in forward direction during diastole.
  • Blood in blood vessels is pushed forward during systole by the force created by ventricular ejection and during diastole by the force created by arterial recoiling.

questions.text: Which membrane channel is mainly affected in Cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Chloride

  • The chloride membrane channel is affected in cystic fibrosis.

Pathogenesis of Cystic Fibrosis

Mechanism

Key Features

CFTR Defect
  • Defective chloride/bicarbonate transport
  • Located in apical plasma membranes
  • F508del (phenylalanine is replaced) mutation most common (~70%)

Airway Changes
  • Depleted periciliary fluid layer
  • Thick mucus accumulation
  • Impaired mucociliary clearance

Infection Risk
  • Common pathogens: P. aeruginosa, S. aureus
  • Chronic bacterial colonization
  • Progressive bronchiectasis

Clinical Impact
  • Recurrent pneumonia
  • Progressive lung damage
  • Requires aggressive antibiotic therapy

questions.text: Which of the following substances causes a bitter taste that deters us from consuming toxic substances?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) Alkaloids

Explanation:

Bitter taste:

  • Alkaloids are a class of naturally occurring organic compounds that often have bitter tastes.
  • Various plants produce them as a defence mechanism against herbivores and insects.
  • Many alkaloids are toxic or have pharmacological effects on the human body.
  • Examples of alkaloids: are caffeine, nicotine, morphine, and quinine.

Aldehyde (Option A): Aldehydes and ketones have a sweet taste. Most sweet substances are organic. This option is incorrect.

Amino acids (Option B): α-amino acids have a sweet taste, but polypeptides are often bitter. This option is incorrect.

Hydrogen ions (Option D): Sour taste is triggered by hydrogen ions, the adequate stimulus being a pH of less than 4 of the solution. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Choledochal Cyst is incorrect?

choices.text: The cyst can be opened directly and drained
Todani classification is used for grading

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The cyst can be opened directly and drained

Explanation:

  • Choledochal cysts should not be simply drained. Direct drainage can lead to complications, including infection and further dilation. The proper treatment usually involves surgical resection of the cyst and reconstruction of the bile duct.

Choledochal Cyst: Congenital dilatations of the intra- and/or extrahepatic biliary system can present at any age.

  • In choledochal cysts, there is an abnormal junction between the bile duct and the pancreatic duct (Option D), leading to the reflux of pancreatic enzymes into the common bile duct (CBD). The presence of these enzymes in the CBD causes its dilation.
  • Clinical features:
    • Patients may present with jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, and a right upper quadrant mass.
    • Pancreatitis is a frequent presentation in adults.
    • Approximately 60% of cases are diagnosed before the age of 10 years.
    • The classical triad of jaundice, right upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain is present in only a minority of patients (0–17%)
  • Patients have an increased risk of developing malignancies like:
    • Cholangiocarcinoma (Option A)
    • Squamous cell carcinoma
    • Bile duct sarcoma
    • Hepatoma
    • Pancreatic carcinoma
    • Gallbladder carcinoma

Todani modification of Alonso- Lej classification (Option C)

Type I

Ia

Cystic dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct (Most common)

Ib

Focal segmental dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Ic

Fusiform dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Type II

Diverticular dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Type III

Dilatation of intraduodenal part of bile duct (choledochocele)

Type IV

IV a

Dilatation of both intra and extrahepatic bile duct

 

IV b

Multiple cysts involving extrahepatic bile duct only

Type V

Multiple cysts involving intrahepatic bile duct only (Caroli’s disease)

 

Type

Treatment

Type I

Complete excision, cholecystectomy, Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

Type II

Complete excision

Type III

Transduodenal excision or sphincteroplasty, endoscopic drainage may suffice

Type IVa

Tailored to anatomy: extrahepatic cysts treated like Type I; partial hepatectomy and reconstruction for localised intrahepatic involvement

Type IVb

Managed like Type I

Type V

(Caroli disease)

Resection for unilobar disease; liver transplantation for diffuse disease

questions.text: The diagram displays nerve cell physiology. The event marked by 3 to 4 is due to _______ ?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option C) K+ exiting the cell

Explanation: The event marked between 3 to 4  is Early repolarisation  where voltage gated  K+ channels  are fully open resulting in K+ exiting the cell.

  • Resting Membrane Potential (Point A on graph):
    • At rest, the neuron's membrane potential is around -70 mV.
    • K+ permeability is higher than Na+ permeability due to the presence of K+ leak channels.
    • However, the overall permeability to both ions is relatively low.
  • Depolarization Phase (Between Points A and C): (Options A and D ruled out)
    • Voltage-gated Na+ channels open faster than K+ channels.
    • Rapid influx of Na+ ions, causing a rapid rise in membrane potential, causing a steep slope.
  • Peak of Action Potential (Point C):
    • Na+ permeability is at its maximum.
    • K+ channels are also opening at this stage but have not reached their peak.
  • Early Repolarization Phase (Point D): (Option C)
    • Voltage-gated K+ channels are fully open, resulting in the highest permeability. K+ moves exits the cell.
    • Na+ channels are rapidly inactivated during this phase.
  • Late Repolarization and After-hyperpolarization (Points E and F): (Option C)
    • K+ permeability starts to decline as the membrane potential moves towards its resting state.
    • Slow closure of K+ channels results in a period of hyperpolarization, where the membrane potential falls slightly below the resting potential (Point F).

questions.text: Which of the following describes an aortic regurgitation murmur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Diastolic murmur

  • A diastolic murmur is seen in aortic regurgitation.

Classification of Murmurs

Murmur Type

Subtype

Conditions murmur heard

Additional points

Systolic Murmurs

Ejection Systolic Murmur

(HAPpy)
  1. Pulmonary Stenosis
  2. Aortic Stenosis
  3. HOCM
  • Early systolic murmur seen with papillary muscle dysfunction.
  • Late systolic murmur is seen in small VSD and mitral valve prolapse (MVP)

Pan Systolic Murmur(MTV)
  1. Mitral regurgitation
  2. Tricuspid regurgitation
  3. Ventricular septal defect

Diastolic Murmurs

Early Diastolic Murmur (GAP)
  1. Graham Steell murmur
  2. Aortic regurgitation
  3. Pulmonary regurgitation (mild)
  • Along with hemodynamic changes the characteristics of flow also changes

Mid-Diastolic Murmur
  1. Carey Coombs murmur
  2. Austin Flint murmur
  3. Mitral stenosis
  • Flow murmur may mimic mid-diastolic murmur

Continuous Murmurs

 
  1. Patent ductus arteriosus
  2. Aortopulmonary window
  3. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm
  4. Coronary arteriovenous fistula
  5. Cervical venous hum
  6. Anomalous left coronary artery origin
  7. Mammary souffle of pregnancy
  8. Bronchial collateral circulation
  9. Intercostal or pulmonary arteriovenous fistula
  10. Peripheral pulmonic stenosis
  • Causes are diverse and involve persistent communication between systemic and pulmonary circulation.

 

Examination Findings of Aortic Regurgitation

Blood Pressure
  • Elevated systolic pressure and decreased diastolic pressure result in increased arterial pulse pressure.
  • Atrio-ventricular malformation and Atrio-ventricular ﬁstula also show low diastolic BP due to continuous Korotkoﬀ sounds.
  • Positive Hill’s sign is an abnormal difference in BP in the upper limb and lower limb.

On Palpation
  • Heaving LV impulse is noted, which is displaced laterally and inferiorly
  • Diastolic and Systolic Thrills were noticed at the left lower sternal border and suprasternal notch, respectively.

On Auscultation

 

Heart Sounds
  • A2 is absent
  • In the Bicuspid aortic valve, systolic ejection sound is present
  • Sometimes, A4 is also heard

 

 

 

 

 

 

Murmurs
  • A Decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard when sitting up and leaning forward, is an early diastolic murmur that becomes holo-diastolic as the condition progresses to a severe stage.
  • Musical diastolic murmur is aortic cusp fluttering in the regurgitant flow.
  • Mid-diastolic murmur
  • Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, mid- to end-diastolic murmur caused by mitral valve displacement due to AR.
  • Ejection systolic murmur is commonly heard in AR along with AS.

questions.text: What is the enzyme deficiency in Pompe’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase

  • Pompe’s disease is a muscle glycogen storage disorder, also known as Glycogen storage disorder type I,I which is caused by the deficiency of acid α-1,4-glucosidase.

Pompe disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type II)

Definition

Glycogen storage disorder caused by deficiency of acid α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase)

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

 

Pathophysiology

Accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes, primarily affecting cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells

 

Forms
  • Infantile Pompe disease (IPD) - Severe
  • Late-onset Pompe disease (LOPD) - Less Severe

Clinical Features
  • IPD: Hypotonia, muscle weakness, feeding difficulties, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • LOPD: Proximal limb-girdle muscle weakness, respiratory muscle involvement, cardiac rhythm disturbances

 

Laboratory Findings
  • Elevated serum CK, AST, ALT, LDH
  • Cardiomegaly on chest X-ray (infantile form)
  • ECG changes- shortened P-R interval, tall QRS complexes

Treatment
  • Enzyme replacement therapy with alglucosidase alfa
  • High-protein diet (for LOPD)
  • Histopathology findings: muscle biopsy/ cardiac biopsy has vacuoles within muscle fibres which stain with PAS strongly (glycogen is pas positive, diastase sensitive)


Glucose 6 phosphatase (Option B) is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. Deficiency of this enzyme is seen in Von Gierke's disease (glycogen storage disease type I), not in Pompe's disease.

Muscle phosphorylase (Option C), also known as myophosphorylase, is an enzyme involved in glycogenolysis (the breakdown of glycogen into glucose) in muscle tissue. A deficiency of muscle phosphorylase leads to McArdle disease (glycogen storage disease type V), characterized by exercise intolerance and muscle cramps.

Phosphofructokinase (Option D) is an enzyme involved in glycolysis, the breakdown of glucose to produce energy. Deficiency of phosphofructokinase leads to Tarui disease (glycogen storage disease type VII), characterized by exercise intolerance and muscle weakness.

questions.text: What does the ECG in the following image depict?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Torsades de pointes:

  • The polymorphic VT, spindle-shaped pattern, and prolonged QT interval seen in the ECG show the diagnosis of Torsades de Pointes.

Torsades de Pointes

ECG features:

  • Polymorphic VT: Characterized by variation in QRS direction and amplitude.
  • Spindle-shaped pattern: The QRS complexes form a twisting or spindle-shaped "envelope".
  • Prolonged QT interval
  • PVC initiation: Often triggered by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC) on a prolonged T-U wave, creating an "R on T" phenomenon.
  • Postectopic pause: A pause following the PVC, further prolonging repolarization.

Causes:

Mnemonic: "A TIGERS BITE"

  • A - Antiarrhythmics (Class IA and III)
  • T - Tricyclic antidepressants
  • I - Ischemia (myocardial)
  • G - Genetics (congenital long QT syndrome)
  • E - Electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia)
  • R - Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • S - Stroke (especially subarachnoid haemorrhage)
  • B - Bradycardia
  • I - Interactions (drug-drug interactions that prolong QT)
  • T - Toxins (organophosphates, arsenic, etc.)
  • E - Endocrine disorders (hypothyroidism, pheochromocytoma)

Treatment:

  • Immediate management: Intravenous magnesium sulfate (even if serum magnesium is normal)
  • Discontinue potential QT-prolonging medications
  • Correct electrolyte abnormalities, especially hypokalemia
  • Consider temporary pacing or isoproterenol infusion to increase heart rate and shorten QT interval

Acute pericarditis (Option A) shows T-wave inversion following ST-segment elevation in the ECG.

Viral myocarditis (Option B) shows prolonged QRS, QT prolongation, diffuse T wave inversion, ventricular arrhythmias, and AV conduction defects in the ECG.

Cardiac tamponade (Option D) shows consecutive normally-conducted QRS complexes that alternate in height (electrical alternans) and low QRS voltage with tachycardia in the ECG.

questions.text: What is observed in the case of an abnormal accumulation of misfolded protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Creutzfeldt jakob disease

  • The disease associated with abnormal accumulation of misfolded proteins is Creutzfeldt Jakob disease affecting the brain.
  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) is a rare, rapidly progressing brain disorder affecting coordination, memory, and mental functions.

Aetiology:

  • CJD is caused by prions, which are abnormally folded proteins that induce other normal prion proteins to adopt the same harmful shape.
  • These abnormal prion proteins accumulate in the brain, leading to nerve cell damage and the characteristic spongiform appearance (brain tissue with holes).
  • The prion proteins disrupt normal brain functions, causing progressive neurological degeneration.

Main symptoms:

  • Severe mental deterioration (dementia)
  • Involuntary muscle jerks (myoclonus)

Early symptoms:

  • Lack of coordination, walking/balance problems
  • Impaired thinking, memory, judgment, mood changes, anxiety
  • Confusion, insomnia, vision changes, unusual sensations

Progression symptoms:

  • Weakness, blindness, loss of movement or speech
  • Pneumonia, infections, coma

CJD types:

  • Sporadic (unknown cause, 85% of cases)
  • Hereditary (gene mutation, 10-15% of cases)
  • Acquired (rare, from medical procedures or contaminated tissue)
  • Variant CJD (linked to "mad cow" disease, affects younger people)

Diagnosis:

  • EEG, cerebrospinal fluid tests (14-3-3 protein), MRI
  • Brain biopsy or autopsy for confirmation

Treatment:

  • No cure
  • Symptom management (pain relief, muscle jerk control, comfort care)

Nephritic syndrome (Option B) is primarily associated with immune-mediated damage and not the accumulation of misfolded proteins.

In sickle cell anaemia (Option C), while there is an abnormality in the structure of haemoglobin, it does not involve the accumulation of misfolded proteins as seen in CJD.

Megaloblastic anaemia (Option D) is a type of anaemia characterized by the presence of large, immature red blood cells (megaloblasts) in the bone marrow. Megaloblastic anaemia does not involve the accumulation of misfolded proteins.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a complication of blood transfusion in a 25-year-old mother who developed acute postpartum haemorrhage (PPH), hypovolemic shock, and underwent major blood transfusion after delivering a baby boy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Hypokalemia

  • Hypokalemia is not seen with blood transfusions. Instead, hyperkalemia occurs due to leakage of potassium from red blood cells in stored blood.

Complications of Massive Blood Transfusion

Complication

Cause

Effect

Prevention/ Management

Hypothermia (Option C)

Transfusion of cold blood (stored at 4°C).

Body temperature drops, leading to impaired clotting mechanisms (coagulopathy), and worsening bleeding.
  • Warm blood products before transfusion
  • Use external warming methods (e.g., warming blankets).

Coagulopathy

Dilution of clotting factors and platelets due to transfusion; consumption of clotting factors by ongoing haemorrhage.

Impaired blood clotting, prolonged bleeding time, increased risk of continued bleeding.
  • Administer fresh frozen plasma (FFP), platelets, and cryoprecipitate.
  • For massive BT, blood products should be administered in a 1:1:1 ratio.
  • Monitor clotting factors (e.g., PT, aPTT).

Citrate Toxicity

Large volumes of transfused blood contain citrate, which binds to calcium.

Hypocalcemia (Option A), leads to muscle cramps, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Administer calcium gluconate or calcium chloride prophylactically.

Hyperkalemia (Option D)

Potassium leaks from stored red blood cells into plasma during storage.

Elevated potassium levels (hyperkalemia) can cause cardiac arrhythmias, potentially leading to cardiac arrest.
  • Monitor potassium levels.
  • Administer calcium to stabilize the myocardium.
  • Insulin with glucose to shift potassium intracellularly if needed.

Metabolic Alkalosis

Rapid metabolism of citrate into bicarbonate.

Increased pH (alkalosis) can lead to muscle twitching, irritability, and impaired oxygen release from haemoglobin.
  • Monitor arterial blood gases (ABG)
  • Adjust transfusion speed and, if necessary, reduce bicarbonate levels.

Metabolic Acidosis

Inadequate tissue perfusion leads to lactic acid accumulation.

Lowered blood pH (acidosis) leads to confusion, fatigue, rapid breathing, and worsened cardiovascular function.
  • Correct underlying cause (e.g., improve perfusion).
  • Administer sodium bicarbonate in severe cases of acidosis.

Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

Antibodies in transfused blood activate the recipient's immune response, causing inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs.

Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, presenting as acute respiratory distress with hypoxia within 6 hours of transfusion.
  • Immediate cessation of transfusion.
  • Oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation if necessary.

Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO)

The volume of transfused blood exceeds the patient’s capacity to manage, leading to fluid overload.

Pulmonary oedema, shortness of breath, hypertension, and signs of heart failure.
  • Administer diuretics (e.g., furosemide).
  • Slow the rate of transfusion.

Iron Overload

Repeated transfusions lead to excessive accumulation of iron.

Iron deposits in organs (e.g., liver, heart, pancreas), lead to organ damage and failure over time.

Administer iron chelators (e.g., deferoxamine, deferasirox).

Hemolytic Reactions

ABO or Rh incompatibility.

Rapid destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), causes fever, chills, hemoglobinuria, and potentially acute renal failure or shock.
  • Immediate cessation of transfusion.
  • Supportive care with IV fluids.

Allergic Reactions

Reaction to proteins in transfused blood products.

Symptoms range from mild itching, rash, or hives to severe anaphylaxis (airway constriction, low blood pressure, shock).
  • Administer antihistamines for mild reactions.
  • Corticosteroids and epinephrine for severe reactions like anaphylaxis.

Bacterial Contamination

Blood products are contaminated during collection or storage.

Sepsis is characterized by fever, chills, low blood pressure, and possibly septic shock.
  • Immediate cessation of transfusion.
  • Administer broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: What kind of wound is an open cardiac massage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Contaminated

Explanation:

  • Open cardiac massage is classified as Category 3 due to a significant breach in sterile technique.
  • It is generally performed in situations of inadequate cardiac output, following emergency thoracotomy for penetrating chest trauma, during pericardial tamponade, or in cases of cardiac arrest after recent chest surgery.

Classification of Wounds:

Classification

Description

Class I

Clean

An uninfected operative wound with no inflammation and no entry into the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts. Wounds are primarily closed, and drainage is closed if needed.

Class II Clean-Contaminated

An operative wound where the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts are entered under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Includes operations like biliary tract, appendix, vagina, and oropharynx.

Class III

Contaminated

Open, fresh accidental wounds or operations with major breaks in sterile technique

(open cardiac massage) or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract, with acute non-purulent inflammation.

Class IV

Dirty-Infected

Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue, clinical infection, or perforated viscera. The organisms causing postoperative infection were already present in the operative field before the operation.

questions.text: Which of the microorganisms listed below will exhibit intrinsic resistance to meropenem and aminoglycosides, but have sensitivity to cotrimoxazole?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Stenotrophomonas

  • The microorganism that exhibits intrinsic resistance to meropenem and aminoglycosides but sensitive to cotrimoxazole is Stenotrophomonas.
  • Stenotrophomonas maltophilia is a non-fermenting gram-negative rod, similar to Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Acinetobacter.

Risk factors:

  • Chronic respiratory diseases (e.g., cystic fibrosis)
  • Hematologic malignancies, chemotherapy-induced neutropenia
  • Organ transplants, HIV infection, hemodialysis, neonates
  • Hospital settings, ICU stays, mechanical ventilation, tracheostomies
  • Central venous catheters, severe burns, trauma, mucosal damage, and prolonged antibiotic use increase the risk.

Management:

  • First-line treatment: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) (co-trimoxazole) at high doses (15 mg/kg of trimethoprim component).
  • Alternative treatments:
    • Fluoroquinolones (e.g., levofloxacin, moxifloxacin) have good efficacy, particularly in lung infections.
    • Minocycline and tigecycline show high effectiveness (80-100% susceptibility).
    • Ticarcillin-clavulanic acid, ceftazidime, colistin, and chloramphenicol can be considered.
  • Emerging treatments:
    • New agents like Cefiderocol, Eravacycline, Omadacycline, and Delafloxacin show promising in-vitro activity.
    • Combination therapies (e.g., TMP-SMX/ciprofloxacin, ticarcillin-clavulanate/aztreonam) have demonstrated synergistic effects.
  • Challenges:
    • Resistance to many common antibiotics like meropenem, and aminoglycosides is rising, necessitating new treatments.
    • Studies on aerosolized antibiotics, bacteriophage therapy, and other innovative approaches are ongoing.
  • Duration of treatment:
    • Pneumonia: Typically 7 days, extended to 10-14 days in immunocompromised patients.
    • Bacteremia: Generally treated for 14 days.
  • Source control:
    • Surgical removal of infected devices (e.g., central venous catheters) and drainage of infected collections is critical for successful treatment.

Option A, B, and C: These organisms are susceptible to meropenem and aminoglycosides.

questions.text: A female presents with a non-palpable lump in the breast. The biopsy and IHC results reveal Luminal A. What characteristics are included under Luminal A?

choices.text: ER positive, PR positive, Her2 neu positive
ER positive, PR positive, Her2 neu negative with low proliferation
ER positive, PR positive, Her2 neu negative with high proliferation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ER positive, PR positive, Her2 neu negative with low proliferation

Explanation:

  • Luminal A is characterised by being ER positive, PR positive, and Her2 neu negative.
  • It is the most common breast cancer subtype, characterised by low cell proliferation activity and the best prognosis among all subtypes.

Molecular classification of breast cancer:

Subtype

ER Status

PR Status

HER2 Status

Ki-67 Status

Characteristics

Luminal A

+

+

-

Low

Generally, it is low grade, has a better prognosis, and is responsive to hormonal therapy.

Luminal B

+

+ or -

+ or -

High

Higher grade, poor prognosis compared to Luminal A, may require targeted HER2 therapy following status.

HER2-enriched

-

-

+

High

Aggressive, higher grade, poor prognosis, requires targeted HER2 therapy.

Basal-like

-

-

-

High

Includes triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), highly aggressive, no targeted hormonal therapy.

Claudin-low

-

-

+ or -

Often High

Often associated with poor prognosis and aggressive behaviour, typically lacks response to hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of pain in the flank region with hematuria. On investigation, an X-ray shows multiple calcifications (stones) in both kidneys. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Renal calculi

  • The presence of flank pain, hematuria, and multiple calcifications seen on X-ray in both kidneys strongly suggests the presence of kidney stones.

Clinical manifestations of Renal stones:

  • Renal colic is typically characterised by severe, sharp, and fluctuating pain originating in the flank and radiating toward the lower abdomen or groin, based on the location of the stone within the ureter.
    • Upper ureteral stone: Pain radiates anteriorly.
    • Lower ureteral stone: Pain radiates to the ipsilateral groin or labium in females/testicles in males.
  • Hematuria is a common finding due to ureteral irritation and damage caused by the sharp edges of the stone.
  • Nausea and vomiting are frequently present due to the intensity of pain and reno-gastric reflex.

Investigations for renal calculi

  • Lab investigations:
    • Urine analysis (24-hour urine analysis) and blood tests should be conducted to assess serum levels of calcium, uric acid, phosphate, oxalate, and other relevant substances.
  • Radiological investigations:
    • Helical CT abdomen (non-contrast) is the investigation of choice (gold standard) to confirm the diagnosis and locate the stones.
    • Ultrasonography (abdomen, KUB) can also be done.
    • X-ray (KUB) can also reveal radio-opaque stones such as Lysine, uric acid, and xanthine.

Management of renal stones

Medical management

Surgical Management
  • Analgesics like diclofenac, ketorolac, tramadol
  • Fluid therapy: IVF (intravenous fluids) are administered to prevent dehydration
  • Alpha 1 blocker: Tamsulosin (relaxes ureter and expels the stone).
  • Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): Indicated if the size of the calculi <2 cm. (Contraindicated in pregnancy and bleeding diathesis).
  • PCNL (Percutaneous nephrolithotomy): If the size is >2 cm.
  • Uretrorenoscopy
  • Retrograde intrarenal surgery
  • Pyelolithotomy and nephrolithotomy (rarely used).

Parathyroid adenoma (Option A) refers to the enlargement of one or more of the parathyroid glands, which are responsible for regulating calcium levels in the body.

While Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) (Option C) can lead to kidney-related symptoms, such as flank pain and hematuria, the presence of multiple calcifications (stones) in both kidneys is not a typical feature of this condition.

While CKD (Option D) can lead to various complications, such as the formation of kidney stones, the presence of multiple calcifications (stones) in both kidneys on X-ray is not specific to CKD.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient suffers from schizophrenia. He is currently receiving clozapine treatment. Why does he require frequent blood monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Agranulocytosis

  • Clozapine is the drug of choice for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. However, a patient on this medication needs monitoring of his blood regularly due to the risk of agranulocytosis, a common side effect of clozapine.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Clozapine primarily works as a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, but it also has significant effects on serotonin receptors (5-HT2A and 5-HT2C), which helps reduce symptoms in treatment-resistant cases.

Side Effects:

  • Severe risks:
    • Agranulocytosis: Occurs in approximately 0.3% of users, necessitating regular monitoring of white blood cell counts.
    • Seizures (Option D): Affects up to 5% of patients on doses exceeding 600 mg.
  • Common side effects:
    • Hypersalivation
    • Sedation
    • Tachycardia
    • Weight gain
    • Postural hypotension
    • Rare side effects include myocarditis (Option B).

Cerebral bleeding (Option C) is not a commonly reported side effect of clozapine nor does regular blood tests help in assessing the risk or occurrence of one.

questions.text:
Match the following medical conditions with their corresponding descriptions:


	
		
			
			A
			
			
			Caplan syndrome
			
			
			1
			
			
			Initially observed in coal workers
			
		
		
			
			B
			
			
			Asbestosis
			
			
			2
			
			
			Presents with a characteristic "crazy pavement" appearance
			
		
		
			
			C
			
			
			Mesothelioma
			
			
			3
			
			
			Affects the pleura
			
		
		
			
			D
			
			
			Sarcoidosis
			
			
			4
			
			
			Exhibits the presence of pleural effusion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - A-1, B-4, C-3, D-2

The correct match is:

A

Caplan syndrome

1

Initially observed in coal workers

B

Asbestosis

4

Exhibits the presence of pleural effusion

C

Mesothelioma

3

Affects the pleura

D

Sarcoidosis

2

Presents with a characteristic "crazy pavement" appearance


Caplan syndrome:

  • It is characterised by the formation of multiple well-defined pulmonary nodules, typically located in the lung periphery, in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis who have been exposed to inorganic dust.
  • This syndrome is specifically associated with coal worker's pneumoconiosis but can also occur in other forms of pneumoconiosis.

Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibres. Pleural effusion can be seen in the advanced stages of the disease.

Mesothelioma is a rare and aggressive malignant tumour originating from the mesothelial cells lining the pleura (the thin membrane surrounding the lungs).

Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, but it most commonly involves the lungs and lymph nodes.

  • The term "crazy pavement" is not specifically associated with sarcoidosis.
  • It is a radiographic appearance seen in certain lung conditions, particularly pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, where the lung tissue exhibits a mosaic pattern resembling crazy paving.

questions.text:
What is the correct order for cardiac auscultation, from superior to inferior?

a. Pulmonary

b. Tricuspid

c. Mitral
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - a > b > c

  • The correct order for auscultation of the heart sounds from superior to inferior is aortic > pulmonary > Erb’s point > tricuspid > mitral. (mnemonic: APE to Man)

"APE to Man" refers to:

  • Aortic Valve: To listen to the aortic valve closing, place the stethoscope on the right side of the sternum at the 2nd intercostal space.
  • Pulmonary Valve: To listen to the pulmonic valve closing, place the stethoscope on the left side of the sternum at the 2nd intercostal space.
  • Erb’s Point (where S2 sound is best heard): Located on the left side at the 3rd intercostal space.

questions.text: What immunological abnormality is observed due to the absence of CD40 in B cells?

choices.text: Decreased IgG and increase in IgM
Inability of neutrophils to act against infections

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Decreased IgG and increase in IgM

  • When there is an absence of the CD40 ligand in the B lymphocytes, they cannot switch, leading to the production of only IgM and hence will have a normal or increased IgM level (hyper IgM syndrome).

Hyper IgM syndrome

  • A rare primary immunodeficiency disorder characterised by low or absent IgG, IgA, and IgE, with normal or increased IgM levels.

Causes: Results from various X-linked or autosomal mutations.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Pulmonary complications (e.g., infections)
  • Gastrointestinal issues
  • Autoimmune diseases
  • Hematologic abnormalities
  • Lymphoproliferation
  • Increased risk of malignancies

Diagnosis: Based on immunoglobulin levels and genetic testing.

Management:

  • Treatment varies depending on the genetic mutation and clinical presentation.
  • Options may include immunoglobulin replacement therapy, antibiotics, and management of associated complications.

Prognosis:

  • Depends on the severity of symptoms and timely treatment, but early diagnosis and management can improve outcomes.

A total lack of NK cells (Option A) or natural killer deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that has a genetic mechanism causing it. This is not associated with hyper IgM syndrome.

Lack of CD8-mediated cytotoxicity (Option B) can be as a result of many chronic autoimmune diseases (like multiple sclerosis, rheumatoid arthritis, SLE, etc). It can also be seen in healthy blood relatives of people with autoimmune disorders. However, it is not associated with increased IgM production.

The inability of neutrophils to act against infections (Option D) is not associated with the absence of CD40 ligand of B cells.

questions.text: All of the following tests are done for screening in patients with Turner’s syndrome, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - ANA

  • The ANA test is not typically performed as part of Turner mosaic screening. ANA testing is primarily used to help diagnose autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or other connective tissue diseases.

Condition

Evaluation

Cardiac Abnormalities

EKG (for prolonged QT interval), Blood pressure (upper and lower extremities), Echocardiogram (Option C) or Cardiac MRI for anomalies.

Cognitive Function/Learning Disabilities

Special education assessments and evaluations at school.

Hearing Loss

Serial audiology evaluations (Option B) every 3 years in children, and every 5 years in adults.

Renal Abnormalities

Renal ultrasound at diagnosis.

Ovarian Failure

Serum FSH and AMH at 10-11 years.

Osteoporosis/Bone Health

Screening for low bone mineral density and fractures. Annual screening for scoliosis during growth hormone therapy.

Celiac Disease

Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibodies at 2 years, and every 2 years thereafter.

Autoimmune Thyroiditis

TSH and free or total T4 measurements annually starting at 4 years.

Liver Disease

ALT, AST, GGT, and alkaline phosphatase annually after 10 years.

Metabolic Syndrome

Hemoglobin A1c annually, starting at 10 years.

Lipid panel annually if cardiovascular risk factors are present.

Vitamin D Deficiency

Serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D at 9-11 years, and every 2-3 years thereafter.

Gonadoblastoma

Screening for Y chromosome if marker chromosome elements are present or virilization develops.

Screening Laboratory Tests

Fasting blood glucose (Option D), glycated haemoglobin, serum creatinine, and urinalysis at 10 years and above to screen for diabetes mellitus and kidney disease.

questions.text: An elderly patient was brought to the OPD with complaints of tremors, stoop posture and slow movements. His son also gives a history of the patient forgetting day to day activities. What is the possible cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Lewy body:

  • The scenario here points to the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia which is a neurodegenerative disorder characterised by dementia and signs of Parkinson’s disease.
  • Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) includes Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD) and dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), which are the second most common cause of neurodegenerative dementia after Alzheimer’s disease.

Prevalence:

  • The incidence of DLB is approximately 7 per 100,000 person-years, with both PDD and DLB becoming more common with age and affecting men more often than women.

Cognitive Features:

  • Common in both PDD and DLB: Severe executive, attentional, and visuospatial deficits with preserved episodic memory.
  • Fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism are key features, especially in DLB.
  • Day-to-day variations in cognitive function are often seen, with periods of confusion or lethargy that resolve quickly.

Motor Symptoms:

  • Parkinsonism in DLB often includes postural instability, which can emerge early or later.

Other Symptoms:

  • REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a common and early sign.
  • Symptoms like anosmia, constipation, depression, and anxiety may precede or accompany the cognitive decline.

Diagnostic Features:

  • PDD typically develops after long-standing Parkinson’s disease with cognitive decline, visual hallucinations, and fluctuating attention.
  • DLB involves early dementia and neuropsychiatric symptoms like hallucinations and fluctuating cognition, occurring alongside or before parkinsonism.

Pathology:

  • Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites are present in key brain areas, including the brainstem, substantia nigra, amygdala, and cortex.
  • These inclusions are composed of α-synuclein aggregates, making LBD a synucleinopathy.
  • The progression follows three stages: brainstem predominant, transitional limbic, and diffuse neocortical.

Pathogenesis:

  • Both genetic factors (e.g., α-synuclein duplications, mutations in the glucocerebrosidase gene) and environmental factors, such as toxins, may contribute to LBD development.
  • LBD might spread via a prion-like mechanism, propagating from peripheral areas like the gastrointestinal system or olfactory bulb to the brain.

Cholinergic and Adrenergic Deficits:

  • DLB shows a profound cholinergic deficit, contributing to cognitive fluctuations and hallucinations.
  • Adrenergic deficits, especially from the locus coeruleus, further impair alertness and arousal.

Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) (Option A) can cause a triad of symptoms known as Hakim's triad, which includes gait disturbances, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment. The triad is not present in the given scenario.

Hypothyroidism (Option B) can lead to various symptoms, including cognitive impairment, depression, and memory problems. But the given scenario does not provide any relation to it.

Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option D) can lead to neurological symptoms, including cognitive impairment and dementia-like symptoms. However, the given scenario is not associated with this.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman experiences skin thickening, muscle weakness, and pale peripheries upon cold exposure. Her creatine kinase is increased with positive ANA, and biopsy revealed scl-70 positivity and perifascicular infiltration. What is the antibody linked to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Anti PM /Scl antibody

Raynaud’s phenomenon and scl-70 positivity signify systemic sclerosis (diffuse). The peri fascicular infiltration and raised creatine kinase signify the presence of dermatomyositis/ polymyositis. Hence, this is called overlap syndrome (dermatomyositis/ polymyositis + systemic sclerosis), and the antibody linked to this combined scenario is Anti PM/ Scl antibody.

  • Overlap Syndrome occurs when dermatomyositis (DM) or polymyositis (PM) coexists with other connective tissue diseases (CTDs), such as scleroderma, mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD), Sjögren’s syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), or rheumatoid arthritis.

Polymyositis

  • Clinical Features:
    • Polymyositis (PM) presents with symmetric, proximal muscle weakness that worsens over weeks to months.
    • PM can involve the heart, lungs, and joints and is associated with an increased risk of cancer, although likely less than dermatomyositis (DM).
  • Laboratory Features:
    • Creatine kinase (CK) levels always elevate in uncontrolled PM; normal CK suggests the inclusion of body myositis.
    • Electromyography (EMG) and muscle imaging can show abnormalities but are not specific to PM.
  • Histopathology and Pathogenesis:
    • PM shows varied muscle pathology, with nonspecific inflammatory cells found more often in the perimysium than in the endomysium.
    • CD8+ T cells and macrophages are the primary inflammatory cells in the endomysial, perimysial, and perivascular regions.

 

Systemic sclerosis

Features

Diffuse

Limited

Skin involvement

Proximal & Distal extremities, face, trunk

Distal to elbows, face

Raynaud’s Phenomenon

Onset <1 year/at the time of skin changes

Precede skin diseases by years

Organ Involvement
  • Pulmonary (Interstitial fibrosis),
  • Renal (Renovascular hypertensive crisis),
  • GI & Cardiac

GI, Biliary cirrhosis, Pulmonary artery hypertension

Nail fold capillaries

Dilatation and dropout

Dilatation without significant dropout

Antinuclear antibodies

Anti-topoisomerase 1

Anticentromere

 

Autoantibodies in systemic sclerosis

Auto-Antibody

SSc SUBSET

Prominent characteristic

Topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

dcSSc
  • Speckled pattern

 

  • Tendon friction rubs, digital ischemic ulcers, scleroderma, extensive skin involvement, early ILD, cardiac involvement, scleroderma renal crisis

Centromere proteins

lcSSc
  • Discrete speckled (centromere) pattern
  • Digital ischemic ulcers, calcinosis cutis, isolated PAH; renal crisis rare

RNA polymerase III

dcSSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • Rapidly progressive skin involvement, tendon friction rubs, joint contractures, GAVE, renal crisis, contemporaneous cancers; digital ulcers rare

U3-RNP (fibrillarin)

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • PAH, ILD, scleroderma renal crisis, GI tract involvement, myositis

Th/To

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • ILD, PAH

PM/Scl

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • Calcinosis cutis, ILD, myositis overlap

Ku

overlap
  • Speckled pattern
  • SLE, myositis overlap

U1-RNP

dc/lc SSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • PAH, inflammatory arthritis, myositis overlap

U11/U12 RNP

dc/lc SSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • ILD

Anti Jo1 antibody (Option B) is positive in antisynthetase syndrome which presents with myositis, non-erosive arthritis, interstitial lung disease, Raynaud’s phenomenon, mechanic’s hand, and fever. This is not the given scenario.

Anticentromere antibody (Option C) is positive in CREST syndrome which is a subtype of limited scleroderma and presents with calcinosis, Raynaud’s phenomenon, oesophagal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasis. This is not the given scenario.

Anti-nuclear antibody (Option D) is positive in many autoimmune disorders and already provided in the scenario.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory. On examination his BMI is 41 kg/m2, BP is 160/100 mm Hg. His awake ABG analysis is given:


	PaO2= 66mm Hg
	PaCO2= 50 mm Hg
	HCO3= 28 mEq/L


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Obesity hypo-ventilation syndrome

Obesity hypo-ventilation syndrome (OHS) is defined by raised 'awake' arterial pressure of carbon dioxide levels in patients with obesity for whom alternative causes of hypercapnia and hypoventilation have been excluded.

  • This is caused due to obesity causing a restriction in lung filling and this causes hypoventilation.
  • In this patient with hypercapnia while awake, with compensatory metabolic alkalosis, the diagnosis is likely OHS.

Diagnosis Criteria:

  • Body mass index (BMI) ≥30 kg/m².
  • Chronic daytime alveolar hypoventilation, defined as Paco2 ≥45 mmHg in the absence of other causes.
  • Evidence of sleep-disordered breathing, usually in the form of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

Risk Factors:

  • Severe obesity (BMI >40 kg/m²) and severe obstructive sleep apnea (AHI >30 events/hour) are considered risk factors for OHS.

Pathophysiology:

  • Hypoventilation is caused by factors like OSA, increased work of breathing, respiratory muscle impairment due to excess adiposity, and poor ventilatory response to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
  • These issues can improve with the treatment of sleep-disordered breathing (CPAP or NIPPV), suggesting that impaired ventilatory drive is a consequence, not the cause, of OHS.

Treatment:

  • Weight reduction: Significant weight loss (20–25% of body weight) can normalize Paco2, but weight loss alone is challenging without bariatric surgery.
  • Positive airway pressure:
    • CPAP or NIPPV (Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation) during sleep is the primary treatment.
    • CPAP is effective in improving daytime hypercapnia and hypoxemia, especially in patients with severe OSA.
    • Bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) should be used for those who cannot tolerate CPAP or if obstructive events persist.
    • Bilevel PAP with a backup rate (BiPAP ST or volume-assured pressure support) is suggested for persistent hypercapnia or acute decompensated OHS.

Management of Comorbidities:

  • Other conditions that impair ventilation, such as COPD, should be treated concurrently with OHS.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) (Option A) is a disorder that is characterized by obstructive apneas and hypopneas due to repetitive collapse of the upper airway during sleep. The clinical features against OSA include hypercapnia and hypoxemia in an awake individual.

Narcolepsy (Option B) is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, sudden loss of muscle tone (cataplexy), and disrupted sleep patterns. While impaired concentration and memory can be seen in narcolepsy, the ABG is normal.

Central sleep apnea (Option D) is a condition in which there is a lack of respiratory effort during sleep, leading to pauses in breathing. Impaired concentration and memory can occur in central sleep apnea.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is recently approved to be used in patients with heart failure with low ejection fraction and reduced urine output?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Empagliflozin

  • Anti-diabetic drugs reducing cardiovascular mortality are SGLT2 inhibitors (Empagliflozin, Dapagliflozin) and GLP1 agonists (Semaglutide, Dulaglutide).

Drug Class

Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) Inhibitors

Examples
  • Canagliflozin
  • Dapagliflozin
  • Empagliflozin (Option B)

Mechanism of Action

Blocks reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubule, promoting the excretion of sodium and glucose in urine

Indications
  • Reduce progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD)
  • Diuretic effect, leading to sodium loss
  • Reduces systolic blood pressure (SBP) by 3-6 mmHg
  • Cardiorenal advantage
  • CHF to decrease mortality with or without DM

Side Effects
  • Increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Glucosuria (leading to UTIs and vulvovaginal candidiasis)
  • Dehydration (orthostatic hypotension)
  • Weight loss

Contraindications
  • Not recommended if estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) < 45 ml/min
  • Use with caution in renal insufficiency (decreased efficacy with decreased GFR)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Linagliptin (Option A): It is a DPP-4 inhibitor. The DPP 4 enzyme is responsible for the breakdown of incretins such as GLP-1.

Pioglitazone (Option C): These drugs have been shown to cause dose-dependent fluid retention, hence this drug class is generally avoided in patients with heart failure.

Degludec (Option D): Insulin degludec is a long-acting insulin used to treat hyperglycemia caused by type 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the ER in an unconscious state after severe vomiting and abdominal pain episodes. HR = 100/min and BP=100/60 mm Hg.

Work up shows:


	pH=7.2
	Blood glucose 300 mg/dl
	Ketone 3+.


What should be the best management?

choices.text: Infusion of 0.05 – 0.1 U/kg dose insulin after 1 hour of IVF
0.1 Unit/kg insulin stat followed infusion of 0.5 U- 0.1 U/kg dose insulin and IVF
0.1 U/kg insulin subcutaneous stat followed by IVF
IVF followed by subcutaneous 0.1 U/kg insulin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Infusion of 0.05 – 0.1 U/kg dose insulin after 1 hour of IVF:

  • The clinical scenario here points to the diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis.

Diagnostic parameters in an unconscious diabetic patient:

Parameters

Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)

pH (7.35-7.45)

6.8 - 7.3

HCO3¯ (22 to 26 meq/L)

<18

Ketostix

++++

Plasma beta-hydroxybutyrate

>2.5

RBS (mg/dL)

250 - 600

Plasma Osmolality (275 to 295 mOsm/kg)

300 - 320

 

Updated Management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (ISPAD 2022):

Contraindication of Insulin Drip:

  • Insulin should be withheld if the serum potassium level is below 3.3 mmol/L.
  • The target is to maintain serum potassium levels above 3.5 mmol/L (3.5 meq/L) to start the insulin drip.
  • Hypokalemia can lead to diaphragmatic paralysis and potentially result in respiratory arrest.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with palpitations, weight loss, tremors, sweating and diarrhoea. What is the next test that will help establish the diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - TSH and free T4

  • The TSH and T4 are the primary screening tests for thyroid function, and low TSH and high free T4 levels indicate hyperthyroidism, which matches the symptoms described.

Thyroid Function Test Workup:

  • Initial Screening: TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone)
    • Normal range: 0.4-4.0 mIU/L
  • Follow-up Tests (if TSH is abnormal):
    • Free T4 (thyroxine)
    • Free T3 (triiodothyronine) if T4 is normal but TSH is suppressed (Option C)
    • Consider total T4 and T3 tests, but free hormone tests are preferred
  • Interpretation of Results:

Condition

↑

  • Additional Tests for Etiology:
    • Anti-TPO (thyroid peroxidase) antibodies (Option B)
      • Positive in 5-15% of euthyroid women, up to 2% of euthyroid men
      • Present in almost all autoimmune hypothyroidism cases
      • Present in up to 80% of Graves' disease cases
    • TRAb (TSH receptor antibody) or TSI (Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin)
      • For Graves' disease diagnosis
      • Used to predict remission after antithyroid drug treatment
      • Important in pregnancy to assess the risk of fetal/neonatal thyrotoxicosis
    • ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Thyroglobulin (Tg)
      • Elevated in all types of thyrotoxicosis except factitia
      • Main use: follow-up of thyroid cancer patients post-treatment
  • Imaging Studies:
    • Thyroid Ultrasound (Option D)
      • Indication: All patients with suspected thyroid nodules
      • Evaluate nodule characteristics (size, composition, echogenicity, margins, calcifications)
  • Fine Needle Aspiration (FNA) Biopsy:
    • Indicated for suspicious nodules based on ultrasound criteria
    • Ultrasound-guided FNA preferred for improved accuracy
  • Radioactive iodine uptake scan: While useful in differentiating causes of hyperthyroidism (e.g., Graves' disease vs. thyroiditis), it is not the immediate next best step. It is the next step after TFT shows a hyperthyroid picture.
    • Graves' disease: Enlarged gland, homogeneous increased uptake
    • Toxic adenoma: Focal area of increased uptake, suppressed remainder
    • Toxic multinodular goitre: Multiple areas of increased/decreased uptake
    • Thyroiditis: Very low uptake
    • Thyrotoxicosis factitia: Low uptake

questions.text: A young patient developed hyperpigmentation of distal fingers after being hospitalized post-adrenalectomy. What could be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Nelson syndrome

  • Nelson syndrome is a rare condition that occurs in patients who have had both adrenal glands removed (bilateral adrenalectomy) as a treatment for Cushing's disease.
  • The hyperpigmentation of distal fingers post-adrenalectomy is due to the development of pituitary adenoma that produces excess adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), especially in areas exposed to friction and pressure, such as the distal fingers.

Nelson syndrome/post-adrenalectomy syndrome

Definition

Nelson's syndrome is a condition that typically occurs after bilateral adrenalectomy for the treatment of Cushing's disease (pituitary-dependent Cushing’s syndrome). The removal of the adrenal glands leads to a lack of negative feedback on the pituitary, resulting in increased secretion of ACTH. Over time, the pituitary gland may develop a pituitary adenoma (or enlargement of an existing adenoma), which secretes ACTH in excess.

Prevention

Prophylactic radiation therapy may be indicated to prevent the development of Nelson’s syndrome after adrenalectomy

Clinical features

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Progressive visual loss in cases of large tumours
  • Headache
  • Weakness and fatigue
  • Inhibition of the release of other pituitary hormones

Evaluation

  • Fasting Plasma ACTH Levels:
    • Very high levels.
    • Diagnosis confirmed by an ACTH increase >30% of the initial result on three consecutive samples after bilateral adrenalectomy.
  • Decreased levels of anterior pituitary hormones.
  • Brain MRI shows pituitary tumours or enlargement of existing tumours.
  • Screening:
    • Regular screening with fasting plasma ACTH levels and brain MRI in patients after bilateral adrenalectomy.

Management

  • Surgical Removal of the Tumor
  • Radiotherapy / Radiosurgery
  • Medical Treatment
  • Hormonal Replacement Therapy

Addison's disease (Option A) involves primary adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands do not produce sufficient steroid hormones. Hyperpigmentation can occur due to increased ACTH levels, but Addison's disease is typically associated with adrenal atrophy or autoimmune destruction, not post-adrenalectomy.

Conn's syndrome (Option B), or primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by excessive production of aldosterone by the adrenal glands. It does not typically cause hyperpigmentation. Symptoms are usually related to hypertension and hypokalemia.

Cushing syndrome (Option D) is caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. It usually leads to symptoms such as central obesity, moon face, and purple striae, rather than hyperpigmentation of the fingers.

questions.text: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in a hospitalized patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Malignancy

The most common cause of hypercalcemia in a hospitalized patient is malignancy.

  • In malignancy-associated hypercalcemia, the disease is usually not occult; rather, symptoms of malignancy bring the patient to the physician, and hypercalcemia is discovered during the evaluation.
  • In such patients, the interval between detection of hypercalcemia and death, especially without vigorous treatment, is often <6 months.

Hypercalcemic crisis

Aetiology:

  • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
    • Paraneoplastic syndromes in Squamous cell carcinoma of lungs
    • Breast carcinoma
  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Vitamin D toxicity
  • Milk alkali syndrome
  • Jansen disease: Autosomal dominant defect in PTHR-1 leading to receptor gain mutation (hyperactive receptor)
  • Lithium toxicity: Causes diabetes insipidus and activation of parathyroid glands.
  • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia: Autosomal dominant defect in CaSR receptor in parathyroid and kidneys, which leads to excess PTH secretion

Investigations:

  • Serum electrolytes: ↑ calcium and ↓ phosphate.
  • ↑ Serum alkaline phosphatase.
  • ↑↑↑ Serum PTH in cases of parathyroid adenoma

Treatment:

  • Aggressive hydration with normal saline: First-line management to correct dehydration and promote renal calcium excretion.
  • Forced diuresis with loop diuretics: Can be used after adequate hydration to enhance calcium excretion in the urine.
  • Intravenous Zoledronate: Drug of choice for lowering calcium. It begins to act within 1-2 days and lasts up to 3 weeks.
  • Calcitonin: Promotes calcium deposition in bones but may develop tachyphylaxis (reduced response over time).
  • Denosumab: Inhibits osteoclast differentiation by binding to RANK ligand, reducing bone resorption.
  • Peritoneal dialysis: Indicated in renal failure, it can rapidly reverse life-threatening hypercalcemia.

Parathyroid Adenoma (Option B): Primary hyperparathyroidism, most commonly due to a parathyroid adenoma, is the leading cause of hypercalcemia in the outpatient setting rather than hospitalized patients. It leads to increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), causing increased calcium resorption from bones and reduced renal calcium excretion.

Parathyroid Hyperplasia (Option C): Parathyroid hyperplasia causes primary hyperparathyroidism, but it is less common than parathyroid adenoma. It is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes, particularly MEN 1 and MEN 2A. Like adenomas, it is more commonly seen in outpatient settings rather than as a cause of acute hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients.

Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (Option D): While follicular thyroid carcinoma can sometimes lead to bone metastases, resulting in hypercalcemia, it is not a common cause. Hypercalcemia from malignancy is more often seen in cancers that secrete PTHrP (e.g., squamous cell lung cancer) or cause direct bone destruction (e.g., multiple myeloma).

questions.text:
Which among the following statements best describes the appropriate mechanism involved in coughing?


	Forceful expiration against a closed glottis
	Expiration against an open glottis
	Normal inspiration
	Removing harmful substances
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) 1,4

Explanation:

Forceful expiration against a closed glottis:

  • This describes the initial phase of a cough.
  • The cough reflex begins with a deep inhalation, followed by the closure of the glottis (the opening between the vocal cords).
  • The expiratory muscles then contract forcefully, increasing the pressure in the chest. When the glottis suddenly opens, the built-up pressure is released, producing a forceful expulsion of air and any irritants in the airway.

Removing harmful substances:

  • Coughing clears the respiratory tract of irritants, such as mucus, dust, smoke, or other harmful substances.
  • This is a protective reflex mechanism aimed at keeping the airways clear and preventing the aspiration of foreign materials.

Expiration against an open glottis (Statement 2): happens during sneezing. Hence, this statement is incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the incision made and marked in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gibson Abernathy

Explanation:

  • The given image shows Gibson Abernathy's incision.

Gibson Abernathy incision:

  • Primary Use: Provides access to the lower/distal part of the ureter.
  • Procedure Steps: The patient is placed in a supine position. The incision is made 1 inch medial to the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS), extending 1 inch above the inguinal ligament toward the pubic symphysis.
  • Indications:
    • Renal transplant offers less trauma and convenient access to the iliac fossa and bladder.
    • Laparoscopic surgery is used as access for the non-dominant hand.
    • Open nephroureterectomy, facilitates splitting the rectus fascia and developing the space of Retzius for distal ureterectomy.
    • Kidney excision and removal of the renal specimen from the entrapment sac.

Incision Type

Description

Common Uses

Abdominal Incisions

Midline

Longitudinal cut through the linea alba, bloodless access

Exploratory laparotomy, trauma surgery, emergency surgeries

Periumbilical

Incisions around the umbilicus, avoiding the umbilical stalk

Laparoscopy, umbilical hernia repairs, postpartum tubal ligation

Pararectus

Along the semilunar line, lateral to the rectus abdominis

Abdominal wall hernia repairs, stoma creation, pelvic surgeries

Paramedian

Lateral to the linea alba, access to lateral viscera

Lateral abdominal structures,

Reduced hernia risk

Kocher/Subcostal

Inferior and parallel to the costal margin, access to upper abdomen structures

Gallbladder, biliary tree, pancreas, liver transplants, epigastric surgeries

Gridiron/

McBurney/

Lanz

Lower abdomen incisions, typically for appendectomy

Appendectomy (right side), sigmoid diverticulitis (left side), cosmetic appendectomy

Thoracoabdominal

From 7th intercostal space to the umbilicus, exposes thoracic and abdominal organs

Retroperitoneal masses, pleural space, distal oesophagus, abdominal organs

Thoracic Incisions

Thoracotomy

Access to thoracic structures, various approaches

Lung transplants, cardiac surgeries, trauma

Median Sternotomy

Vertical incision dividing the sternum, wide access to the mediastinum

Open-heart surgery, anterior mediastinal tumour resection

Trapdoor

Complex incision, supraclavicular, sternal, and thoracotomy components

Penetrating trauma, aortic arch aneurysms, complex cardiovascular access

Infraclavicular

A transverse incision just below the clavicle for subclavian vessel access

Thoracic outlet syndrome, subclavian vessel surgeries

Supraclavicular

Superior to the clavicle, providing access to the subclavian vessels

Trauma, thoracic outlet syndrome

Neck Incisions

Collar

Incision above the sternal notch for thyroid surgeries

Thyroid surgery, mid-neck structures

Traumatic Neck

Along the sternocleidomastoid muscle for trauma

Vascular or traumatic neck injuries

Tracheostomy

Vertical/horizontal incision superior to the thyroid for tracheostomy

Airway management in patients needing long-term ventilation

Pelvic Incisions

Pfannenstiel

Transverse incision above the pubic symphysis

Cesarean section, pelvic, urologic, and orthopaedic surgeries

Maylard/Cherney

Above pubic tubercle provides access to pelvic structures

Hysterectomy, pelvic lymph node dissection, lower pelvis surgeries

Inguinal

Above and parallel to the inguinal ligament

Inguinal hernia repair, urologic surgeries (cryptorchidism, varicocele)

McEvedy

Vertical incision for femoral hernia repair

Femoral hernia repair (obsolete now due to high hernia recurrence rate)

Gibson

Above inguinal ligament, arc to the lateral rectus sheath

Kidney transplantation, retroperitoneal access (iliac vessels, ureter)

questions.text: Identify the test provided in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Allen’s test

Explanation:

The given image shows Allen’s test.

Allen's Test is a clinical manoeuvre used to assess the blood flow to the hand, specifically evaluating the patency of the radial and ulnar arteries. It is commonly used before procedures like inserting an arterial line or taking a blood sample from the radial artery.

  • Procedure:
    • The patient is asked to make a fist, compressing the radial and ulnar arteries simultaneously.
    • The patient is then asked to open their hand (which should appear pale).
    • Once the hand is open, the examiner releases one of the arteries (usually the ulnar artery).
    • The test is positive if normal colour returns to the hand quickly (within 5-10 seconds), indicating adequate collateral circulation.
  • If there is a delay in the colour return or no return, this may suggest compromised blood flow through the released artery, which could indicate arterial occlusion & the radial artery should not be pricked.

 

Adson's test (Option B) is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), which occurs due to compression of the brachial plexus or subclavian artery in the thoracic outlet.

  • The patient is instructed to extend their neck and turn their head toward the arm being tested while the examiner palpates the radial pulse. The patient then takes a deep breath. A positive test is indicated by a reduction or disappearance of the radial pulse, suggesting compression in the thoracic outlet.

 

Elevated Arm Stress Test (Option C) evaluates thoracic outlet syndrome by assessing the compression of neurovascular structures in the thoracic outlet.

  • The patient’s arms are raised above the head and held for 1-2 minutes. A positive test occurs if the patient experiences symptoms of numbness, tingling, or a decrease in the radial pulse, which indicates compression of the neurovascular bundle in the thoracic outlet.

 

Nicoladoni's test (Option D) is used to assess for increased intracranial pressure (ICP) or brainstem compression.

  • The test is positive if the patient exhibits a sudden drop in pulse or blood pressure when their head is tilted backwards (in a hyperextended position).
