questions.text:
The marked structure relays efferents to which nucleus of the thalamus?

[
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anterior nucleus of thalamus

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is the fornix.
  • Fornix is the major efferent tract of the hippocampus.
  • The fornix sends efferents to the mammillary bodies, and the mammillothalamic tract connects the mammillary bodies to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus.
  • This pathway is part of the Papez circuit, involved in memory and emotional processing.

Thalamic Nuclei and their Connection:

  • Anterior nucleus
    • Receives input from hypothalamic mammillary nuclei via mammillothalamic tract.
    • Receives input from the hippocampus via fornix.
    • Projects fibers to the cingulate gyrus.
  • Dorsomedial nucleus
    • Part of the limbic system.
    • Lesion results in memory loss (Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome).
  • Intralaminar nuclei
    • Receives input from the reticular formation.
    • Projects fibers to the neocortex.
    • Sends fibers to other thalamic nuclei (unlike other thalamic nuclei, which project to different cortical areas).
  • Dorsal tier nucleus
    • Lateral dorsal nucleus: Posterior extension of the anterior nucleus.
    • Pulvinar:
      • Largest thalamic nucleus.
      • Receives input from the lateral and medial geniculate bodies.
      • Integrates visual and auditory input.
  • Ventral tier nucleus
    • Ventral anterior nucleus:
      • Receives input from globus pallidus and substantia nigra.
      • Projects fibers to the motor cortex.
    • Ventral posterior nucleus:
      • Contains three subnuclei:
        • Ventral posterolateral (VPL): Receives input from spinothalamic tracts and medial lemniscus.
        • Ventral posteromedial (VPM): Receives input from trigeminothalamic tracts.
        • Ventral posterior inferior (VPI): Receives input from vestibular nuclei.

 

Lateral nucleus of thalamus (Option B): The lateral nucleus functions as the hunger center, promoting eating when stimulated, while its destruction leads to starvation.

Ventro-postero-lateral nucleus of thalamus (Option C): The ventro-postero-lateral nucleus of the thalamus processes sensations like pain, vibration, proprioception, and light touch from the spinothalamic tract and dorsal column pathways.

Posterior nucleus of the thalamus (Option D): The posterior nucleus aids in thermoregulation by promoting heat conservation. It triggers the sympathetic nervous system, causing peripheral vasoconstriction to retain heat.

questions.text: Which is a rare but very serious side effect of clozapine that requires regular monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Agranulocytosis

  • Clozapine (atypical antipsychotic) is prescribed for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and is associated with a rare but serious side effect, agranulocytosis, which requires regular monitoring.

Adverse effects of Clozapine:

Serious Adverse Effects of Clozapine

Agranulocytosis
  • Rare but life-threatening decrease in white blood cells, requiring weekly monitoring.
  • Discontinue if total leukocyte count < 3000/mm³ or absolute neutrophil count < 2000/mm³.
  • Avoid combining with carbamazepine.
  • Monitoring of agranulocytosis: 1st 6 weeks - weekly; Next 6 months- Fortnightly; After 1 year- Monthly

Seizures
  • Dose-dependent seizure risk. Higher than other atypical antipsychotics.

Cardiac Effects
  • Risk of tachycardia, myocarditis (fatal, within first 6 wks) and dilated cardiomyopathy.

Non-serious Adverse effects of Clozapine

Hypersalivation

  • Known as "wet pillow syndrome" due to muscarinic receptor stimulation.

Metabolic Complications
  • Significant risk of weight gain, hyperglycemia, and dyslipidemia.
  • Associated with increased appetite due to 5-HT2C receptor blockade.

Cataracts
  • Higher risk than other atypical antipsychotics.

Effects on Pregnancy and Breastfeeding
  • Can cause decreased arousal and hypotonia in neonates.
  • C/I during breastfeeding due to the risk of neutropenia, sedation, and seizures in infants.

Renal bleed (Option B): Renal bleeding refers to bleeding within the kidneys or urinary tract. Renal bleeding is not a well-established side effect specifically associated with clozapine.

Hepatomegaly (Option C): Hepatomegaly refers to an enlargement of the liver. While clozapine treatment can cause mild elevations in liver enzymes, significant hepatomegaly is not a common side effect.

Seizures (Option D): Clozapine can lower the seizure threshold, increasing the risk of seizures, particularly at higher doses. Patients with a history of seizures or epilepsy may be more susceptible. If seizures occur, appropriate medical management and dose adjustments may be necessary. However, this is not a serious complication at normal therapeutic levels.

questions.text: A patient underwent a hysterectomy and was given morphine in the post-operative period and in the ward for pain. She now presents with respiratory depression and pinpoint pupils. What is the drug used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Naloxone

  • Naloxone, an opioid antagonist, is the treatment of choice for reversing opioid overdose in this patient, who shows signs such as respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils, and dizziness, which are consistent with opioid overdose.
  • It works by binding to opioid receptors in the body, blocking the effects of opioids, and rapidly reversing respiratory depression.

Opioid Overdose/ Poisoning

Cause

Clinical, accidental, or suicidal overdose.

Symptoms
  • Unconsiousness/coma
  • Miosis: Pin point pupil
  • Respiratory depression
  • Dry secretion in the eye/mouth
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Flaccid muscles
  • Convulsions (in children)

Management

Acute overdose/poisoning: IV Naloxone (Antidote) → Maintenance (Detoxification phase: To prevent withdrawal):

  • Opioids: Buprenorphine, Methadone, Tramadol
  • Non-Opioids- Clonidine, Lofexidine → Abstinence (Prevent relapse):
  • DOC: Oral Naltrexone

Atropine (Option B) is a medication that belongs to the class of anticholinegic drugs. It is primarily used to increase heart rate and treat certain types of bradycardia (slow heart rate). While atropine may be useful in specific situations, such as in the treatment of bradycardia or organophosphate poisoning, it is not the appropriate drug for reversing respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose.

Phentolamine (Option C) is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist medication primarily used for the treatment of high blood pressure, certain types of vasospasm, and to counteract the effects of excessive levels of catecholamines. It is not indicated for reversing respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose.

Physostigmine (Option D) is a cholinesterase inhibitor that increases the levels of acetylcholine in the body. It is primarily used to reverse anticholinergic toxicity and certain types of drug-induced delirium. However, it is not indicated for the reversal of respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of pain in the genital area. On examination, there is a painful vesicle. Further examination also reveals tender lymphadenopathy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HSV-2

Explanation:

The scenario of painful genital ulcers, flu-like symptoms, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a history of multiple sexual partners is most likely indicative of a Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV 2) infection.

Genital lesions of HSV

  • Mostly seen in HSV type 2.
  • Bilateral, painful genital vesiculo-ulcerative lesions.

  • Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • Site: Lesions are mainly seen on,
    • Males: The penis or in the urethra (urethritis).
  • Females: The cervix, vagina, vulva and perineum
  • It is associated with systemic features like fever (flu-like) and malaise.
  • In pregnant females, a cesarean is preferred over normal labour to prevent vertical transmission.

Molluscum (Option B): Molluscum contagiosum, caused by the Molluscum contagiosum virus, presents as painless, dome-shaped, umbilicated papules. It does not cause vesicular lesions or significant lymphadenopathy.

HPV (Option C): Human papillomavirus (HPV) causes genital warts, which appear as painless, verrucous growths (condyloma acuminata). Unlike HSV-2, HPV does not present with painful vesicles or tender lymphadenopathy.

HZV (Option D): Herpes zoster virus (HZV) causes painful vesicular eruptions following a dermatomal distribution. While it can affect the genital area (e.g., sacral zoster), it does not typically cause inguinal lymphadenopathy unless secondarily infected.

questions.text: Which is true about the KEYNOTE 189 trial?

choices.text: Pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy used in NSCLC
Nivolumab plus chemotherapy used in NSCLC

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy used in NSCLC

  • The patient's symptoms, CT findings, molecular testing, and biopsy tests of adenocarcinoma (the most common subtype of NSCLC) results are typical presentations for a patient with non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC).
  • Here, the patient has high PD-L1 expression (>50%).
  • Pembrolizumab is particularly effective in NSCLC patients with high PD-L1 expression (≥50%) and is approved as a first-line treatment for these patients when there are no actionable mutations in EGFR, ALK, or ROS1.
  • The KEYNOTE -189 trial investigated the use of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy in the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
  • Conclusion of trial: In patients with previously untreated metastatic nonsquamous NSCLC without EGFR or ALK mutations, the addition of pembrolizumab to standard chemotherapy of pemetrexed and a platinum-based drug resulted in significantly longer overall survival and progression-free survival than chemotherapy alone.

Nivolumab plus chemotherapy used in NSCLC (Option B): The KEYNOTE-189 trial specifically focused on pembrolizumab and not nivolumab.

Pembrolizumab is used in NSCLC (Option C): The KEYNOTE-189 trial investigated the combination of pembrolizumab with chemotherapy, not pembrolizumab alone, to treat NSCLC. The study had two treatment arms: one receiving pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy and the other receiving a placebo alongside chemotherapy.

Nivolumab is used in NSCLC (Option D): The KEYNOTE-189 trial did not evaluate nivolumab for the treatment of NSCLC.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is derived from the marked point in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ribs

Explanation:

  • Structures derived from the paraxial mesoderm include the somites.
  • Somites are bilaterally paired blocks of mesoderm that form on either side of the neural tube during early embryonic development.
  • The somites give rise to various structures in the embryo, including the axial skeleton (such as vertebrae), skeletal muscles, and the dermis of the skin.

Intraembryonic Mesoderm/ Secondary Mesoderm:

  • Formed by the proliferation of cells from the primitive streak.
  • Separates the ectoderm and endoderm except in specific regions that remain bilaminar throughout life:
    • Prochordal plate (future oral cavity)
    • Cloacal membrane (future anal and urogenital openings)
    • Midline caudal to the prochordal plate

Formation of intraembryonic mesoderm. (B) is a section along axis in (A)

  • Subdivisions:

 

1. Paraxial Mesoderm

2. Lateral Plate Mesoderm

3. Intermediate Mesoderm

Located on either side of the notochord and becomes thick.

It forms a thinner layer located laterally.

A longitudinal strip found between the paraxial and lateral plate mesoderm.

It forms:

  • Somitomeres: Form mesoderm and muscles of the head and jaw.
  • Somites: Form midline axial skeleton, skeletal muscles and dermis of back.

It forms:

  • Somatopleuric (parietal) layer: Forms connective tissue of the body wall and limbs, such as appendicular skeleton bones , muscles and dermis of periphery.
  • Splanchnopleuric (visceral) layers: Forms connective tissue and smooth muscle layers of the gut, cardiac muscle and the circulatory system.

It forms:

  • Urinary and genital systems.

Somites:

  • Paraxial mesoderm becomes segmented to form 42-44 pairs of somites develop on either side of the neural tube and notochord.
  • Appear between the 20th and 30th day, marking the 4th week as the somite period.
  • Somite Structure:
    • Sclerotome: Ventromedial part; forms vertebral column and ribs.
    • Dermatome: Lateral part; forms dermis of skin and subcutaneous tissue.
    • Myotome: Intermediate part; forms striated muscle.

 

 

Kidneys (Option B): Kidneys are the derivatives of the intermediate mesoderm.

Dorsal root ganglion (Option C): Dorsal root ganglia are derived from the neural crest cells.

Parietal pleura (Option D): The pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities, housing vital organs, originate from the lateral plate mesoderm during embryonic development.

questions.text: A diabetic patient was started on a drug that decreased HbA1c from 7.6 to 6.8. She started complaining of itching around the vulvovaginal area. Which drug was she started on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Canagliflozin

  • The described scenario of itching around the vulvovaginal area after starting anti-diabetic medication suggests vulvovaginal pruritus. Canagliflozin has been linked to vulvovaginal pruritus (itching) caused by candidiasis.
  • It belongs to the class of medications known as sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors. These drugs work by reducing glucose reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine.
  • Vulvovaginal candidiasis is common (ncreased excretion of sugar in the urine). The sugar promotes the growth of pathogens like candida, resulting in:
    • Vulvovaginal pruritis (pruritus in the genital area, including the vulva and vagina).
    • UTI (urinary tract infection)
    • Fournier's gangrene.

Metformin (Option B) belongs to the class biguanide, which is an oral anti-diabetic medication that stimulates the AMPK enzyme, inhibits hepatic glucose production, and increases peripheral insulin sensitivity. It can lead to adverse effects like megaloblastic anaemia and lactic acidosis.

Linagliptin (Option C) is a DPP-4 inhibitor that increases the secretion of Insulin from the pancreas in response to meals (there is no risk of hypoglycemia) and reduces the Secretion of glucose.

Liraglutide (Option D) is a GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) analogue that enhances insulin secretion in response to food intake and helps manage postprandial blood glucose levels. It can cause gallstones, pancreatitis, and risk of Pancreatic and thyroid cancer (contraindicated in MEN syndrome).

questions.text: An antidiabetic drug causes a decrease in HbA1c by causing an increase in GIP and GLP-1 levels and decrease in glucagon. It is an oral drug causing reduction in both pre and post-prandial glucose. The drug is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Alogliptin

  • Alogliptin is an oral medication classified as a Dipeptidyl Peptidase-4 (DPP-4) Inhibitor, which increase levels of GIP and GLP-1 while reducing glucagon. This oral drug helps lower both pre- and postprandial glucose levels.
  • Mechanism: Acts by inhibiting the enzyme DPP-4, which breaks down incretin hormones such as GLP-1 and GIP.
  • By inhibiting DPP-4, alogliptin increases the levels of GLP-1 and GIP, which stimulate insulin secretion and reduce glucagon secretion. This helps lower blood sugar levels.
  • They are also known to reduce HbA1c levels in patients with diabetes, making it a suitable option based on the provided information of high GIP and GLP1 levels along with low glucagon levels.
  • Drugs:
    • Linagliptin (safe in renal failure)
    • Teneligliptin (safe in renal failure)
    • Vildagliptin (hepatotoxic)
    • Alogliptin
    • Sitagliptin
    • Saxagliptin
  • Side effects:
    • Nausea and vomiting (most common)
    • Pancreatitis (lesser than GLP-1)
    • Risk of pancreatic and thyroid cancer (lesser than GLP-1)
    • Arthritis, Nasopharyngitis:
      • Increase interleukins and cytokines levels (similar structure to CD26)
    • Hypersensitivity reactions: Steven-Johnson syndrome, angioedema

Liraglutide (Options A) is a medication in the class of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists, which help lower blood sugar levels by increasing insulin secretion, reducing glucagon secretion, slowing gastric emptying, and promoting satiety.

  • It also reduces HbA1c levels and body’s GLP-1 production. The information provided about high GIP (gastric inhibitory peptide) levels and low glucagon levels does not directly indicate the use of liraglutide. Therefore, it is not the most suitable option in this scenario.

Pramlintide (Option B) is an injectable medication used in the treatment of type 1 and type 2 diabetes. It is a synthetic analog of amylin, a hormone involved in glucose regulation. It helps to lower blood sugar levels by reducing the secretion of glucagon, slowing gastric emptying, and promoting satiety. However, it has no effect on GLP-1 levels.

Voglibose (Option C) is an oral medication that belongs to the class of alpha-glucosidase inhibitors. It works by inhibiting the enzymes in the intestines that break down carbohydrates, thereby delaying the absorption of glucose and reducing postprandial (after meal) blood sugar spikes. It does not directly affect GLP-1, GIP, or glucagon levels. Therefore, it may not be the most suitable option based on the information provided.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in diabetic neuropathy, post herpetic neuralgia and spinal cord injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Pregabalin

  • Pregabalin can be used in the treatment of diabetic neuropathy, post-herpetic neuralgia and spinal cord injury.
  • It works primarily by binding to a specific subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels in the central nervous system. This binding inhibits the release of several neurotransmitters, including glutamate, norepinephrine, and substance P.

Amitriptyline (Option A) is a TCA (tricyclic antidepressant) commonly used to treat depression and neuropathic pain (post-herpetic neuralgia). It can also be used for migraine and diabetic neuropathy, but not in spinal cord injury.

Phenytoin (Option B) is an antiepileptic medication primarily used to manage and prevent seizures. It is a sodium channel blocker that stabilizes the neuronal membrane by inhibiting the repetitive firing of action potentials. It can also be used in trigeminal neuralgia.

Carbamazepine (Option C) is an anticonvulsant. It inhibits high-frequency neuronal discharges and modulates voltage-gated sodium channels. It can be used in trigeminal neuralgia, GTCS, partial seizures, bipolar disorder.

questions.text: Sodium valproate has an inhibitory action at which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - B

  • The “B” label in the above image indicates the mechanism of action of Sodium Valproate (anti-epileptic drug).

Sodium Valproate

Mechanism of Action
  • Sodium Channel Inactivation: Prolongs Na+ channel inactivation in a frequency-dependent manner, similar to phenytoin.
  • Calcium Channel Modulation: Weakly attenuates the T-type calcium currents, akin to ethosuximide.
  • GABA Enhancement: Increases GABA levels by:
    • Inhibiting GABA transaminase, leading to reduced degradation.
    • Possibly enhancing GABA synthesis from glutamic acid.
  • Glutamate Receptor Blockade: Blocks excitatory NMDA glutamate receptors, reducing excitatory neurotransmission.

Uses

  • Seizure Disorders: It is the DOC for atypical absence seizures, myoclonic seizures, and generalised tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS).
  • Mood Disorders: Valproate is effective in the treatment of mania and bipolar disorder.
  • Panic Attacks: It can be used off-label for the treatment of panic attacks.
  • Migraine Prophylaxis: Valproate is considered a second-line treatment for preventing migraines.
  • Mixed Seizure Syndromes: It is used in conditions such as Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • Severe Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy: Valproate is also used in Dravet syndrome.

Adverse Effects
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, and indigestion.
  • Neurological: Tremor, sedation, dizziness, and ataxia.
  • Hepatic: Hepatotoxicity (mainly in children <2 years of age).
  • Hematologic: Thrombocytopenia and other blood dyscrasias.
  • Metabolic: Weight gain, hyperammonemia, and pancreatitis.
  • Teratogenicity: Risk of congenital malformations, such as neural tube defects (spina bifida oculta), if used during pregnancy.
  • Others: Hair loss (alopecia) and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Drug interactions

Valproate is a CYP enzyme inhibitor that inhibits CYP2C9, which can lead to increased levels of drugs metabolised by this enzyme, such as phenytoin and warfarin

 

A (Option A): Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic drug used for infantile spasms and refractory complex partial seizures. It acts by irreversibly inhibiting GABA transaminase to increase GABA levels in the brain.

C (Option C): Tiagabine is an antiepileptic that acts by facilitating GABA-mediated Cl-channel opening.

D (Option D): Benzodiazepines are sedative drugs that are GABA-A chloride channel openers.

questions.text: A patient on fluoxetine was started on a pain control drug for neurotic pain. He developed an episode of syncope after 2 weeks. ECG reveals a QT interval of 477ms. Which of the following is the causative drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Methadone

  • Methadone blocks NMDA receptors and is associated with QT prolongation, which can lead to life-threatening arrhythmias such as torsades de pointes
  • Mechanism: It is a full opioid agonist that works by binding to the same receptors as other opioids, providing similar effects and thereby preventing withdrawal and reducing cravings.
  • Use: It is highly effective for detoxification and long-term maintenance therapy.
  • Advantages: Methadone has a long half-life, which allows for once-daily dosing.
  • Effectiveness: It is considered one of the most effective medications for opioid addiction, especially for individuals with a long history of high-dose opioid use.

Morphine (Option B) is a potent opioid analgesic used for managing severe pain, including acute pain resulting from traumatic injuries like crush injuries. It works by binding to opioid receptors in the brain and spinal cord, altering pain perception. It is the drug of choice for managing severe pain in an emergency. It is not associated with QT prolongation.

Meperidine (Option C), also known as pethidine, is an opioid analgesic. It is the drug of choice in post-anesthesia shivering and involves both opioid receptor activity and effects on the thermoregulatory center in the hypothalamus. It does not cause QT prolongation.

Propoxyphene (Option D) is a methadone analog that was used to treat mild to moderate pain. As mentioned earlier, the U.S. FDA recommended the removal of the drug (trade name: Darvon) from the U.S. market in 2010 due to reports of cardiac toxicity (QRS interval prolongation).

questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilizers causes hepatotoxicity and hyperammonemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Valproate

  • Valproate (antiepileptic) causes hepatotoxicity and hyperammonemia.

Adverse Effects of valproate:

  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, and indigestion.
  • Neurological: Tremor, sedation, dizziness, and ataxia.
  • Hepatic: Hepatotoxicity (mainly in children <2 years of age).
  • Hematologic: Thrombocytopenia and other blood dyscrasias.
  • Metabolic: Weight gain, hyperammonemia, and pancreatitis.
  • Teratogenicity: Risk of congenital malformations, such as neural tube defects (spina bifida oculta), if used during pregnancy.
  • Others: Hair loss (alopecia) and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Valproate is a CYP enzyme inhibitor that inhibits CYP2C9, which can lead to increased levels of drugs metabolised by this enzyme, such as phenytoin and warfarin.

Lithium (Option A) can cause adverse effects like tremors, alopecia, acne, weight gain, seizures and sinus node dysfunction, hypothyroidism, ataxia, tinnitus, diarrhea, and seizures, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI), and Ebstein’s anomaly (cardiovascular defect called tricuspid atresia, a teratogenic effect when administered to pregnant women).

Carbamazepine (Option C) can cause hepatotoxicity but does not cause hyperammonemia. It has adverse effects like hepatotoxicity, neurotoxicity (Sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, and ataxia), coma, convulsions, cardiovascular collapse, water retention and hyponatremia, Steven Jones syndrome, agranulocytosis, aplastic anaemia, thrombocytopenia, hypersensitivity reactions and teratogenicity.

Topiramate (Option D) causes impairment of attention, sedation, ataxia, word-finding difficulties, poor memory, weight loss, paresthesias, renal stones. It does not cause hepatotoxicity or hyperammonemia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect related to the given image?

choices.text: Result from the aberrant migration of primordial germ cell

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prechordal plate anomaly

Explanation:

  • Sacrococcygeal teratomas are tumors that originate from primordial germ cells and are typically found at the base of the spine.
  • They are associated with the remnants of the primitive streak rather than the prechordal plate.

 

  • Teratomas mostly occur during the neonatal period and most of them are benign
  • Most common site- Sacrococcygeal region
  • Females > males
  • The risk of malignancy increases with age
  • It is thought to be derivative of the primitive streak

Clinical features:

  • External presacral mass with minimal intrapelvic presacral component
  • Symptoms include weakness, paralysis, and bladder or bowel dysfunction
  • Currarino Triad: Anorectal malformations + sacrococcygeal osseous defect + presacral mass

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • CT/MRI is done to detect intra-abdominal and intra-pelvic components.

Treatment:

  • Complete surgical excision of the tumor should be done
  • To avoid local recurrence - resection of the coccyx is done

 

Benign tumor of coccyx (Option A): Sacrococcygeal teratoma is a tumor that arises at the base of the spine, often from remnants of primitive tissue, and it can exhibit both benign(mostly) and malignant (few) characteristics.

Presence of teeth and hair (Option B): Teratomas can have any of the 3 germ layers (Endoderm, ectoderm or mesoderm) because primordial germ cells themselves are pluripotent cells.

Result from the aberrant migration of primordial germ cell (Option C): Abrupt migration of primordial germ cells may cause oropharyngeal teratoma and sacrococcygeal teratoma.

questions.text: Which of the following sulcus will be injured in a patient with trauma to the pointed area ‘X’?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stem of lateral sulcus

Explanation:

  • The marked part in the above image is the Pterion.
  • The Pterion is a crucial anatomical landmark where several skull bones converge, forming an H-shaped sutural junction.
  • It's particularly vulnerable due to the thinness of the bones in this region.
  • The lateral sulcus, or Sylvian sulcus, divides the temporal lobe below from the parietal lobe above.
  • The middle cerebral artery (MCA), a branch of the internal carotid artery (ICA), runs within it, supplying the lateral cerebrum.

Pterion:

Located at the anterolateral fontanelle and is formed by the union of:

    • Frontal bone
    • Parietal bone
    • Squamous temporal bones &
    • Greater wing of the sphenoid.
  • At birth, this area is filled with a membrane, which typically closes by around 2 months of age, though it can sometimes be delayed until 6 months.
  • The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery runs beneath the Pterion and Stem of lateral sulcus.
  • Injury to this area can result in extradural or epidural haemorrhage.
  • The pterion is a frequent location for trephination (creating an opening in the skull) during surgical procedures.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Terminal bronchioles

Explanation:

  • Terminal bronchioles differ from larger bronchi as they are devoid of cartilage in their walls.
  • The ciliated cells are still present in terminal bronchioles, but their abundance is reduced.
  • Additionally, terminal bronchioles exhibit alveolar outgrowths, marking the transition to structures involved in gas exchange.

 

Respiratory bronchus (Option A):

  • Respiratory bronchioles have alveoli budding directly from their walls. This is a distinctive feature that indicates their role in gas exchange.
  • Epithelium may become more cuboidal, eventually transitioning to simple squamous epithelium in the alveoli.
  • Similar to terminal bronchioles, respiratory bronchioles lack cartilage in their walls.

Alveolar sac (Option C):

  • Alveolar sacs are composed of clusters of alveoli, which are small, balloon-like structures.
  • Alveolar walls are extremely thin to facilitate efficient gas exchange.

Intrapulmonary bronchus (Option D):

  • Intrapulmonary bronchi have smooth muscle in their walls, which helps regulate airflow.
  • Goblet cells, found in the epithelium of intrapulmonary bronchi, secrete mucus to aid in capturing particles and facilitating their expulsion from the respiratory tract.
  • Cartilage found in the intrapulmonary bronchus helps maintain the shape of the bronchi, preserving the integrity of the airway structure.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Orientia tsutsugamushi

Explanation:

Orientia tsutsugamushi causes scrub typhus and is transmitted by the bite of Leptotrombidium mites (chiggers).

Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (Option B): This viral hemorrhagic fever is caused by the Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV) and is transmitted by Hyalomma ticks.

Babesiosis (Option C): Babesia species cause babesiosis, a malaria-like illness, and are transmitted by Ixodid (hard) ticks, primarily Ixodes scapularis (deer tick).

Ehrlichiosis (Option D): Ehrlichia species, responsible for human ehrlichiosis, are transmitted by Amblyomma americanum (Lone Star tick) and other tick species.

questions.text: The image below demonstrates the mechanism of action of a certain pathogen. Which of the following pathogens is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Streptococcus pyogenes

Explanation:

  • Streptococcus pyogenes produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins (SPEs), which act as superantigens.
  • These exotoxins cause an exaggerated immune response by directly linking T-cell receptors to MHC class II molecules, leading to massive cytokine release.
  • This mechanism underlies toxic shock-like syndrome and scarlet fever.

Diseases caused by Streptococcus pyogenes:

Disease

Clinical Features

Diagnosis

Treatment

Complications

Pharyngitis

Sore throat, fever, swollen lymph nodes

Throat culture, rapid antigen detection test

Penicillin, amoxicillin, cephalosporins

Rheumatic fever, acute glomerulonephritis

Scarlet Fever

 

Rash, fever, strawberry tongue

Clinical presentation, throat culture

Penicillin, erythromycin

Rheumatic fever, septicemia

Impetigo- Non-bullous

Honey-crusted lesions on the face and limbs

Clinical presentation, culture of lesions

Topical mupirocin, oral antibiotics

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Erysipelas

 

Raised, well-demarcated erythematous lesions

Clinical presentation, blood cultures

Penicillin, erythromycin

Bacteremia, septicemia

Cellulitis

Diffuse, spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue

Clinical presentation, blood cultures

Penicillin, clindamycin, cephalosporins

Necrotizing fasciitis, sepsis

Necrotizing Fasciitis

Severe pain, swelling, fever, rapid spread of infection

Clinical presentation, imaging studies

Surgical debridement, broad-spectrum antibiotics

Septic shock, multi-organ failure

Streptococcal Toxic Shock Syndrome (STSS)

 

Fever, hypotension, multi-organ involvement

Clinical presentation, blood cultures

IV fluids, vasopressors, broad-spectrum antibiotics

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

Acute Rheumatic Fever

Migratory arthritis, carditis, chorea, erythema marginatum

Clinical criteria (Jones criteria), throat culture

Penicillin, anti-inflammatory drugs (aspirin)

Chronic rheumatic heart disease

Acute glomerulonephritis

Hematuria, proteinuria, edema, hypertension

Clinical presentation, urine analysis

Supportive care, antihypertensives

Chronic kidney disease

Vibrio cholerae (Option A): Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin, which ADP-ribosylates the Gsα subunit of adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cAMP levels. This results in massive chloride and water secretion in the intestines, causing profuse watery diarrhea.

Clostridium difficile (Option C): Clostridium difficile produces toxin A and toxin B, which inactivate Rho GTPases, disrupting the cytoskeleton and leading to colonic epithelial damage and pseudomembranous colitis.

Clostridium botulinum (Option D): Clostridium botulinum produces botulinum toxin, which cleaves SNARE proteins, preventing acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions and causing flaccid paralysis.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following causes Barth’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cardiolipin

Explanation:

Barth’s syndrome:

Cause

Mutations affecting cardiolipin metabolism (decreased or altered cardiolipin levels), causing defects in mitochondrial function.

Clinical Features
  • Cardioskeletal myopathy (affects both heart and muscle).
  • Mitochondrial dysfunction in aging and pathologic conditions.

questions.text: Xanthurenic aciduria may be treated with high doses of which vitamin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vitamin B6

Explanation:

The metabolic disorders which respond to vitamin B6 therapy are:

  • Xanthurenic aciduria
  • Homocystinuria

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxal Phosphate - PLP):

Amino Acid Metabolism

PLP acts as a coenzyme for many reactions in amino acid metabolism.

Transamination

Catalyzed by amino transferases (e.g., Alanine transaminase), converting amino acids to keto acids.

Decarboxylation

Required for decarboxylation of amino acids, forming important neurotransmitters and metabolites.

Neurotransmitter Synthesis
  • GABA from glutamate (important for inhibitory neurotransmission).
  • Histamine from histidine (mediator of allergy).
  • Serotonin from 5-hydroxy tryptophan (mood regulation).
  • Taurine from cysteine.

Sulfur Containing Amino Acids

Involved in methionine and cysteine metabolism.

Homocysteine Metabolism

Converts homocysteine to cystathionine; deficiency leads to increased homocysteine, associated with myocardial infarction risk.

Heme Synthesis

Required for ALA synthase, the rate-limiting enzyme in heme biosynthesis.

Niacin Production

Required for the conversion of tryptophan to niacin (via kynurenine).

Glycogenolysis

PLP is a coenzyme for phosphorylase, which converts glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of facial pain, swelling, and nasal discharge. The patient was recently hospitalized for a COVID-19 infection and treated with a prolonged course of steroids. Examination of the nasal discharge under the microscope shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mucor

Explanation:

  • Mucor species cause mucormycosis, an invasive fungal infection seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with uncontrolled diabetes or prolonged steroid use (such as post-COVID-19 patients).
  • It often presents as rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis with symptoms including facial pain, swelling, nasal discharge, and black eschar in the nasal mucosa.
  • Histopathology shows broad, aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching, which is characteristic of Mucorales.
  • Mucor species similar characteristics to Rhizopus, including non-septate hyphae. However, it is less frequently implicated compared to Rhizopus arrhizus in cases of sinus infections. More in Covid-19 due to use of steroids.

Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus:

Absidia:

Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained):

 

 

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b. Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

Aspergillus species (Option B): such as Aspergillus fumigatus, typically produce septate hyphae that branch at acute angles. Histopathology typically shows narrow, septate hyphae with acute-angle branching, distinguishing it from Mucor.

Candida (Option C): Candida species cause candidiasis, which typically manifests as oral thrush, esophagitis, or disseminated candidiasis. It does not commonly present as invasive sino-orbital disease. Microscopically, Candida shows budding yeasts and pseudohyphae, rather than hyphal invasion seen in Mucor.

Trichosporon (Option D): Trichosporon is a yeast-like fungus that causes trichosporonosis, a rare opportunistic infection seen in immunocompromised individuals. It does not cause sino-orbital infections and is more commonly associated with disseminated disease in neutropenic patients.

questions.text: What is the blood supply of the marked area in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

Explanation:

  • The highlighted structure is the inferior cerebellar peduncle, a white matter bundle linking the medulla oblongata to the cerebellum.
  • It is mainly supplied by the Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA), a branch of the vertebral artery.

Blood supply of various parts of brain:

Structure

Blood Supply

Medulla
  • Anterior spinal artery
  • Posterior spinal artery
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Medullary branch from basilar artery

Pons
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Pontine branch from basilar artery
  • Superior cerebellar artery

Midbrain
  • Posterior cerebral artery
  • Superior cerebellar artery

Thalamus
  • Posterior communicating artery
  • Posterior cerebral artery

Cerebellum
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Superior cerebellar artery

 

Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (Option B): The anterior inferior cerebral artery (AICA) a branch of the basilar artery, supplies blood to the anteroinferior cerebellum, middle cerebellar peduncle, and inferolateral pons.

Superior cerebellar artery (Option C): Superior cerebellar artery (SCA) supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum, superior and middle cerebellar peduncles, and the lower midbrain.

Posterior Cerebral Artery (Option D): The Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) provides blood supply to the occipital cortex, inferior and medial temporal cortices, thalamus, and rostral midbrain.

questions.text: Which of the following methods can detect deoxynucleotide incorporation in DNA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pyrosequencing

Explanation:

Pyrosequencing is a DNA sequencing method that detects nucleotide incorporation by measuring the release of pyrophosphate (PPi) during DNA synthesis. The incorporation of deoxynucleotides is detected in real-time, making it the correct answer.

Pyrosequencing in Microbial Genomics

  • Purpose:
    • Identifies bacterial species & strains
    • Detects mutations linked to antimicrobial resistance
  • Mechanism:
    • DNA synthesis-based sequencing (one base at a time)
    • Single-stranded template DNA immobilized
    • Sequential addition of dNTPs
    • Unincorporated dNTPs degraded before next addition
    • Chemiluminescence signals indicate base incorporation
    • Signal pattern determines DNA sequence
  • Applications:
    • Identifies SNPs, point mutations, insertions, deletions
    • Quantifies multiple gene copies in drug-resistant strains

Flow cytometry (Option A): Flow cytometry is used to analyze the physical and chemical characteristics of cells, such as DNA content, surface markers, and apoptosis. It does not directly detect deoxynucleotide incorporation in DNA.

FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) (Option C): FISH is a cytogenetic technique used to detect specific DNA or RNA sequences in chromosomes or cells. It does not assess nucleotide incorporation but rather identifies target sequences using fluorescent probes.

RFLP analysis (Option D): Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) is a method used for genetic fingerprinting and mutation analysis. It relies on restriction enzyme digestion and gel electrophoresis but does not measure nucleotide incorporation.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme defects leads to Pompe’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lysosomal alpha glucosidase

Explanation:

Pompe’s Disease (Glycogen storage disease Type II)

Enzyme Deficiency

Lysosomal α1→4 and α1→6 glucosidase (acid maltase)

Affected Gene

GAA

Clinical Features
  • Muscle hypotonia, death due to heart failure within 2 years of age (seen in juvenile)
  • Muscle dystrophy (seen in adults)

Mode of Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Management
  • Supportive care
  • Enzyme replacement therapy
  • Chest x-ray at regular intervals
  • Obtain an initial echocardiogram to evaluate the extent of cardiomyopathy
  • Medical management may be useful based on the stage of cardiomyopathy.
  • Avoid drastic changes in fluid status, either through dehydration or fluid overload.

questions.text: Which of the following best helps assess the issues in the quality of healthcare?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Ishikawa diagram/ Fishbone diagram

Explanation:

  • Ishikawa diagram/Fishbone diagram is specifically designed to identify and organize potential causes of a problem systematically. It is widely used in quality improvement processes to uncover root causes of issues in healthcare.

 

Histogram (Option B):

  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

 

Bar Diagram (Option A):

  • Simple bar diagrams represent the frequency of discrete variables like gender.
  • Discrete variables:These variables take fewer values and no in between values.
    • Examples: Religion, Blood groups
    • These are not represented in decimals so there are gaps.

 

Regression analysis (Option C): It is a statistical technique used to describe relationships between variables. It represents unitary change.

  • It quantifies how changes in one variable are associated with changes in another variable(s).
  • It provides insights into the direction (positive or negative correlation) and strength (the magnitude of the relationship) between variables. (Option A)
  • The process involves fitting a mathematical model to observed data to describe the effect of ≥1 independent variable on a dependent variable. (Option B)
  • Equation: y = a + bx
  • where, y = Dependent variable; a = Constant ; b = Regression coefficient ; x = Independent variable
  • E.g., Blood pressure is a continuous variable, it can be affected by age, cholesterol.

questions.text: A patient on amitriptyline was found in an unconscious state. Which of the following does not suggest amitriptyline toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Hypothermia

  • Amitriptyline is a Tricyclic Antidepressant (TCA) that can cause hyperthermia as a side effect, rather than hypothermia.

Side effects of Tricyclic antidepressants (TCA):

Mechanism of side effect

Side effect

H1 receptor blockade
  • Sedation, weight gain

Anticholinergic action on muscarinic receptors
  • Hyperthermia (Option C)
  • Dry eyes/mouth
  • Mydriasis (C/I in glaucoma) (Option D)
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Tachycardia
  • Confusion (Option B)

Increase in serotonin in the brain
  • Seizure threshold reduction

Alpha 1 adrenergic receptor antagonism
  • Postural hypotension

Sodium channel block
  • Arrhythmia/QT prolongation (Option A)
  • Bradycardia in heart block due to overdose

questions.text:
Match the following organisms with their incubation periods.

 


	
		
			
			Organism
			
			
			Incubation Period
			
		
		
			
			a. Syphilis
			
			
			1. 6 Days
			
		
		
			
			b. Chickenpox
			
			
			2. 90 Days
			
		
		
			
			c. SARS-CoV-2
			
			
			3. 16 Days
			
		
		
			
			d. Hepatitis A
			
			
			4. 28 Days
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) a-2, b-3, c-1, d-4

Explanation:

Syphilis: The incubation period of Treponema pallidum (syphilis) ranges from 10 to 90 days, with an average of 3 weeks.

Chickenpox: Varicella-zoster virus has an incubation period of 10 to 21 days, with an average of 14-16 days.

SARS-CoV-2: The incubation period for COVID-19 typically ranges from 2 to 14 days, with an average of 5-6 days.

Hepatitis A: The incubation period of Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is 15-50 days, with an average of 28 days.

questions.text: A 10-week-old baby has come for vaccination. The baby has had a previous history of inconsolable crying and fever (40 degrees C) after vaccination at 6 weeks. What should be the next step now?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Give DPT

Explanation:

  • Assess if symptoms were directly related to vaccine
  • Contraindications to pertussis vaccine: anaphylaxis, encephalopathy, family history of CNS disorders, concurrent febrile illness
  • Baby's symptoms are likely vaccine-related, no contraindications present
  • Proceeding with DPT vaccination recommended

questions.text: The active site of an enzyme is most complementary to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Substrate

Explanation:

Properties of Enzyme

Nature of Enzymes

Enzymes are proteins, heat-sensitive, water-soluble

Efficiency

Enzymes can accelerate reactions by factors 10^6 to 10^9 or more.

Specificity

Enzymes act on specific substrates and can distinguish stereoisomers.

Cofactors/Coenzymes

Some enzymes need non-protein molecules (cofactors or coenzymes) to be active.

Substrate Binding

Enzymes bind substrates at multiple points, creating chiral products from non-chiral substrates.

Transition State

Enzymes stabilize the transition state, lowering activation energy.

Reversibility

Enzymes can catalyze both forward and reverse reactions.

Regulation

Activity is regulated by pH, temperature, inhibitors, and activators.

Active site

  • The region where the substrate binds and undergoes a chemical reaction
  • It is most complimentary to enzyme-substrate

questions.text: An elderly patient with dementia is not compliant with oral medications. Which of the following will be beneficial in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Rivastigmine

  • In this scenario, where the patient is not compliant with oral medications, a transdermal Rivastigmine patch can be used as an alternative. Since only the Rivastigmine patch is available in India among the options listed, it would be the most appropriate choice.

Treatment of Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Patient and caregiver education.

Neurotransmitter-based therapies

  • Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors
    • Donepezil
    • Rivastigmine
    • Galantamine
  • N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptor blocker
    • Memantine
  • A common approach to AD drug therapy is to initiate a cholinesterase inhibitor for a patient diagnosed with mild AD dementia and to add memantine when patients enter the moderate stage of the disease.

Therapies targeting amyloid-𝛃

  • Aducanumab
    • MOA: Monoclonal antibody targeting the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide
    • Dosage: Intravenous infusion every 4 weeks (7 infusions in total)
    • Should only be considered for treating MCI (Mild Cognitive Impairment) or early dementia due to AD
    • S/E: Vasogenic cerebral edema, cortical microhemorrhages, and superficial siderosis

Donepezil (Option A) and Galantamine (Option C) are available in both oral and transdermal patch forms, but in India, only the oral forms are accessible, so they are not the answer.

Memantine (Option D): A common approach to Alzheimer's disease drug therapy is to initiate a cholinesterase inhibitor for a patient diagnosed with mild AD dementia and to add memantine when patients enter the moderate stage of the disease. But memantine is available only for oral administration.

questions.text: A person is bitten by a dog. The dog and the person are fully immunized against rabies. There is a laceration at the site of the bite. What would you advise to the person?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amoxiclav

Explanation:

  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate (Amoxiclav) is the preferred antibiotic for dog bite wounds because it provides broad coverage against Gram-positive, Gram-negative, and anaerobic bacteria, including Pasteurella multocida.
  • Since the patient has a laceration, antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended to prevent secondary bacterial infections.

Metronidazole (Option A): Metronidazole is effective against anaerobic bacteria but is not the first-line prophylactic treatment for dog bites, which often involve aerobic and anaerobic polymicrobial infections, including Pasteurella multocida, Staphylococcus aureus, and Streptococcus species.

Ciprofloxacin (Option B): Ciprofloxacin is primarily effective against Gram-negative bacteria but has limited activity against Pasteurella multocida, a common pathogen in dog bites. It is not the preferred first-line antibiotic for animal bites.

Observation (Option D): While observation is appropriate for minor scratches or superficial wounds in an immunized person, a laceration presents a higher risk of bacterial infection, warranting antibiotic prophylaxis.
