questions.text: A patient in the emergency has the following lab parameters: creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. The chest x-ray (pneumonia with infiltrates in the middle part of the right lung and patchy infiltrates in the left lung) is given. In gram staining and culture, only rhinovirus was isolated. The patient is shifted to the ICU. What is the best treatment of choice in this option?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin

  • The scenario, which includes ICU admission and lung infiltrates on the chest X-ray, suggests community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) with a rhinovirus infection. Since no growth was observed in the culture (with no presence of Pseudomonas or MRSA), a combination of beta-lactam (ceftriaxone) and macrolide (azithromycin) will be administered.

Management:

  • Treatment depends on severity; assess if inpatient or outpatient management is needed.
  • CURB-65 Score: Used to stratify patients with the following factors:

CURB-65

Symptom

Score

(C) Confusion

1

(U) Urea: BUN >19mg/dL (>7 mmol/L)

1

(R) Respiratory rate ≥30/min

1

(B) Blood Pressure – Systolic BP ≤90 mmHg or diastolic BP ≤60 mmHg

1

(65) Age ≥65 years

1
  • Hospitalization Criteria:
    • CURB-65 score 1 or 2: Indicates hospitalization
    • A score ≥3: Indicates ICU admission and more intensive therapy.
  • Empiric Therapy:
    • Outpatient:
      • No comorbidities: Monotherapy with macrolides (azithromycin, clarithromycin). (Option A)
      • With comorbidities (chronic lung/heart disease, diabetes, smoking, HIV): Newer fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, gemifloxacin) or a combination of beta-lactam (e.g., amoxicillin) and a macrolide.
    • Inpatient Non-ICU:
      • Newer fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin) alone or a combination of beta-lactam (e.g., ampicillin, ceftriaxone) and a macrolide. (Option B)
    • Inpatient ICU:
      • Combination of macrolide (azithromycin) or newer fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin) with beta-lactam (e.g., ampicillin-sulbactam, ertapenem). (Option D)
      • If risk of aspiration, consider ampicillin-sulbactam or ertapenem; for Pseudomonas infection, use anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam) with anti-pseudomonal fluoroquinolone (e.g., ciprofloxacin). (Option C)
      • For MRSA, add vancomycin or linezolid.
  • Duration of Therapy: Typically 5 to 7 days, extended if clinical response is delayed.
  • Influenza Treatment: All hospitalized patients testing positive for influenza should receive oseltamivir, regardless of illness onset.

questions.text: A person is found to have an absence of the CD40 marker. Which of the following would be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Absent B cells

Explanation:

CD40 Characteristics:

  • A TNF receptor family member expressed on B cells, APCs, non-immune cells, and tumors, which is an essential costimulatory marker.
  • Binds CD40L, which is transiently expressed on T cells and inflamed non-immune cells.
  • It interacts with CD40L on T helper cells, which is crucial for B cell activation, proliferation, and class switching.
  • If CD40 is absent, B cells cannot receive activation signals, leading to defective antibody production and absent/malfunctional B cells.
  • This condition is associated with Hyper-IgM Syndrome, an immunodeficiency disorder where B cells fail to undergo class switching due to defective CD40 signaling.

Absent T cells (Option A): T cells are present but fail to provide effective help to B cells due to impaired CD40-CD40L interaction.

NK cells do not rely on CD40 for their development.

Absent Macrophages (Option D): Macrophages are present but show impaired activation, leading to decreased IL-12 production and defective T-cell-mediated immunity.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contribute to the repair of DNA double-stranded breaks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ATP

Explanation:

ATP is not directly involved in the repair of DNA double-stranded breaks (DSBs), but it provides the energy necessary for many cellular processes, including DNA repair.

Homologous DNA Repair (HR)

  • HR is a type of Double-strand DNA break repair mechanism used to fix double-strand breaks (DSBs) by utilizing a homologous DNA template for error-free repair.
  • HR is active during the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle.
  • RAD 51 and ATM are involved in the G2 phase

Nonhomologous End Joining (NHEJ)

  • NHEJ is a DNA repair mechanism that fixes double-strand breaks (DSBs) by directly joining the broken ends without requiring a homologous template.
  • Active throughout the entire cell cycle, including G0/G1 phases.
  • Ku70 is involved in the G1 phase

questions.text:
Match the following columns


	
		
			
			A. Byssinosis
			
			
			1. Cane sugar factories
			
		
		
			
			B. Bagassosis
			
			
			2. Sandstone industry
			
		
		
			
			C. Silicosis
			
			
			3. Cement industry
			
		
		
			
			D. Asbestosis
			
			
			4. Textile industry
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) A4-B1-C2-D3

Explanation:

  • Silicosis: Often occurs in workers exposed to silica dust in industries like mining and quarrying.
  • Asbestosis: Typically found in workers who handle asbestos, prevalent in construction and shipbuilding industries.
  • Byssinosis: Common among workers exposed to cotton, flax, or hemp dust, primarily in the textile manufacturing industry.
  • Bagassosis: an occupational lung disease caused by inhaling bagasse (sugarcane dust) in workers at a sugarcane processing plant (Causative Agent: Thermoactinomyces sacchari)

questions.text: Hyperpigmentation and keratosis can be seen with which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Arsenic

Explanation:

  • Chronic arsenic exposure can lead to skin hyperpigmentation, with dark patches or spots. It can also cause keratosis, leading to thickening and roughening of the skin. • This combination of symptoms is often referred to as "arsenicosis."

Heavy metal

Source of exposure

Clinical features

Lead

 

Non-industrial

  • Gasoline from automobile exhaust.
  • Contaminated water from lead pipes.
  • Lead paints in old homes.

 

Industrial

  • Battery and cosmetic manufacturing
  • Printing paint and dye factories
  • Glass manufacturing
  • Shipbuilding

Organic lead

  • Wrist and/or foot drop.
  • Insomnia.
  • Headache.
  • Mental confusion.

 

Inorganic lead

  • Anemia.
  • Burton’s line - blue lines on gums.
  • Colic, abdominal pain with diarrhoea/constipation.

 

Arsenic

(Option A)
  • Pesticide
  • Contaminated water
  • Copper and lead smelting
  • Wood preservatives

 

 

Acute poisoning

  • Gastroenteritis (Rice watery diarrhoea)
  • Hypotension
  • Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema
  • Proteinuria
  • Seizures, delirium and encephalopathy

 

Subacute poisoning (1-3 weeks)

  • Glove stocking pattern polyneuropathy
  • Absent deep tendon reflex
  • Anemia, Leukopenia

 

Chronic poisoning

  • Raindrop pattern hyperpigmentation
  • Palmar-plantar hyperkeratosis
  • Alopecia
  • Angiosarcoma
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Gangrene of extremities.

Mercury

  • Fish (from water pollution)
  • Dental amalgam
  • Gold and mercury mining
  • Contaminated food and grains
  • Greying of the oral mucosa
  • Hemorrhagic gastroenteritis
  • Acute tubular necrosis
  • Shock
  • Excessive irritability
  • Acrodynia (painful extremities)
  • Facial paresthesias
  • Ataxia (loss of coordination), Dementia
  • Blindness

Cadmium

(Option D ruled out)

 
  • Smoking
  • Paint manufacturing
  • Nickel-cadmium battery manufacturing
  • Plastic production

 

 

Acute poisoning

  • Inhalation: Pneumonitis; ARDS
  • Ingestion: GIT hemorrhagic necrosis

 

Chronic poisoning

  • Osteomalacia
  • Parkinson like symptoms
  • Proteinuria

 

Raindrop pigmentation (Arsenic poisoning)

Acrodynia (Mercury poisoning)

 

Copper (Option C): Overt acute copper toxicity presents with gastrointestinal symptoms like abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea, often with blue-green material in emesis/stool.

Zinc (Option D): It is generally safe orally, but excessive intake may lead toxicity but hyperpigmentation and keratosis are not typical findings of zinc toxicity.

questions.text: A microorganism resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides but sensitive to piperacillin clavulanate, cotrimoxazole? The causative organism is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Stenotrophomonas

  • Stenotrophomonas (gram-negative bacilli) is resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides and sensitive to piperacillin clavulanate and cotrimoxazole.
  • It is treated by cotrimoxazole/TMP-SMX (Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole) plus Ticarcillin/clavulanate.
  • The combination of ticarcillin and clavulanate has activity against other gram-negative aerobic and anaerobic organisms, such as Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, and has been used for intra-abdominal and urinary tract infections.

Burkholderia cepacia (Option A) is sensitive to Meropenem or TMP-SMX (Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole).

Acinetobacter (Option B) and Pseudomonas (Option C) are both sensitive to meropenem and aminoglycosides.

questions.text:
Which of the statements about palliative care is true?

A. Disease is the centre of concern

B. The patient is sovereign

C. Death should neither be prolonged nor hastened

D. The aim is to improve the quality of life

E. The intention is to cure

F. Imperative to do something than passively observe
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) B, D, F

Explanation:

Palliative care:

  • It is a specialized medical care, where the main aim is to improve the quality of life and alleviate the suffering of patients.
  • It addresses the physical, psychosocial, and spiritual aspects of patients who have a life-threatening disease with interprofessional team approach
  • Management of symptoms and patient distress is the central focus
  • Care is not limited to a hospital; there are many community clinics and in-home opportunities
  • Hospice care is a form of palliative care specifically designed for patients with a terminal illness and a prognosis of six months or less to live. It focuses on providing comfort and support to patients and their families in the final stages of life, often foregoing curative treatments.

questions.text: Which statement about rubella is incorrect?

choices.text: It is one of the teratogenic TORCH infections
Causes maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads caudally to involve the trunk and extremities

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is a Flavivirus

Explanation:

  • Rubella is caused by a Togavirus (Rubivirus genus), not a Flavivirus.
  • Flaviviruses include Dengue, Yellow Fever, Zika, and West Nile Virus, whereas Rubella belongs to the Togaviridae family.

CONGENITAL RUBELLA SYNDROME

Definition
  • Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) occurs in infants who have contracted rubella from their mothers while in utero.
  • The most likely time for this to occur is between 8-10 weeks of gestation.
  • After birth, these babies can transmit the virus to others for a period of 12–18 months.

Dermatological presentation
  • Blueberry Muffin Rash (Option D ruled out)
  • Forchheimer Spots- small, red or purple spots that can appear on the soft palate

Ophthalmic Defects
  • Cataracts
  • Microphthalmia
  • Glaucoma
  • Salt and pepper retinopathy
  • Chorioretinitis

Auditory Defects
  • Sensorineural deafness

Cardiac Defects
  • Peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis
  • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Ventricular septal defects

Craniofacial Defects
  • Microcephaly

Other Infant Presentations
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Interstitial pneumonitis
  • Radiolucency in the long bones

 

Diagnosis

 
  • Hemagglutination inhibition test (HAI) is the commonly preferred test.
  • Presence of IgM antibodies shortly after birth.
  • Presence of IgG antibodies lasting >6 months.
  • IgM positive implies in-utero infection because IgM antibodies cannot pass from mother to child through the placenta.

 

Blueberry muffin rash:

Forchheimer Spots

It is one of the teratogenic TORCH infections (Option A): Rubella is a part of the TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other [Syphilis, Varicella-Zoster, Parvovirus B19], Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, Herpes Simplex Virus), which can cause congenital defects if contracted during pregnancy.

Causes maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads caudally to involve the trunk and extremities (Option B): Rubella presents with a mild maculopapular rash that begins on the face and then spreads downward to the trunk and extremities, similar to measles but less severe.

questions.text: Which of the following acts via the JAK-STAT pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Leptin

  • Leptin (cytokine) controls our appetite in the brain and acts via the JAK-STAT Pathway.
  • Cytokines and certain hormones signal to transcriptional elements via signal transducers and activators of transcription (STATs).
  • The receptors have no intrinsic enzymatic activity; each is associated with a distinct intracellular tyrosine kinase termed a Janus kinase, or JAK.

JAK-STAT receptors

  • Growth hormone
  • Prolactin
  • Erythropoietin
  • Thrombopoietin
  • Interleukin / Interferon

Calcitonin (Option A) and Vasopressin (Option B) are G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). GPCRs on cell membranes consist of seven α-helical domains. In the inactive state, GDP is bound to the α subunit, transitioning to GTP upon activation through the receptor. This leads to effector activation/inhibition and signal amplification.

Aldosterone (Option C) is a nuclear receptor (a type of intracellular receptor). Intracellular receptors can increase or decrease gene transcription through coactivators and corepressors and are known for their slow and sustained effects.

questions.text: A child presents with the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease

 

Explanation:

  • Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease are commonly triggered by Parvovirus B19 infection, which causes transient red cell aplasia.
  • This is because Parvovirus B19 infects erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, leading to a temporary halt in erythropoiesis.
  • This virus causes cell lysis and depletion of erythroid precursors, leading to transient arrest of erythropoiesis, which exacerbates anemia in children with sickle cell disease.

 

Clinical Manifestations and Complications of Parvovirus B19 Infection

  • Low grade fever, malaise, URTI.
  • Erythema infectiosum (Fifth Disease): Characterized by a "slapped-cheek" rash followed by a lacy, reticular rash on the body.
  • Arthropathy: Common in adults, presenting as arthritis or arthralgia.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis: Severe anaemia in individuals with chronic hemolytic anaemia.
  • Fetal Infection: Risk of nonimmune fetal hydrops and stillbirth typically results in normal deliveries.
  • Papular purpural gloves and socks syndrome
  • Myocarditis

 

Immunodeficiency (Option B): While Parvovirus B19 can cause chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals, immunodeficiency itself does not directly present as an acute aplastic crisis with a sudden drop in hemoglobin.

 

Lymphoproliferative disorder (Option C): Lymphoproliferative disorders (e.g., leukemias, lymphomas) may present with pancytopenia, but they do not cause a transient aplastic crisis. They are also more likely to be associated with lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and abnormal white blood cell counts.

 

BK Nephropathy (Option D): BK virus mainly affects renal transplant recipients or immunocompromised patients, leading to nephropathy and renal dysfunction, but it does not cause an aplastic crisis.

questions.text: Cyclosporine-induced cholestasis is due to which receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - MDR1

  • Cyclosporine-induced cholestasis is due to the MDR1 receptor.

P-glycoprotein (P-gp), also known as ATP-binding cassette sub-family B member 1 (ABCB1) or multidrug resistance protein 1 (MDR1)

  • It is an efflux transporter protein.
  • Its primary function is to pump out a wide range of substances, including drugs, from inside the cell to outside the cell (drug efflux).
  • When Pgp is overexpressed or hyperactive in cancer cells, it leads to increased efflux of chemotherapeutic drugs out of the cells (leads to drug resistance).
  • Location of Pgp in various body tissues:
    • GIT: Decreases absorption of the drug.
    • Kidney: Increases urinary excretion of the drug.
    • Liver: Increases bile excretion of the drug.
    • Blood-brain-barrier/Placenta: Decreases drug entry into the brain/placental cells.
  • Substrates: Etoposide, doxorubicin, vincristine; diltiazem, verapamil; indinavir, ritonavir; erythromycin, ketoconazole; testosterone, progesterone; cyclosporine (Option C), tacrolimus; digoxin, quinidine, fexofenadine, loperamide

BRCA (Option A), or breast cancer susceptibility gene, mutation can lead to carcinoma of the breast, ovaries, pancreas and prostate. The target drugs which can be used are olaparib, rucaparib, talazoparib.

OATP1B1 (Option B): Organic Anion Transporting Polypeptide 1B1 (OATP1B1) is a protein encoded by the SLCO1B1 gene in humans. It is a type of transporter protein found primarily in the liver and plays a crucial role in the uptake of various compounds, including drugs, bile acids, and other organic anions, into liver cells.

MRP1 (Option D): Multidrug Resistance-associated Protein 1 (MRP1), also known as ABCC1 (ATP-Binding Cassette Sub-family C Member 1), is a protein that plays a significant role in cellular drug transport and the efflux of various substances from cells. Its substrates include vincristine (with GSH), methotrexate; GSH conjugate of LTC4 , ethacrynic acid; glucuronide of estradiol, bilirubin; estrone-3-sulfate; saquinavir; grepafloxacin; folate.

questions.text: A South Indian male farmer presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of reddish mass coming out from the nose and histopathology image as given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Rhinosporidiosis

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of rhinosporidiosis includes the presence of reddish or pinkish masses or polyps in the nasal cavity and histopathology shows sporangium with sporangiospores as seen in the images shown.

Rhinosporidiosis:

  • It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by an aquatic protistan protozoa- Rhinosporidium seeberi.
  • It is a water-borne disease- contaminated water of ponds usually with cow dung.

Epidemiology:

  • Common in India, Sri Lanka, and Pakistan
  • More common in southern states than in northern India

Life cycle:

Trophic stage → Development of sporangium → Release of endospores

Clinical Features:

  • Blood-tinged nasal discharge
  • Nasal block
  • Epistaxis
  • Leafy, polypoidal, pink to purple colored mass attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall.
  • Very vascular mass and bleeds easily on touch.
  • White dots are studded on its surface representing the sporangia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Rhinoscleroma (Option B): Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by the bacterium Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It is characterized by the formation of fibrotic nodules in the nose and other respiratory passages as shown below. Histopathology shows Miculicz cells (large foam cells with central nucleus and cytoplasm with the bacilli) and Russell bodies (cells with eccentric nucleus and eosinophilic cytoplasm).

Rhinophyma (Option C): Rhinophyma is a condition characterized by progressive enlargement of the nose due to sebaceous gland hyperplasia as shown below. It is typically associated with acne rosacea.

Nasal polyp (Option D): Nasal polyps are non-cancerous growths that develop in the lining of the nose or sinuses. They are usually soft, painless, and non-inflammatory translucent tissue containing mucus unlike the fleshy polyps of rhinosporidiosis.

questions.text: In which of the following disorders is vaccination not contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Complement deficiency

Explanation:

  • Complement deficiencies primarily impair the humoral immune response.
  • However, patients have normal T-cell function, making both live and inactivated vaccines safe.
  • Vaccination against meningococcal and pneumococcal infections are strongly recommended.

DiGeorge syndrome (Option A):

  • DiGeorge syndrome is characterized by thymic hypoplasia, leading to T-cell deficiency.
  • Live vaccines are contraindicated in patients with severe T-cell deficiency due to the risk of vaccine-induced infection.
  • However, in mild cases with adequate T-cell function, some live vaccines may be considered under specialist guidance.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (Option B):

  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is a combined B and T cell immunodeficiency, increasing susceptibility to infections.
  • Live vaccines are generally avoided due to impaired immune responses and the risk of vaccine-strain infection.
  • Patients with WAS may receive inactivated vaccines.

Ataxia-telangiectasia (Option D):

  • Ataxia-telangiectasia is a DNA repair disorder associated with immunodeficiency, particularly affecting IgA and T-cell function.
  • Live vaccines are generally avoided due to impaired cellular immunity, which increases the risk of adverse effects from attenuated pathogens.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is a 27-year-old female patient presenting with thyroid swelling is unlikely to experience due to compression of adjacent structures?

choices.text: Hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve compression

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) None of the above

Explanation:

Thyroid swelling can cause all of these symptoms from compression:

Hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve compression (Option A):

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve is located posteromedial to the thyroid gland and can be compressed by an enlarged thyroid. This compression can lead to hoarseness of voice or vocal cord paralysis.

Dysphagia due to esophagus compression (Option B):

  • The esophagus can also be compressed by an enlarged thyroid due to its medial relation to the thyroid. This compression can cause difficulty in swallowing or dysphagia.

Superior vena cava syndrome (Option C):

  • Superior vena cava syndrome occurs when the superior vena cava becomes partially or completely blocked, leading to facial and upper extremity edema, breathlessness, and facial plethora.
  • While thyroid swelling can cause compression on nearby structures, it does not typically involve or compress the superior vena cava due to its location in the superior mediastinum. Yet, it can occur rarely.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with meningitis, and the CSF sample is subjected to Gram staining and microscopy, as shown in the image. Which of the following characteristics is associated with the most likely organism?

choices.text: No motility at 22°C and motile at 37°C

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Motile at 22°C and non-motile at 37°C

Explanation:

  • The most likely causative organism in an elderly patient with meningitis is Listeria monocytogenes, a Gram-positive bacillus.
  • Listeria exhibits characteristic tumbling motility at 22°C due to peritrichous flagella but loses motility at 37°C as flagellar expression is downregulated in host environments.
  • Listeria is also known for its ability to survive intracellularly by escaping the phagosome using Listeriolysin O (LLO).

questions.text: Identify the accurate sequence of the auditory pathway.

choices.text: Eight nerve → cochlear nuclei → superior olivary nucleus → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex
Eight nerve →Cochlear nuclei → lateral lemniscus → superior olivary nucleus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex
Eight nerve →Superior olivary nucleus → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex → Cochlear nuclei
Eight nerve →Superior olivary nucleus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex → Cochlear nuclei → lateral lemniscus

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Eight nerve → cochlear nuclei → superior olivary nucleus → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex

Explanation:

The correct auditory pathway sequence is:

Eight nerve → cochlear nuclei → superior olivary nucleus → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex

questions.text: A man has undergone a renal transplant and is taking immunosuppressant drugs. On biopsy, gram positive budding cells with pseudohyphae are observed. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Candida

Explanation:

  • The presence of budding cells with pseudohyphae on biopsy strongly suggests Candida infection.
  • Candida species are opportunistic pathogens in immunosuppressed patients (e.g., transplant recipients).
  • Candida exists in different morphological forms:
    • Budding yeast (blastoconidia)
    • Pseudohyphae (elongated yeast cells with constrictions at septa, forming chains)
    • True hyphae (seen in invasive disease, germ tube formation in serum at 37°C)

 

Laboratory diagnosis of candida

Germ tube test
  • The germ tube test is a specific diagnostic test for Candida albicans.
  • Germ tube also seen in candida dubliniensis
  • Candida tropicalis- pseudo germ tube formation

 

Also known as Reynolds Braude Phenomenon

Candida + Human serum → Incubation → Big tube-like structure (Pseudohyphae).

 

Gram stain

Yeast-like organism - Has both buds and pseudohyphae.

 

SDA Culture media test

Colonies are creamy white, smooth and with a yeasty odor

Corn meal agar test

 

Forms chlamydospores on corn meal agar cultures at 20°C -identified by double wall configuration.

 

Chrom agar test

Colour differentiation test

Each type of organism is seen differently

Aspergillus (Option B): Aspergillus species are characterized by septate hyphae with acute-angle branching (45° angle) rather than budding cells or pseudohyphae. It is a mold, not a yeast, and is a common cause of invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised individuals, often affecting the lungs.

Pneumocystis jirovecii (Option C): Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungal organism responsible for Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in immunosuppressed patients (e.g., AIDS, transplant recipients). It does not form budding cells or pseudohyphae but appears as cystic structures in lung tissue, detected using silver stain.

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option D): Histoplasma is a dimorphic fungus, appearing as intracellular yeast in human tissues. It does not form pseudohyphae, making it an unlikely answer. Histoplasma is commonly associated with disseminated histoplasmosis in immunosuppressed patients, particularly in endemic regions (Ohio and Mississippi River valleys).

questions.text: A 64-year-old female patient is brought to the ENT OPD with difficulties in comprehension. On examination, her fluency is found to be intact with poor comprehension and repetition. Her Pure tone audiometry and ABR is normal. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Wernicke’s aphasia

Explanation:

  • The likely diagnosis in this patient is Wernicke’s aphasia.
  • Wernicke's aphasia is a condition where language comprehension is impaired, but speech may still have a normal rate, rhythm, and grammar. The most common cause of this type of aphasia is an ischemic stroke that affects the posterior temporal lobe of the dominant hemisphere.
  • Pure tone audiometry and auditory brainstem response (ABR) tests are normal in this patient, indicating that there is no hearing loss or problem with the transmission of sound signals from the ear to the brain.

Incorrect Options:

Malingering (Option A):

  • Malingering refers to the deliberate feigning or exaggeration of symptoms for secondary gain, which is unlikely to be in this case.

Auditory cortex lesion (Option B):

  • Auditory cortex lesions could potentially cause speech difficulties, but they would likely present with additional auditory deficits,and therefore show abnormal ABR. .

Broca's aphasia (Option C):

  • Broca's aphasia is a type of non-fluent aphasia that causes a significant reduction in the ability to produce speech spontaneously. This type of aphasia also results in a loss of normal grammatical structure, specifically in the use of small linking words like conjunctions (such as "and," "or," and "but") and prepositions.

questions.text: The socially acquired learned behaviour is known as?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Culture

Explanation:

  • Learned behaviour which has been socially acquired.
  • Culture is passed on from one generation to another by learning process (bith formal and informal).

 

Custom (Option A): Established pattern of human behavior. Customs are considered to be a part of culture as a whole.

Socialization (Option C): It is the process by which individuals adopt the cultures, customs, traditions, beliefs, and habits of a society and become a part of the society.

Mores (Option D): It is social norms that are widely observed within a particular society or culture. Mores determine what is considered morally acceptable or unacceptable within any given culture.

questions.text: Identify the marked ligament?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) PCL

Explanation:

  • The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) is a key ligament in the knee joint, located at the back of the knee. It prevents the tibia from sliding backward relative to the femur and provides stability, especially during activities like walking, running, and jumping.

Knee Ligaments

  • The knee joint is stabilized by several ligaments, including the PCL, ACL, and other supportive ligaments like the patellar tendon. Each of these ligaments plays an important role in maintaining the structural integrity of the knee, facilitating movement, and preventing injury.

Comparison of Knee Ligaments and Tendons

Structure

Location

Function

Injury Characteristics

PCL (Posterior Cruciate Ligament)

Back of the knee joint

Prevents tibia from sliding backward, stabilizes knee

Less common than ACL injury; caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., car accidents, contact sports); symptoms include instability, pain, and swelling

ACL (Anterior Cruciate Ligament)

Front of the knee joint

Prevents tibia from sliding forward, controls rotational movement

Common in sports with sudden stops, direction changes, or jumps (e.g., football, basketball, skiing); symptoms include pain, swelling, and functional loss

Patellar Tendon

Connects patella (kneecap) to tibia

Enables knee extension during walking and running

Injured due to trauma or overuse; symptoms include pain, swelling, and difficulty straightening the knee

 

 

 

 

ACL (Option B): The anterior cruciate ligament is located in the front of the knee, preventing excessive forward movement of the tibia. This is not the ligament in question here.

Patellar Tendon (Option C): The patellar tendon connects the patella to the tibia and does not function in the same way as the cruciate ligaments, which control the motion of the tibia in relation to the femur.

None of the Above (Option D): This option is incorrect because the marked ligament is clearly identified as the PCL.

questions.text: Banana sign on USG is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Spina bifida

Explanation:

  • The Banana sign is a term used in ultrasound (USG) to describe a specific appearance seen in spina bifida, a neural tube defect.
  • It is characterized by the shape of the cerebellum, which appears curved or banana-shaped due to caudal displacement of the cerebellum and tethering of the spinal cord.
  • This sign is typically seen in fetal ultrasound and is a key indicator of spina bifida, particularly in cases of myelomeningocele, a type of open spina bifida.

Neural Tube Defects:

Condition

Description

Spina Bifida (Myelomeningocele)

The cerebellum appears flattened and curled at the base, creating a "banana" shape due to tethering of the spinal cord.

 

A lemon sign indicates a flattened frontal bone often seen in spina bifida.

Omphalocele

Abdominal organs protrude through the umbilical cord, covered by a membrane.

Anencephaly

The brain and skull fail to develop fully, leading to severe neural tube defects.

Absence of the brain, with partial or total lack of the skull.

Encephalocele

Brain tissue protrudes through a skull defect, forming a sac-like structure.

 

Omphalocele (Option A): This is a defect of the abdominal wall and does not show the banana sign.

Anencephaly (Option C): This condition involves the absence of the brain and skull and is not associated with the banana sign.

Encephalocele (Option D): This involves a protrusion of brain tissue through an opening in the skull, and does not show the banana sign.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Ranula

Explanation:

  • A ranula is a type of mucocele that occurs when a salivary gland duct, typically the sublingual gland duct, becomes blocked or damaged, leading to the accumulation of saliva in a cystic structure. This results in a painless, translucent or bluish swelling in the floor of the mouth as shown in the image
  • Treatment: marsupialisation

 

Pleomorphic adenoma (Option B) is the most common salivary gland tumor with an epithelial and mesenchymal component, commonly occurring in the parotid gland located in front, below & behind the ear lobule, pushing it up.

Ludwig angina (Option C) typically presents with a rapidly spreading, firm, and symmetrical swelling in the submandibular (below the jaw) and sublingual (under the tongue) spaces. The swelling may extend to the neck and cause a "woody" or indurated texture. It is also associated with features like fever, drooling, neck pain, and difficulty swallowing.

Dermoid cysts (Option D) usually present as a well-defined, raised mass under the skin. The size can vary from small to large.The surface of the dermoid cyst is usually smooth and can appear skin-colored or slightly discolored. It may resemble normal skin or have a slightly yellowish hue.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a benefit of ultrasound (USG) compared to mammography?

choices.text: USG can be used to detect calcifications, asymmetries, and distortions better than mammography
Can be used for guided biopsy
In young females with dense breasts
Can be used to differentiate solid VS cystic

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) USG can be used to detect calcifications, asymmetries, and distortions better than mammography.

Explanation:

  • Mammography is superior to USG in detecting microcalcifications, architectural distortions, and asymmetries, which are key features of early breast malignancies.
  • Ultrasound is not effective in detecting tiny microcalcifications (seen in DCIS) because it relies on sound waves rather than X-rays.
  • Mammography remains the gold standard for breast cancer screening, especially in women >40 years.

Comparison of USG vs. Mammography

Feature

Ultrasound (USG)

Mammography

Microcalcifications detection

Poor

Excellent

Architectural distortion

Poor

Good

Best for dense breasts

Yes (young females)

Limited sensitivity

Solid vs. cystic differentiation

Excellent

Poor

Guided biopsy

Yes

Yes (stereotactic)

Radiation exposure

None

Yes (low dose)

 

Can be used for guided biopsy (Option B): Ultrasound is excellent for guided biopsies, as it provides real-time imaging, allowing accurate needle placement for tissue sampling.

In young females with dense breasts (Option C): Ultrasound is particularly useful in young women with dense breasts because mammography may not clearly differentiate between benign and malignant masses in dense tissue, whereas ultrasound can.

Can be used to differentiate solid vs cystic (Option D): Ultrasound is effective in distinguishing between solid tumors and fluid-filled cysts, which helps avoid unnecessary biopsies in cystic cases.

questions.text:
Match the poisons and their site of action.


	
		
			
			A. Datura
			
			
			1. CVS
			
		
		
			
			B. Nicotine
			
			
			2. CNS
			
		
		
			
			C. Nitric acid
			
			
			3. SKIN
			
		
		
			
			D. Nux vomica (strychnine)
			
			
			4. SPINAL CORD
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4

Explanation:

Datura (A-2): Datura primarily acts on the central nervous system (CNS).

Actions
  • Anticholinergic effects: CNS stimulant initially (causing anticholinergic effects such as delirium, hallucinations, and confusion), followed by CNS depression (respiratory center).
  • Vagolytic action: Heart stimulation.

Nicotine (B-1): Nicotine affects the cardiovascular system (CVS) by stimulating nicotinic receptors, leading to tachycardia, hypertension, and vasoconstriction.

Nitric acid (C-3): Nitric acid primarily affects the skin, causing corrosive injuries, burns, and tissue damage upon contact.

Nux vomica (strychnine) (D-4): Strychnine acts on the spinal cord, causing excitation of motor neurons, leading to muscle spasms and convulsions.

Clinical Features
  • Opisthotonus- arched body with only the back of head and heels touching the ground:
  • Emprosthotonus- forward curve
  • Pleurothotonus- sideways curve
  • Risus sardonicus- fixed grin:

questions.text: A patient with Alzheimer’s disease refused to take oral drugs. Which of the following drugs can be prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Rivastigmine

  • In this scenario, a transdermal Rivastigmine patch can be used as an alternative, as it is the only option available in India.
  • It is a reversible anticholinesterase used in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.
  • It is also available as a transdermal patch, which is applied to the skin and releases the medication gradually over 24 hours, ensuring a steady and continuous therapeutic effect.

Treatment of Alzheimer’s disease

  • Patient and caregiver education.
  • Neurotransmitter-based therapies
    • Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors
      • Donepezil
      • Rivastigmine
      • Galantamine
    • N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptor blocker
      • Memantine
    • A common approach to AD drug therapy is to initiate a cholinesterase inhibitor for a patient diagnosed with mild AD dementia and to add memantine when patients enter the moderate stage of the disease.
  • Therapies targeting amyloid-𝛃
    • Aducanumab
      • MOA: Monoclonal antibody targeting the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide
      • Dosage: Intravenous infusion every 4 weeks (7 infusions in total)
      • Should only be considered for treating MCI (Mild Cognitive Impairment) or early dementia due to AD
      • S/E: Vasogenic cerebral edema, cortical microhemorrhages, and superficial siderosis

Memantine (Option A), an NMDA antagonist for moderate to severe Alzheimer's, regulates glutamate and is given orally. Treatment typically starts with a cholinesterase inhibitor for mild AD and adds memantine in the moderate stage, but it is only available in oral form.

Donepezil (Option B) and Galantamine (Option D) are reversible anticholinesterase inhibitors used to treat mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. While they are available in both oral and transdermal patch forms, only the oral forms are accessible in India, making them incorrect options.

questions.text: A man presents with a rash on his flank, with Itching for the past 2 weeks. The patient has tried several over-the-counter medications without any improvement. In physical examination, the rash is seen on his palms and the sole of one foot, but no oral lesions are found. What is the Iikely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Erythema multiforme

Explanation:

Erythema multiforme is usually seen as a reaction to drugs or HSV. It presents as target lesions on the palms, soles, or trunk. It shows a dusky, central area or blister, a dark red inflammatory zone surrounded by a pale ring of edema, and an erythematous halo on the extreme periphery of the lesion.

Urticaria (Option A): It usually presents as wheals  (erythematous, edematous, itchy, and evanescent lesions). They are small and multiple as shown below:

Viral exanthem (Option B): Exanthems usually start in the trunk and spread to other parts

Tinea manuum (Option D): Skin lesions caused by dermatophytes in the palms. It is a circular ring-shaped scaly lesion.

questions.text:
Match the following woods lamp findings:


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Erythrasma
			
			
			a. Yellow
			
		
		
			
			2. Pityriasis versicolor
			
			
			b. Coral red fluorescence
			
		
		
			
			3. Tinea capitis
			
			
			c. Pink
			
		
		
			
			4. Vitiligo
			
			
			d. Green
			
		
		
			 
			
			e. Milky white
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-e

Explanation:

  • Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic procedure used to observe fluorescence patterns in the skin under ultraviolet light.
  • It helps identify fungal infections, bacterial infections, pigmentary disorders, and other skin conditions based on characteristic fluorescence reactions
  • This non-invasive test is conducted in a darkened room, emitting light of wavelength 320-450nm.

Disease

Milky white

Erythrasma

Pseudomonas

Scabies

Porphyria

Ash-leaf macules
