questions.text: Which of the following is correct about congenital CMV?

choices.text: 40-50% of the cases are symptomatic at birth
Optimum sample for PCR is blood/urine/saliva sample within 2-3 weeks of birth
If asymptomatic at birth, then there is a 25.7% higher risk of developing SNHL later
Most common congenital infection after congenital syphilis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Optimum sample for PCR is blood/urine/saliva sample within 2-3 weeks of birth

Explanation:

  • The correct statement is that the optimal sample for PCR in diagnosing congenital CMV infection is blood, urine, or saliva collected within the first 2-3 weeks of life. Testing after this period cannot reliably distinguish between congenital and acquired infection. Saliva and urine samples are more sensitive than blood because not all infants with congenital CMV are viremic at birth.

Congenital Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

Causative Agent

Cytomegalovirus (CMV), a member of the herpesvirus family

Transmission

Vertical transmission from mother to fetus during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding.

Incidence

CMV is the most common congenital viral infection, affecting approximately 0.5-2% of all live births.

Incubation Period

3–12 weeks

Risk Period

Highest fetal risk occurs when the mother contracts CMV during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester

Classical Triad

1. Sensorineural deafness

2. Microcephaly

3. Chorioretinitis

Clinical Features in Neonates

Asymptomatic in 80-90% of cases

 

Symptomatic in 10-20% of cases, with signs such as:

  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Petechial rash,
  • Microcephaly
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Seizures
  • Intracranial periventricular calcifications.

Long-Term Sequelae
  • Hearing loss (most common)
  • Developmental delay
  • Visual impairment (e.g., chorioretinitis)
  • Cerebral palsy
  • Seizure disorders

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting CMV DNA using PCR in urine, saliva, or blood collected within the first 2-3 weeks of life.
  • Preferred sample: Urine > saliva > blood
  • IgM antibody detection in fetal blood is less reliable.

Management

Ganciclovir or valganciclovir may be used in symptomatic infants with progressive neurologic disease or hearing loss.

Prognosis
  • Asymptomatic infants generally have a normal long-term outcome
  • Symptomatic infants may have developmental and neurological impairments

questions.text: A 3.5 kg term neonate born to a mother with eclampsia did not cry at birth. Which of the following is the criterion for perinatal asphyxia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypotonia

Explanation:

  • The essential criterion for diagnosing perinatal asphyxia among the given options is hypotonia.

Perinatal Asphyxia

  • Perinatal asphyxia refers to an insult to the fetus or newborn due to inadequate oxygenation (hypoxia) and/or impaired perfusion (ischemia), leading to metabolic complications. It often results in lactic acidosis and hypercarbia.

Essential Criteria for Diagnosis:

  • Umbilical Arterial Blood pH <7.0: Metabolic or mixed acidemia (severe acidosis) indicates oxygen deprivation during birth. The cutoff for perinatal asphyxia is a pH <7.0, not <7.2
  • APGAR Score: An APGAR score of 0-3 persisting for >5 minutes is a significant marker of perinatal asphyxia. A score of 4-7 for >5 minutes (Option A) is not diagnostic.
  • Neurological Manifestations: Hypotonia (floppiness), seizures, coma, or hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) are critical indicators of neurological dysfunction caused by asphyxia.
  • Multiorgan Dysfunction: Asphyxia can lead to dysfunction in multiple organs, including the brain, heart, kidneys, and liver.

 

APGAR persists at 4-7 for >5 minutes (Option A): This indicates moderate neonatal distress but does not meet the criteria for severe perinatal asphyxia. A score of 0-3 persisting for >5 minutes is required for diagnosis.

Cord pH <7.2 (Option B): While a pH <7.2 suggests mild acidosis, the threshold for perinatal asphyxia is <7.0, indicating severe acidemia.

Hypocalcemia (Option C): Hypocalcemia is a secondary complication of perinatal asphyxia but is not included in its diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: Among the listed options, which substance is not utilized as a chelating agent in cases of heavy metal poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Oximes

 

Explanation:

Oximes, such as pralidoxime, are not chelating agents. They are used as antidotes in organophosphate poisoning by reactivating acetylcholinesterase, which is inhibited by the poison.

 

 

Deferiprone (Option A): Deferiprone is a chelating agent used to treat iron overload, commonly seen in conditions like thalassemia major. It binds to iron and facilitates its excretion.

 

EDTA (Option B): Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) is a well-known chelating agent used in cases of lead and other heavy metal poisonings. It binds metal ions, aiding in their excretion.

 

Penicillamine (Option C): Penicillamine is an effective chelating agent for metals like copper (used in Wilson's disease) and lead. It binds metals and facilitates their removal from the body.

questions.text: An autopsy was conducted on a male with a history of drowning. No water was found in his lungs, and he was labeled a case of dry drowning. What is the cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Laryngospasm

Explanation:

Dry drowning occurs when water triggers a reflex laryngospasm, causing the airway to close. This prevents water from entering the lungs but also obstructs airflow, leading to hypoxia and death. This is the most accurate explanation for dry drowning.

Types of atypical drowning

Dry drowning

  • In dry drowning, water does not enter the lungs due to laryngeal spasms induced by small amounts of water entering the larynx.
  • Cause of death: Reflex cardiac arrest due to vasovagal stimulation.

Immersion syndrome (Cold water drowning)
  • It refers to syncope resulting from cardiac arrhythmias on sudden
  • contact with water that is at least 5°C lower than the body temperature.
  • Also called hydrocution or submersion inhibition.

Near drowning (post-immersion syndrome or secondary drowning)
  • Near drowning refers to survival beyond 24 hours after a submersion episode.
  • Death is caused by complications or sequelae like ARDS, pneumonia, sepsis, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, and DIC.

Asphyxia (Option A): Asphyxia is a general term for oxygen deprivation leading to death, it is not the direct mechanism in dry drowning. The absence of water in the lungs suggests a different mechanism.

Vagal inhibition (Option B): Vagal inhibition can lead to sudden death due to overactivation of the vagus nerve, but it is not the primary cause in cases of dry drowning.

Ventricular fibrillation (Option D): Ventricular fibrillation is not typically associated with dry drowning. It is more likely in cases of electrocution or cardiac conditions.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements for cystic fibrosis:

i. Increased Cl- in sweat.
ii. Decreased Cl- in sweat.
iii. Increased Cl- in pancreatic juice.
iv. Decreased Cl- in pancreatic juice.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) i and iv

Explanation:

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene. The CFTR protein regulates chloride channels in various organs, including the sweat glands and the pancreas, which leads to the clinical features observed in CF.

  • Increased chloride in sweat (i): In CF, the CFTR defect leads to impaired chloride reabsorption in sweat glands. This results in abnormally high chloride levels in sweat, which is used as a diagnostic test for CF (sweat chloride test). A sweat chloride level >80 mmol/L is diagnostic of CF.
  • Decreased chloride in pancreatic juice (iv): In CF, the CFTR defect also impairs chloride secretion in the pancreas. This results in thick and adherent exocrine secretions that obstruct pancreatic ducts, impair enzyme production, and lead to malabsorption and steatorrhea.

Cystic fibrosis

Genetic Basis
  • Gene: CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator)
  • Location: Chromosome 7q31.2
  • Common Mutation: ΔF508
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive

Pathophysiology

 

  • CFTR Dysfunction: Defective chloride transport, increased sodium absorption, dehydrated mucus
  • Metabolic: (Hypokalemia) Due to excessive loss of potassium through sweat and impaired renal potassium handling
  • Respiratory: Airway obstruction, bacterial colonization, bronchiectasis, respiratory failure
  • Gastrointestinal: Pancreatic duct obstruction, malabsorption, Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome
  • Sweat Glands: Salty sweat
  • Reproductive:
    Infertility in males: Congenital absence of the vas deferens in males leading to azoospermia and infertility.
    Infertility in females: Defective CFTR in the cervix leads to the production of thick, dehydrated cervical mucus that blocks the cervical os, impairing sperm entry and reducing fertility.

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory: Chronic productive cough, recurrent infections, bronchiectasis
  • Gastrointestinal: Steatorrhea, malabsorption, meconium ileus, failure to thrive
  • Genitourinary: Infertility (males), delayed puberty
  • Other: Digital clubbing, salt-loss syndromes (Contraction alkalosis)

Diagnosis

Diagnostic Criteria

Requirement 1: Any ONE of the following

 

  • Clinical Features: Presence of typical features
  • Family History: A sibling with diagnosed cystic fibrosis
  • Newborn Screening: Positive result indicating risk for CF
  • IRT Screening: Elevated Immunoreactive Trypsinogen (IRT) for pancreatic insufficiency

Requirement 2: At least ONE of the following

Laboratory Evidence:

 

  • Sweat Chloride Test: Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations on separate days ≥60 mMol/L (Pilocarpine iontophoresis method)
  • CFTR Mutations: Identification of two CFTR mutations
  • Nasal Potential Difference: Abnormal measurement

Microbes
  • <18 years: Staphylococcus aureus
  • >18 years: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

  • Burkholderia cepacia: High mortality, low incidence

Management Strategies
  • Airway Clearance: Chest physiotherapy, percussion, postural drainage
  • Infection Control: Antibiotics, CFTR modulators
  • Nutritional Support: High-calorie diet, PERT, vitamin supplementation (A, D, E, K)
  • Other: Insulin for CFRD, bone health management

Advanced Therapies
  • CFTR Modulators: Ivacaftor, lumacaftor, Trikafta
  • Trikafta: Elexacaftor-Tezacaftor-Ivacaftor (≥2 years old), improves lung function, reduces sweat chloride

questions.text: In which condition is La belle indifference observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Conversion disorder

La belle indifférence (“beautiful indifference”) is observed in conversion disorder.

  • It refers to a patient's indifferent attitude toward severe symptoms (absence of psychological distress despite serious medical illness or symptoms).
  • It is most commonly associated with conversion disorder (CD) or functional neurologic symptom disorder (FNSD) in DSM-5, though it can also occur in seriously ill patients with a stoic attitude.
  • It is characterised by neurological deficits without medical or neurological etiology, incompatible with known disorders.
  • For instance, the girl who is not able to see may be sitting very calmly.

Panic disorder (Option B) is characterised by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks, which are sudden episodes of intense fear or discomfort accompanied by physical symptoms such as palpitations, sweating, trembling, and feelings of impending doom or losing control. Individuals with panic disorder typically experience significant distress and anxiety during panic attacks, which is contrary to the indifference seen in La Belle indifference.

Schizophrenia (Option C) is a chronic mental disorder that involves a range of symptoms, including delusions, hallucinations, disorganised thinking, and emotional dysregulation. Individuals with schizophrenia usually experience distress and impairment due to their symptoms and are unlikely to exhibit the characteristic indifference associated with la belle indifférence.

Depression (Option D) is a mood disorder characterised by persistent feelings of sadness, loss of interest or pleasure, and other symptoms such as changes in appetite, sleep disturbances, and thoughts of death or suicide. Individuals with depression typically experience emotional distress and are unlikely to display the indifference associated with la belle indifférence.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated wIth non-scarring alopecia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Frontal fibrosing alopecia

Explanation:

Frontal fibrosing alopecia is scarring alopecia, not non-scarring. It leads to permanent hair loss due to fibrosis and destruction of hair follicles, unlike non-scarring alopecia, where hair loss is reversible if the underlying cause is addressed.

Cicatricial alopecias

Non-cicatricial alopecias

Loss of hair follicle stem cells

Stem cells are not affected

Irreversible cessation of hair cycle

Damage to hair cycle can be reversed

Dermoscopy: Absent follicular ostia

Dermoscopy: Ostia are present. Black dots may be seen

Examples:

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia.
  • Folliculitis.
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Scleroderma

Types:

  • Patterned: Androgenetic alopecia (Option B)
  • Diffuse: Effluvium (Option D)
  • Patchy:
    • Alopecia areata (Option A)
    • Trichotillomania
    • Tinea capitis
    • Moth-eaten alopecia

Telogen Effluvium (Option D) is hair loss triggered by physical stressors like surgery, trauma, or illnesses such as dengue, malaria, COVID-19, TB, or chikungunya. TE can also occur during pregnancy, known as Telogen gravidarum.

  • Here, stress causes hair follicles to prematurely enter the resting phase (Telogen) instead of the growth phase (Anagen), leading to hair shedding after about three months.
  • Chronic TE can be caused by factors like iron deficiency, thyroid disorders, crash dieting, or malnutrition. Prolonged exposure to stressors can result in long-term hair loss.

questions.text: One-day-old term neonate presented with respiratory distress, tachypnea, SpO2-80%, and scaphoid abdomen. Which of the following cannot be used in resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bag and mask ventilation

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario describes a one-day-old term neonate with respiratory distress, tachypnea, SpO2 of 80%, and a scaphoid abdomen—suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

Why Bag and Mask Ventilation Should Be Avoided

  • In CDH, the presence of abdominal contents in the chest cavity severely restricts lung development, leading to pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory failure. Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in such cases because it can increase abdominal distension, which can further compromise lung expansion and worsen the already compromised pulmonary function. It also raises the risk of gastric insufflation.

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH)

Etiology

Failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal during fetal development (normally by 8-10 weeks gestation).

Prevalence of Sides

Left-sided hernias are more common (80%).

Common Hernia Sites

1. Foramen of Morgagni: Hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm (defect between sternal and costal attachments), often involving the transverse colon.

2. Foramen of Bochdalek: Hernia through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally.

 

Pathophysiology

Pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral), leading to smaller bronchi, reduced bronchial branching, and less alveolar surface area. May cause pulmonary hypertension due to thickened arteriolar smooth muscle.

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory distress at birth
  • Grunting respiration
  • Chest retractions
  • Dyspnea
  • Cyanosis
  • Scaphoid abdomen
  • Decreased breath sounds with bowel sounds heard over the chest
  • Shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH).

Associated Complications

Pulmonary hypoplasia, pulmonary hypertension, increased systemic vasoactive factors.

Diagnosis

Clinical evaluation (respiratory distress, scaphoid abdomen, etc.), imaging (X-ray, ultrasound, or CT scan).

Management

Immediate resuscitation and stabilization, surgical repair of the diaphragm defect.

Contraindication

Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated due to risk of insufflation of abdominal contents into the chest cavity. Intubation is preferred.

 

Positive pressure ventilation (Option A): It may be used, but only with caution and under appropriate guidance. Endotracheal intubation is preferable for securing the airway in these babies.

Endotracheal intubation (Option B): This is a standard practice for airway management and is essential for controlling ventilation in neonates with respiratory distress due to CDH.

Oxygen supplementation (Option D): This is routinely used to manage hypoxia in neonates with CDH, improving oxygenation.

questions.text: A girl was found deceased in a lake, and her body was retrieved. Which of the following is false regarding ante-mortem drowning?

choices.text: No mud and vegetation in the respiratory tract

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) No mud and vegetation in the respiratory tract

Explanation:

  • In ante-mortem drowning, mud, vegetation, or other debris from the drowning medium may be aspirated into the respiratory tract during the victim’s struggle to breathe.
  • The presence of these elements can confirm ante-mortem drowning.

Signs of Antemortem Drowning:

  • External Signs: Foam at the mouth/nose, Washerwoman skin, Cyanosis.
  • Internal Signs: Lungs: Over-distended, heavy, and waterlogged, Mucus: Sticky mucus in airways due to fluid inhalation.
  • Diatoms: Microscopic algae in internal organs (bone marrow), indicating water inhalation.
  • Paltauf’s spots: Subpleural hemorrhages caused by lung over-expansion.

Water in the stomach (Option A): In cases of ante-mortem drowning, water may be swallowed and found in the stomach as a result of reflexive actions during the drowning process.

Froth on nose and mouth (Option B): Froth is a characteristic feature of ante-mortem drowning, caused by the mixing of water, air, and mucus during respiratory efforts.

Cadaveric spasm in hand muscle (Option D): Cadaveric spasm, particularly in the hand muscles (e.g., tightly holding grass or weeds), is often seen in drowning cases as a sign of intense physical and emotional struggle before death.

questions.text: SCOFF criteria is used as a screening tool for which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Eating disorder

The SCOFF Criteria are primarily used as a screening tool for eating disorders, including anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge eating disorder.

  • The five questions are related to key symptoms and behaviours commonly seen in individuals with eating disorders, such as a distorted body image, a preoccupation with weight, and loss of control over eating.
  • The SCOFF questionnaire comprises the following inquiries:
    • S - Do you make yourself Sick (vomit) because you feel uncomfortably full?
    • C - Do you worry you have lost Control over how much you eat?
    • O - Have you recently lost more than One stone in a 3-month period?
    • F - Do you believe yourself to be Fat when others say you are too thin?
    • F - Would you say that Food dominates your life?
  • One point for every “yes”; a score of ≥2 indicates a likely case of anorexia nervosa or bulimia.

Sexual disorders (Option B) encompass a range of conditions that affect a person's sexual thoughts, desires, or behaviours. The SCOFF criteria are not designed to assess or evaluate these types of disorders.

Alcohol use disorder (Option C) refers to a problematic pattern of alcohol consumption leading to significant impairment or distress. While screening tools do exist for alcohol use disorder, including the AUDIT (Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test) and the CAGE questionnaire the SCOFF criteria are not among them.

Schizophrenia (Option D) is a complex mental disorder, characterised by symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, disorganised thinking, and impaired social functioning. The SCOFF criteria are specific to screening for eating disorders and do not assess symptoms related to schizophrenia.

questions.text: A child with type 1 DM presents with acidosis, and blood sugar 400 mg/dl. What is the further management?

choices.text: Normal saline with SC insulin stat
Normal saline followed by insulin infusion after 1 hour
Normal saline and insulin infusion immediately

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Normal saline followed by insulin infusion after 1 hour

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario describes a child with type 1 diabetes mellitus (DM) presenting with acidosis and blood sugar 400 mg/dl, suggesting diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).

Diabetic Ketoacidosis" data-author="" data-hash="11520" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/Mw0OKvq9qC8YpsgMGnTS1746179817.png" />

 

IV insulin stat (Option A): Administering IV insulin stat is not recommended in this scenario, as fluid resuscitation should be prioritized first. Insulin therapy should start at least 1 hour after fluid replacement to avoid complications like cerebral edema due to a rapid decrease in blood glucose.

Normal saline with SC insulin stat (Option B): Subcutaneous insulin is not suitable for managing acute DKA. Intravenous insulin infusion is the preferred approach in this emergency setting as it provides more controlled glucose lowering.

Normal saline and insulin infusion immediately (Option D): Starting insulin infusion immediately, without first addressing fluid resuscitation, can lead to a rapid drop in blood glucose. This might cause dangerous complications, including cerebral edema. Fluid replacement must be started before insulin infusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding sample collection in a case of alcohol intoxication?

choices.text: Sample area cleaned with soap and water
Sample should be preserved without preservative
Only one urine sample is required

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sample area cleaned with soap and water

Explanation:

Soap and water are used to clean the sample collection area to avoid contamination with alcohol or other substances.

Alcohol sample collection

Cleaning the Skin
  • Avoid using spirit or alcohol on skin or syringe.
  • Use 1:1000 mercuric chloride solution or soap and water.

Preservation of Blood
  • Add 100 mg sodium fluoride and 30 mg potassium oxalate to 10 mL blood.
  • Shake thoroughly to prevent alcohol loss due to glycolysis and bacterial activity.

Alternate Preservatives
  • Use 50 mg phenyl mercuric nitrate or sodium azide for 10 mL blood or urine.

Storage Containers
  • Use screw-capped glass bottles to minimize alcohol evaporation.
  • Avoid rubber stoppers to prevent contamination from oxidizable substances.
  • Label containers with name, date, and time of collection.

Storage Guidelines
  • Refrigerate if not sent to the lab immediately; avoid freezing (prevents cell lysis).
  • Samples maintain alcohol concentration for weeks at room temperature.

Sample area cleaned with spirit (Option A): The sample collection area with spirit or alcohol-based solutions can contaminate the sample, leading to false-positive results.

Sample should be preserved without preservative (Option C): Blood samples for alcohol analysis are typically preserved with sodium fluoride to inhibit fermentation and prevent false readings due to alcohol production by microorganisms.

Only one urine sample is required (Option D): In cases of alcohol intoxication, multiple urine samples are often collected over time to monitor alcohol levels and assess the rate of elimination.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes lithium?

choices.text: It can cause fine postural tremors at a therapeutic dosage
It is not absorbed from the gut

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - It can cause fine postural tremors at a therapeutic dosage

  • Lithium can cause fine tremors in therapeutic doses.

Lithium

Mechanism of action

  • Increase the level of amine (if the mood is low) by inhibiting the Glycogen synthase kinase-3 enzyme
  • Decrease the level of amine (if the mood is high)
    • Inhibits inositol monophosphatase enzyme
    • Inhibits the release of amines
    • Stabilises neuronal membrane

Uses

  • Bipolar disorder
  • Hypnic headache (occurs in sleep)
  • Anti-suicidal action (another drug is clozapine)
  • Resistant cases of depression

Adverse effects
  • Alopecia and acne
  • Weight gain
  • Seizures and sinus node dysfunction (leading to AV block)
  • Hypothyroidism (hyperthyroidism in rare cases)
  • High doses can cause coarse tremors, ataxia, tinnitus, diarrhea, and seizures.
  • Ebstein’s anomaly: A cardiovascular defect called tricuspid atresia, which has a teratogenic effect when administered to pregnant women.
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI)
  • Fine tremors (most common adverse effect)
  • ECG changes: T-wave flattening
  • Leukocytosis
  • Loose stools (diarrhea)

It is not absorbed from the gut (Option B): This statement is incorrect. Lithium is readily absorbed in the gastrointestinal tract after oral administration.

It is not teratogenic (Option C): Lithium is a medication commonly used for the treatment of bipolar disorder. However, it is known to be teratogenic, meaning it can cause harm to a developing fetus if taken during pregnancy. Lithium exposure during the first trimester has been associated with an increased risk of cardiac malformations, particularly Ebstein's anomaly, in the fetus

Approved for absence seizure (Option D): This statement is incorrect. Lithium is not commonly used for the treatment of absent seizures (also known as absence seizures). It is primarily indicated for bipolar disorder and certain other psychiatric conditions. Drugs used for absence seizures include valproate, lamotrigine, and ethosuximide (especially in < 2 years of age).

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with scaly lesions over the body, as shown in the Image below. No other associated symptoms are present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pityriasis Rosea

Explanation:

Pityriasis Rosea is a scaly red lesion that usually occurs on the trunk. They are scaly heralds patches and a collarette of scales can be seen. It usually presents 2-3 weeks after URTI and Gl infections.

Lichen planus (Option A): Presents as papulosquamous disorder which affects the skin, mucosa, hair, and nails. It is pruritic and it affects flexure surfaces.

Seborrheic dermatitis (Option C): Usually seen as red itchy, scaly patches on the skin. Since in this case, it is asymptomatic it cannot be this option.

Atopic dermatitis (Option D): Atopic dermatitis is dry, itchy, and erythematous. It is not asymptomatic. Hence the incorrect choice.

questions.text: Due to the requirement of regular blood monitoring, what rare side effects must be considered for a patient undergoing treatment with clozapine who is diagnosed with schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Agranulocytosis

  • Clozapine is associated with a rare but serious side effect, agranulocytosis, which requires regular blood monitoring.

Class

Atypical antipsychotic (1st atypical antipsychotic discovered)

Mechanism of action

Primarily works as a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, but it also has significant effects on serotonin receptors (5-HT2A and 5-HT2C), which helps reduce symptoms in treatment-resistant cases.

Uses

  • DOC for TRS (Treatment-resistant schizophrenia): Used only when a patient doesn't respond to at least 2 antipsychotics.
  • Only antipsychotics with anti-suicidal properties (shown ↓ suicidal ideas in Schizophrenia patients).

Side effects

Severe risks (Pneumonic: SAM):

  • S - Seizures (Option C ruled out)
    • Dose dependant
    • > 600 mg has more seizures
  • A - Agranulocytosis (Option A)
    • Idiosyncratic
    • ↓ WBC (Neutrophils)
    • The main reason for deaths and withdrawal from the market
    • Weekly monitoring of WBC and Neutrophil count for 1st 6 months is important
  • M - Myocarditis (Option B ruled out)
    • Idiosyncratic
    • Chest pain
    • Dyspnea
    • Abnormal ECG

 

Common side effects:

  • Sedation (most common)
  • Weight gain (maximum weight gain of all antipsychotics)
  • Hypersalivation (sialorrhea)
  • Sedation
  • Tachycardia
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Constipation
  • Hypotension

Rare side effects include myocarditis.

Contraindications

  • WBC count - < 3500/mm
  • Previous bone marrow disorder
  • H/o of Agranulocytosis during Clozapine treatment
  • Use of another bone marrow suppressant (carbamazepine)

Monitoring

TLC and ANC

  • Once a week for the first 6 months
  • Once in two weeks for the next 6 months
  • Once a month till the patient continues

 

 

Cerebral bleeding (Option D), or intracerebral hemorrhage, is not a recognised or common side effect of clozapine. While antipsychotic medications can have cardiovascular and cerebrovascular effects, including an increased risk of stroke, cerebral bleeding specifically is not associated with clozapine.

questions.text: Identify the following image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Langer's lines

Explanation:

Lines of Langer:

  • The arrangement of the dense network of collagen and elastic fibers in the dermis is referred to as the cleavage direction, while its linear representation on the skin is known as Langer’s lines.

Impact of skin tension:

  • Skin tension and Langer’s lines can change round skin defects into elongated wounds that resemble stab wounds.
  • They can also affect genuine stab wounds, making them appear artificially lengthened.
  • The shape of the wounds also depends on the cleavage lines of Langer.

Assessing wound angles:

  • It may be necessary to bring the wound margins together to determine if a wound angle is sharp or blunt.
  • Holding the edges together aids in a clearer evaluation of the angles.

Variability in injury presentation:

  • Identical weapons can cause different types of injuries based on their location and orientation on the body, influenced by skin elasticity and the alignment of Langer’s lines.
  • A stab wound parallel to the Langer’s lines appears slit-shaped and narrow
  • A stab wound that cuts through the Langer’s lines transversely will gape

Hinderer's line (Option A): Hinderer's line is used in facial surgery to demarcate regions of aesthetic importance. It does not describe natural tension lines of the skin.

Blaschko lines (Option C): Blaschko lines are invisible lines on the skin that represent embryonic cell migration patterns. They become visible in certain skin conditions like linear epidermal nevi or lichen planus.

Dermatomes (Option D): Dermatomes are areas of skin innervated by sensory fibers of a single spinal nerve. They are unrelated to skin tension or collagen orientation.

questions.text:
Statement 1 - A 59-year-old patient presents with flaccid bullae. Histopathology shows a suprabasal acantholytic split.

Statement 2 - The row of tombstones' appearance is diagnostic of Pemphigus vulgaris.

choices.text: Statements 1 & 2 are correct, 2 is not explaining 1
Statements 1 and 2 are correct and 2 is the correct explanation for 1

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Statements 1 & 2 are correct, 2 is not explaining 1

Explanation:

Correct Option A - Statements 1 & 2 are correct, 2 Is not explaining 1:

  • In pemphigus vulgaris, both flaccid blisters and suprabasal acantholytic split, as well as rows of tombstones, are seen.
  • The row of tombstones' appearance is seen due to the detached basal cells from the basement membrane.

Incorrect Options:

Statement 1 Is Incorrect (Option B): this choice is incorrect as there is the presence of flaccid blisters and suprabasal acantholytic split seen in PV

Statement 1 and 2 Is Incorrect (Option C): both statements correctly describe pemphigus vulgaris.

Statement 1 and 2 are correct and 2 Is the correct explanation for 1 (Option D): Statement 2 is not the correct explanation of statement 1.

questions.text: A boy is experiencing low mood, decreased energy and decreased interest in his surroundings. He has not been taking food for the past one week. The thought sample says - ‘I lost my head. I am dead. How can I eat?’. What type of delusion does the patient exhibit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Nihilistic delusion

  • The given scenario, where the patient believes his head is missing and that he is dead, is diagnosed as a Nihilistic delusion (also known as Cotard's delusion or the delusion of negation).
  • It is a psychiatric condition where the individual believes they are dead, nonexistent, or that parts of their body are missing or decaying, often involving denial of their body, mind, loved ones, and the world.

Types of delusional disorders:

Type

Description

Persecutory (Delusion of persecution)

Believing others are trying to harm them

Jealous (Delusion of infidelity or Othello syndrome)

Believing that a lover or partner is unfaithful

Erotomanic  (Delusion of erotomania or De Clerambault’s syndrome)

Believing that another person (often of higher status) is in love with them

Somatic type

Believing he or she has some physical disorder that includes:

  • Delusion of parasitosis (infested with parasites, such as bugs or worms)
  • Delusion of dysmorphophobia (body or appearance is distorted or altered in a negative way)
  • Delusion of halitosis (bad breath)

Grandiose  (Delusion of grandeur)

Believing one has exceptional abilities, wealth, or fame

Delusion of Guilt

Believing that they are an evil person and have ruined their family

Nihilistic delusion (Option B)

Deny the existence of their body, mind, loved ones, or the world, claiming they have no intelligence, that parts of their body are absent, or even believing they are dead or that the world has ended

Delusion of Poverty

Believing they are impoverished and that destitution threatens them and their family.

Mixed and unspecified type (Delusion of misidentification)

(Option A ruled out)

Delusions that are a combination of types or not described by one of the categories:

  • Capgras syndrome
  • Fregoli syndrome
  • Syndrome of metamorphosis
  • Syndrome of subjective doubles

Bizarre delusions (Option C) are characterised by beliefs that are clearly implausible and not derived from ordinary life experiences.

Hypochondriacal delusion (Option D) involves the belief of having a severe illness or disease despite evidence to the contrary. The patient's statement does not directly reflect a preoccupation with physical illness or disease, so this option is not applicable.

questions.text: Which of the following is a new drug approved for Rett syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Trofinetide

  • Trofinetide is a new drug approved for Rett syndrome.
  • It is a synthetic analogue of glycine-proline-glutamate, a naturally occurring peptide.
  • The exact mechanism is unknown, but it may have anti-inflammatory and trophic effects.
  • Clinical trials have shown promising results, with improvements in certain Rett syndrome symptoms.

Ambien (Option B), generic name: zolpidem, is a sedative medication primarily used for the treatment of insomnia.

Lunesta (Option C), generic name: eszopiclone, is another sedative medication used for the treatment of insomnia. Similar to Ambien,

GHB opioids (Option D) is a central nervous system depressant (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) that has been used recreationally and has sedative effects. Opioids, on the other hand, are a class of medications used for pain relief. Neither GHB nor opioids are approved drugs specifically indicated for the treatment of Rett syndrome.

questions.text: A female was given morphine sulfate during labor for pain, following which she developed respiratory distress. Which of the following will be the correct antidote?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Naloxone

Explanation:

Naloxone is the specific antidote for opioid toxicity, including respiratory depression caused by morphine. It works as a competitive antagonist at opioid receptors, rapidly reversing the effects of opioids.

Toxic agent

Specific antidote

Acetaminophen

N-acetyl cysteine

Atropine, datura

(Option B ruled out)

Physostigmine

Organophosphates

Atropine and pralidoxime (Option C ruled out)

Benzodiazepines

Flumazenil

Carbon monoxide

Hyperbaric oxygen

Cyanide

Amyl nitrite, Sodium nitrite, sodium thiosulfate (3-step cyanide antidote kit)

Arsenic, Mercury

BAL (Dimercaprol) > DMSA (Succimer)

Lead

EDTA > DMSA (Succimer)

Copper sulfate

D-penicillamine > DMSA > EDTA

Methanol, ethylene glycol

Ethanol or fomepizole

Opioids

Naloxone

Iron poisoning

Desferrioxamine

Epinephrine (Option D): Epinephrine is used in anaphylaxis or cardiac arrest to stimulate adrenergic receptors. It is not indicated for opioid overdose.

questions.text: A 9-month-old child is brought to the PHC with a fever and cough. She is feeding well and has normal urine output. On examination, a respiratory rate of 48 breaths/min is found, and no chest indrawing is seen. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Explain danger signs and send home
No pneumonia—Give amoxyclav + paracetamol and send home
Refer as the child has severe pneumonia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Explain danger signs and send home

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario involves a 9-month-old child with fever and cough but without severe symptoms like chest indrawing, which would indicate severe pneumonia. The child's respiratory rate (RR) is 48 breaths per minute, which is normal for this age (RR >60/min would be abnormal for infants).

According to the IMNCI guidelines, pneumonia is suspected if:

  • RR >60 breaths/min for infants <2 months
  • RR >50 breaths/min for infants 2-12 months
  • RR >40 breaths/min for children 12 months to 6 years
  • Lower chest wall indrawing, a sign of moderate pneumonia, is absent here.
  • Severe pneumonia involves danger signs like lethargy, inability to drink, persistent vomiting, and convulsions, which are not present in this case.

Based on this assessment, the child does not have severe pneumonia. The next step is to explain the danger signs to the caregiver and send the child home with appropriate follow-up instructions.

Pneumonia

Etiology

  • Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV): Leading viral cause of pneumonia in infants.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae: M/c bacterial cause in children, particularly aged 1-3 months.
  • Pneumocystis jirovecii: Common in HIV-infected infants, especially where ART and PCP prophylaxis are limited.
  • Other Bacteria: E. coli, Gram-negative bacilli, Haemophilus influenzae, Group B streptococcus.
  • Other Viruses: Rhinoviruses, parainfluenza, influenza, human metapneumovirus, adenovirus.
  • Other Fungal: Histoplasma, Aspergillus, Blastomyces, Cryptococcus, mucormycosis, Coccidioides.
  • Parasitic: Ascaris, Strongyloides.
  • Mycobacterium: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium avium complex.

Assessment and Classification of the Sick Child (Age 2 Months Up to 5 Years)

  • Initial Assessment: A thorough history from the mother is essential
  • Check for General Danger Signs:

Ask

Look

Action
  • Able to drink or breastfeed?
  • Does the child vomit everything?
  • H/O convulsions during this illness?
  • Lethargic or unconscious?
  • Currently convulsing?
  • If any danger signs are present, the child needs URGENT attention.

 

Assess Cough or Difficulty Breathing

Ask:

  • How long has the child had a cough or difficulty breathing?

Look, Listen, Feel:

  • Count the breaths per minute (use respiratory rate timers if available).
  • Fast Breathing Criteria:
    • Age 2 months up to 12 months: ≥50 breaths per minute.
    • Age 12 months up to 5 years: ≥40 breaths per minute.

Look for:

  • Chest in-drawing.
  • Stridor, wheeze.
  • Central cyanosis.
  • Oxygen saturation.
  • Use the AVPU scale (Alert, Voice, Pain, Unresponsive).

Assess for possible asthma/TB if the child has wheezing with chest in-drawing or fast breathing.

Classification of Pneumonia and Management

Classification

Signs

Treatment

Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease
  • Any general danger sign
  • Oxygen saturation < 90%
  • Stridor in calm child
  • Central cyanosis
  • Convulsions
  • AVPU = V, P, or U
  • Start oxygen therapy if saturation < 90%.
  • Administer Benzyl Penicillin (or Ampicillin) & Gentamicin.
  • Ceftriaxone should be used as a second-line treatment in children with severe pneumonia having failed on the first-line treatment.
  • Give diazepam if convulsing.
  • Prevent hypoglycemia.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Urgent referral or admission.

Pneumonia
  • Chest indrawing in calm child
  • Fast breathing
  • No signs of severe pneumonia
  • Administer Amoxicillin Dispersible Tablets.
  • Give Vitamin A.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Follow-up in 5 days.
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

No Pneumonia (Cough or Cold)
  • No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease.
  • Treat wheeze if present with salbutamol for 5 days.
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

 

No pneumonia—Give amoxyclav + paracetamol and send home (Option B): While this treatment approach could be appropriate for non-severe cases, the child does not meet the criteria for pneumonia based on clinical signs such as the absence of chest indrawing. Instead, explaining the danger signs and monitoring at home is preferred.

Start IV ceftriaxone (Option C): IV ceftriaxone is typically used in cases of severe pneumonia or when the child is unable to tolerate oral medication. This child does not have severe symptoms, so oral antibiotics (if pneumonia were diagnosed) would be sufficient.

Refer as the child has severe pneumonia (Option D): The child does not have severe pneumonia as defined by the IMNCI criteria, which requires the presence of danger signs such as inability to drink or severe difficulty breathing. There is no indication for referral in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of fetal lung maturity?

choices.text: Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

Explanation:

  • The Nile blue test assesses general fetal maturity by staining exfoliated skin cells, whereas markers like the L/S ratio, shake test, and phosphatidylglycerol specifically evaluate fetal lung maturity.

Tests for fetal lung maturity

Test

Description

Interpretation

Lecithin-sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio
  • Measures the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin in amniotic fluid.
  • Lecithin increases with lung maturity, while sphingomyelin remains stable.

A ratio >2 indicates fetal lung maturity. (Option A ruled out)

Shake Test (Bubble Test, Clement's Test)
  • Amniotic fluid is mixed with 95% ethanol and shaken.
  • Observed for bubbles at the meniscus after 15 minutes.

A complete ring of bubbles suggests fetal lung maturity. (Option B ruled out)

Phosphatidylglycerol (PG)
  • Marker of lung maturity, typically appears in amniotic fluid after 35 weeks of gestation.

Presence of PG indicates fetal lung maturity. (Option C ruled out)

Nile Blue Test
  • Uses 0.1% Nile blue sulfate to stain desquamated fetal cells in amniotic fluid.
  • Observes for color changes in stained cells.
  • >50% orange-stained cells indicate lung maturity.
  • Blue-stained cells do not indicate maturity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with eczematous Itching lesions. Blopsy revealed a subepidermal cleft with Direct Immunofluorescence showIng Linear C3 & IgG deposition along the basement membrane zone. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bullous Pemphigoid

Explanation:

Bullous Pemphigoid:

  • In prodromal phase of Bullous Pemphigoid itchy eczematous lesions can be seen. The associated antibody is IgG. Direct immunofluorescence linear deposition shows IgG and C3. Hence, this option is correct.
  • BP is a common subepidermal immunobullous disorder mainly affecting elder people. Autoantibodies against hemidesmosomal target proteins BP230(BPAG1) and BP180(BPAG2) which finally leads to bullae formation.
  • It is characterised by a prodromal non bullous stage with pruritis which is followed by a bullous stage. The later has intense pruritus with tense blisters and vesicles.
  • These blisters show a negative Nikolsky sign but a positive Bulla spread sign.
  • The rupture of blisters leads to yellow or hemorrhagic crust formation, which later heal without any scar.
  • Oral lesions can occur sometimes.
  • HPE shows a subepidermal split with inflammatory infiltrate, immunofluorescence shows a linear binding of immunoglobulin (IgG and C3) at the dermo-epidermal junction.
  • Topical and systemic steroids are the mainstay of treatment.

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option A)

  • PV is characterized by intraepidermal blistering and acantholysis (loss of cell-to-cell adhesion between keratinocytes).
  • Immunofluorescence shows intercellular IgG (not linear staining at the basement membrane zone).
  • The presence of subepidermal blisters here excludes PV.

Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option C)

  • DH is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy associated with deposition of IgA in the dermal papillae, not linear IgG or C3 at the basement membrane.
  • DH typically shows granular IgA deposition in immunofluorescence and not the linear patterns seen here.

Pemphigus foliaceous (Option D)

  • PF is another type of pemphigus that features intraepidermal blistering and acantholysis but lacks subepidermal blistering.
  • Immunofluorescence in PF typically shows intercellular IgG, not the linear IgG and C3 at the basement membrane observed in this case.

questions.text: The tactile hallucinations seen in cases of chronic cocaine intoxication are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Formication

  • The tactile hallucinations experienced in cases of chronic cocaine use are commonly referred to as "cocaine bugs" or formication.

Cocaine-Induced Psychotic Disorder:

  • Characterised by paranoid delusions and hallucinations.
  • Affects up to 50% of stimulant users.
  • Types of Hallucinations:
    • Auditory hallucinations are common.
    • Visual and tactile hallucinations are less common but may occur.
    • Cocaine can cause formication/ Cocaine bugs (sensation of bugs crawling under the skin).
  • Symptoms depend on dose, duration of use, and individual sensitivity to stimulants.
  • More frequent in users of intravenous cocaine or crack cocaine.
  • Psychotic symptoms are seen more in men than in women.
  • Treatment:
    • The preferred treatment is short-term use of antipsychotics like haloperidol, especially for amphetamine-induced psychosis.

Oneroid state (Option A) refers to an impaired consciousness involving dream-like experiences with vivid perceptions, hallucinations, and delusions, leading to disorientation and difficulty distinguishing reality. There are fluctuating periods of clarity and confusion, with detachment from the environment.

Dipsomania (Option B) refers to a compulsive, uncontrollable craving for alcohol, often leading to binge drinking. It is considered a form of alcohol use disorder characterised by episodes of intense desire to drink despite negative consequences.

Carphologia (Option C) refers to a medical condition characterised by the repetitive, purposeless picking at or tearing of one's clothes, bedding, or other objects, often seen in individuals with certain psychiatric or neurological conditions.

questions.text: Black foot disease with peripheral neuropathy is seen in which metal poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Arsenic

Explanation:

  • Chronic arsenic poisoning is associated with "black foot disease," a condition characterized by gangrene of the extremities due to peripheral vascular damage.
  • Peripheral neuropathy is also a common feature, presenting as sensory and motor dysfunction.

Clinical manifestations of Arsenic Poisoning:

 

Acute Arsenic Poisoning

Chronic Arsenic Poisoning

Dermal

  • Hair loss
  • Mees lines (Aldrich-Mees line or Reynold’s line): Transverse bands of opacity in nails. (Option C)
  • Melanosis (neck, eyelids, nipples)
  • Bowen’s disease
  • Facial oedema
  • Hyperkeratosis

Black foot disease (Peripheral gangrene)

  • Hyperpigmentation (raindrop pattern)
  • Skin cancer (commonly squamous cell carcinoma).

Ocular

  • Conjunctivitis
  • Lacrimation

Dimension of Vision

Gastrointestinal

  • Abdominal pain
  • Metallic taste
  • Garlicky odour
  • Dysphagia
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhoea (bloody or rice water)
  • Anorexia
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Weight loss

Airway

Upper airway irritation
  • Nasal septum perforation
  • Laryngitis
  • Bronchitis

Liver

Fatty degeneration
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Cirrhosis

Kidney

  • Oliguria
  • Uraemia

Nephritic changes

Neurological

  • Hyperpyrexia
  • Convulsions
  • Coma
  • Encephalopathy

Polyneuritis (glove & stocking type)

  • Tremor
  • Ataxia
  • Limb tenderness
  • Difficulty in walking

Haematological

–
  • Anaemia
  • Leucopenia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Basophilic stippling (Rare in arsenic poisoning and common in lead poisoning)
  • Karyorrhexis
  • Pancytopenia

Cardiac

Tachycardia

Hypotension

Cardiac arrhythmias

Hypertension

Myocarditis

Lead (Option B): Lead poisoning primarily causes motor neuropathy (e.g., wrist drop) and cognitive deficits, but it is not linked to black foot disease.

Mercury (Option C): Mercury poisoning leads to neurological symptoms such as tremors, erethism, and sensory disturbances but does not cause black foot disease.

Cadmium (Option D): Cadmium toxicity affects the kidneys and bones, leading to conditions like Itai-Itai disease, but it is not associated with peripheral neuropathy or black foot disease.

questions.text:
Which of the following is used to define dependence:

a. Strong desire to use the drug

b. Priority to use drugs other than any other activity

c. Increased tolerance

d. Persistent use of drugs despite knowing the harmful effects.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - a, b, c, d

  • All of the above statements describe Dependence, which is a condition in which an individual experiences both physical and psychological symptoms due to substance use.

Type of Dependence

Definition

Behavioural Dependence

Focuses on substance-seeking behaviours and the patterns of pathological use.

Physical Dependence

Refers to the physiological effects that result from repeated episodes of substance use.

Psychological Dependence

Also called habituation, characterised by a persistent or occasional craving to avoid dysphoria.

Substance Use Disorder Criteria (DSM-5):

The criteria for diagnosing substance dependence can be grouped into four main categories:

  1. Impaired Control:
    • Using larger amounts or for longer periods than intended
    • Persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control use
    • Spending excessive time obtaining, using, or recovering from the substance
    • Experiencing intense cravings or urges to use the substance (Statement a)
  2. Social Impairment:
    • Failing to fulfil major role obligations due to substance use
    • Continuing use despite persistent social or interpersonal problems
    • Giving up important activities because of substance use (Progressive Neglect) (Statement b)
  3. Risky Use:
    • Recurrent use in physically hazardous situations
    • Continued use despite knowledge of physical or psychological problems caused or exacerbated by the substance (Persistence) (Statement d)
  4. Pharmacological Criteria:
    • Tolerance: Needing increased amounts to achieve desired effects or experiencing reduced effects with the same amount. (Statement c)
    • Withdrawal: Experiencing characteristic withdrawal symptoms or using the substance to relieve withdrawal.

Disease

Incubation period
