questions.text: Which lens is utilized in direct gonioscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Koeppe

Explanation:

  • In direct gonioscopy, the Koeppe lens is commonly used. It is designed with a domed or slanted shape that allows light rays to pass through the contact lens/air interface at a steep angle, enabling direct visualization of the anterior chamber angle.

Direct Gonioscopy:

  • Direct gonioscopy uses a lens with a domed or slanted configuration to allow light from the eye’s angle to pass through the lens to the observer without reflection. It does not require a slit lamp and is typically performed with the patient in a supine position, often under general anesthesia for procedures like infantile glaucoma evaluation and surgery.
  • Lenses Used: Includes Koeppe, Barkan, Swan-Jacob lenses.
  • Technique:
    • Performed with the patient lying down, often using a hand-held microscope or magnifying loupes.
    • Not compatible with desktop slit lamps, limiting clarity and magnification compared to indirect gonioscopy.
  • Indications: Commonly used for evaluating and treating infantile glaucoma.

 

Goldmann lens: Typically used for indirect gonioscopy, which involves using a slit lamp for better magnification and clarity.

Zeiss lens: Also used for indirect gonioscopy with a slit lamp, offering high magnification.

Sussman lens: A type of indirect gonioscopy lens, offering wide-angle visualization but not used in direct gonioscopy.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Canal of petit

Explanation:

  • The Canal of Petit (also known as Spatia Zonularia) is a sacculated canal that encircles the equator of the lens, formed by the zonular fibers (the zonule of Zinn) that anchor the lens to the ciliary body. This canal is located behind the suspensory ligament of the lens and contains aqueous humor in the interstices between the zonules. It is an important anatomical feature in the structure of the eye.

Zonular Spaces (Spatia Zonularia):

  • Zonular fibers, also known as the zonule of Zinn, anchor the lens to the ciliary body and the ciliary part of the retina. These fibers are separated by spaces filled with aqueous humor, referred to as zonular spaces.
  • Anatomy: The zonules form a fibrous ring around the equator of the lens, connecting it to the ciliary body. The spaces between the zonules form a sacculated canal known as Hannover’s Canal or Petit’s Canal or Petit’s spaces (spatia zonularia), which encircles the lens' equator.
  • Function: These spaces are involved in the structure and function of the ciliary zonule, providing mechanical support for the lens and contributing to accommodation. The canal can be inflated using a fine blowpipe inserted under the suspensory ligament.

 

 

Canal of Hannover (Option B): Another term related to zonular anatomy, but it refers to a slightly different structure and is often used interchangeably with the Canal of Petit in some contexts. However, in this case, the correct answer is Canal of Petit.

Hyaloid Canal (Option C): This is a different structure in the eye, located within the vitreous body, and is the remnant of the fetal hyaloid artery. It is not related to the zonules or lens attachment.

Pars Plana (Option D): A region of the retina, part of the ciliary body, involved in ocular surgeries (like vitrectomy) but not related to the canal structures surrounding the lens.

questions.text:
What is the accurate order of staining in patients with dry eyes?

i. Fluorescein stain

ii. Lissamine green

iii. Rose Bengal stain
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) i, ii, iii

Explanation:

In the management of dry eye syndrome, different stains are used to assess the health of the ocular surface. The typical order of staining is as follows:

  1. Fluorescein Stain:
    • First step: Fluorescein is typically used first to highlight epithelial defects and tear film stability. It is a bright yellow-green dye that fluoresces under cobalt blue light, marking areas of corneal epithelial damage. It can also help assess the tear break-up time (TBUT).
  2. Lissamine Green:
    • Second step: Lissamine green is a vital dye that stains dead or degenerated cells in the conjunctiva and cornea, often used to evaluate the conjunctival surface in dry eyes. It is less irritating than Rose Bengal, making it ideal for dry eye patients, and it stains areas with poor tear film or disrupted epithelial integrity.
  3. Rose Bengal Stain:
    • Third step: Rose Bengal stains damaged epithelial cells in the conjunctiva and cornea, particularly in cases of severe dryness. It can be more irritating to the eye than the other two stains, so it is typically used last in the staining sequence. It is helpful in identifying severe damage, such as conjunctival filaments or corneal ulcers.

Investigations of dry eye

1, Slit-lamp examination
  • Superficial corneal erosions
  • Inadequate tear lake volume
  • Early tear film break-up time
  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Conjunctival surface irregularities
  • Meibomian gland dysfunction

2. Schirmer’s Test:
  • Schirmer’s test is used to diagnose aqueous deficiency dry eye disease.

Schirmer's Test 1

  • Measures both basal and reflex tear secretions
  • Uses Whatman-4 filter paper, kept in the lower fornix at the junction of lateral one-third and medial two-thirds.
  • After 5 minutes, wetting of the filter strip from the bent end is measured.
  • Normal value: >15 mm
  • 5-10 mm: Mild to moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS).
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

[1]

Schirmer's Test 2

  • Measures only basal secretion under anesthesia

3. Phenol Red Test
  • A modified Schirmer’s test using a cotton thread impregnated with phenol red dye.
  • The thread is placed in the lower fornix for 15 seconds.
  • Phenol dye changes from yellow to red depending on the pH of the tears.
  • Wet length: >20 mm: Normal.
  • <10 mm: Severe dry eye.
  • ≤19 mm as borderline dry eye.

4. Tear Film Break-Up Time (TBUT)
  • Tear film stained with sodium fluorescein 1% is observed under a slit lamp, and time is noted after the patient blinks.
  • The interval between the complete blink and the first appearance of a ‘dark’ dry spot on the cornea is recorded as TBUT.
  • It is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucin component of tears.
  • Normal: 15-35 seconds
  • < 10 seconds indicates unstable tear film.

5. Rose Bengal or Lissamine Green

Stain devitalized, desiccated corneal and conjunctival epithelium red or green.

 

6. Alcian Blue

Stains particulate matter in the tear film due to mucus

7. Tear Osmolarity

Increased in dry eye

8. Tear to Lysozyme ratio

Between 0.9 and 0.6 indicates dry eye.

 

 

Options A, C, & D are incorrect.

questions.text: In the provided image, which nerve is subjected to blockage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nasociliary nerve

Explanation:

  • The given image represents the nasociliary nerve block.
  • The nasociliary nerve is typically targeted for blockage in procedures involving the ophthalmic region, especially in the context of blocking sensations to the eye and adjacent structures.
  • The nasociliary nerve, as a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (V1), plays a central role in sensory innervation to the eye, cornea, and adjacent regions, which is why it is the primary target in many ophthalmic nerve blocks.

Nasociliary nerve block

  • The nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V).
  • It provides sensory innervation to structures such as the cornea, conjunctiva, sclera, ciliary body, and parts of the nose.
  • Indications for Block:
    • Ocular surgery (e.g., cataract surgery, corneal procedures).
    • Pain management in conditions like corneal ulcers, ocular trauma, or sinusitis.
    • Techniques:
  • Injection Site: The needle is typically inserted near the medial canthus of the eye, in the area where the nasociliary nerve is located close to the lacrimal sac.
  • Injection Approach: The needle is advanced medially, just lateral to the nasal bone, and injected near the nerve's location.
  • Anatomy: The nasociliary nerve travels within the orbit, giving off branches like the long ciliary nerves, posterior ethmoidal, and anterior ethmoidal nerves.
  • Procedure:
    • Patient Positioning: The patient is usually seated or supine with the eye to be blocked exposed.
    • Needle Insertion: A 25-30 gauge needle is used, inserted near the medial canthus, directed medially and slightly superiorly.
    • Local Anesthetic: A small amount (0.5-1 mL) of local anesthetic is injected near the nasociliary nerve for effective blockage.
  • Benefits:
    • Provides anesthesia to the cornea, conjunctiva, and other associated structures in the orbit.
    • Helps in treating ocular pain or managing intraocular procedures with minimal discomfort.
  • Complications:
    • Hematoma
    • Inadvertent block of other branches, leading to side effects like lid drooping or ptosis.

 

Anterior ethmoidal nerve (Option A) is a branch of the nasociliary nerve. It primarily provides sensation to the anterior part of the nasal cavity and the skin of the nose. Although it can be blocked in certain procedures, it is not the primary nerve blocked in typical ophthalmic procedures.

Supratrochlear nerve (Option C) is responsible for sensation in the forehead and scalp, specifically in the area above the eye. This nerve is not typically involved in the same procedures as the nasociliary nerve, which innervates the eye and surrounding structures.

Long ciliary nerves (Option D) are branches of the nasociliary nerve and are responsible for innervating the cornea, iris, and the ciliary body. They may be involved in certain procedures but are not usually blocked on their own without affecting the nasociliary nerve.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed with -1D spherical and -2D cylindrical at 180 degrees. What type of refractive error does this patient have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) With the rule astigmatism

Explanation:

  • The prescription given is -1D spherical and -2D cylindrical at 180 degrees.
    • The spherical component (-1D) indicates a myopic refractive error.
    • The cylindrical component (-2D) at 180 degrees indicates astigmatism with the steepest curvature along the 180-degree axis.

In with-the-rule astigmatism, the steepest curvature (and therefore the highest cylinder value) is along the vertical axis (90 degrees), and the flatter axis is horizontal (0 or 180 degrees). Since the cylinder is placed at 180 degrees and the patient has a more negative cylindrical value at this axis, it indicates with-the-rule astigmatism.

With-the-Rule Astigmatism (WTR)

Against-the-Rule Astigmatism (ATR)
  • The vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal.

 

  • Correction requires a concave cylindrical lens at 180° ± 20° or a convex cylindrical lens at 90° ± 20°.

 

  • It is called "with-the-rule" because the vertical meridian is normally more convex than the horizontal due to eyelid pressure.
  • The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian.

 

  • Correction requires a convex cylindrical lens at 180° ± 20° or a concave cylindrical lens at 90° ± 20°.

 

 

 

180 degrees

90 Degrees

With the rule

[-]

[+]

Against the rule

[+]

[-]

 

Against the rule astigmatism (Option B): This occurs when the steepest curvature is along the horizontal axis (0 or 180 degrees) and the flatter axis is vertical (90 degrees), which is not the case here.

Simple astigmatism (Option C): This refers to astigmatism where one of the meridians has no refractive error (i.e., it's either emmetropic or has no cylinder correction), but this patient has both spherical and cylindrical components.

Mixed astigmatism (Option D): This occurs when one axis has a myopic refractive error and the other has a hypermetropic refractive error. In this case, the prescription is purely myopic in both axes.

questions.text: All of the following are used to detect abnormal gene sequences, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Flow cytometry

Explanation:

  • Flow cytometry is not used to detect abnormal gene sequences.
  • Flow cytometry is a technique primarily used to measure the physical and chemical properties of cells, such as cell size, granularity, and protein expression.
  • It has numerous uses in genomic studies, with a high focus on monitoring cell cycle phases and cell viability, and is more often employed for immunophenotyping and cell sorting.

Fluorescence in situ Hybridization (FISH) (Option A) detects DNA sequence alterations like translocations, deletions, and amplifications using fluorescent probes to bind specific DNA regions, identifying chromosomal abnormalities.
RFLP analysis (Option B) (Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism) detects DNA sequence variations by analyzing the lengths of restriction enzyme-digested DNA fragments.

Pyrosequencing (Option C) is a type of DNA sequencing technology that can directly read DNA sequences by measuring the release of pyrophosphate during nucleotide incorporation. It allows for the detection of mutations, SNPs, and other genetic alterations.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements regarding amyloidosis.


	Amyloidosis is called so because it looks like the deposition of starch.
	Beta-pleated sheets are seen.
	AL is a type of secondary amyloidosis.
	It is an extracellular protein.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2 and 4

Explanation:

  • Amyloidosis is a group of disorders characterized by the extracellular deposition of amyloid fibrils that are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. (Statement 4)
  • The presence of abundant charged sugar groups in these adsorbed proteins gives the deposits staining characteristics that were thought to resemble starch (amylose). Therefore, the deposits were called amyloid (Statement 1).
  • 95% of amyloid consists of fibril proteins, with the remaining 5% being glycosaminoglycans (dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate) and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P.
  • AL amyloidosis is a primary form of amyloidosis, whereas secondary form can be caused by various etiologies and is associated with characteristic amyloid deposition (Statement 3).
  • Physical nature of amyloid:
  • Light microscopy with H & E stains: Amyloid is an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, and extracellular substance.

  • Electron microscopy: All types of amyloid, regardless of clinical setting or chemical composition, consist of continuous, nonbranching fibrils with a diameter of approximately 7.5 to 10 nm.
  • X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy: Characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation, which is responsible for the distinctive Congo-red staining and apple-green birefringence of the amyloid. (Statement 2)

questions.text: What is the causative agent of the ocular condition as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chlamydia

Explanation:

The ocular condition shown in the image is active trachoma, which is caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. Trachoma is a leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide, particularly in areas with poor sanitation.

 

Signs of active trachoma

Signs of cicatricial trachoma

Conjunctival signs:

  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva: Look like sago-grains
  • Papillary enlargement: red, velvety

Conjunctival signs:

  • Scarring
    • It may be irregular, star-shaped, or linear
    • Linear scar in the sulcus subtarsalis is called Arlt’s line
  • accumulation of dead epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in the glands of Henle
  • Pseudocyst
  • Xerosis
  • Symblepharon

Corneal signs:

  • Superficial keratitis on slit lamp and fluorescein
  • Herbert’s follicles
  • Progressive pannus/Trachomatous pannus: The upper part of the cornea is cloudy
  • Corneal ulcers are common at the advancing edge of the pannus
    • Shallow, little infiltrated
    • Cause lacrimation and photophobia

Corneal signs:

  • Regressive pannus or pannus siccus:
    • Receding infiltration
    • Vessels extend beyond the area of infiltration and haze
  • Herbert pits: oval or circular pitted scars formed after the healing of Herbert’s follicles in the limbal area
  • Vascularized and opaque cornea.
  • Corneal xerosis
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Total corneal pannus (blinding sequelae)

 

 

Lid signs:

  • Distortion of the lids
  • Tylosis: Thickening of the tarsal plate/lid margin
  • Trichiasis due to rubbing of lashes on the cornea
  • Trachomatous ptosis (sleepy appearance)
  • Entropion
  • Madarosis
  • Ankyloblepharon

Lacrimal apparatus sequelae:

  • Chronic dacryocystitis
  • Chronic dacryoadenitis

 

Images:

Active Trachoma

Follicles in upper palpebral conjunctiva

 

Progressive pannus

Cicatricial

Trachoma

Regressive pannus

Conjunctival concretions

Trichiasis

Tylosis (thickening of tarsal border of eyelid)

 

WHO Classification of Trachoma (FISTO)

Stage

Description

Image

Management

TF:

Trachomatous Inflammation- Follicular

  • The presence of five or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Active stage of trachoma
  • Antibiotics to eliminate the organism
  • Topical:
    • Tetracycline 1% or
    • Erythromycin 1%
    • Sulfacetamide
  • Systemic:
    • Tetracycline or erythromycin orally
    • Doxycycline orally
    • Azithromycin single oral dose
  • Combined systemic and topical therapy:
    • For TI or when an associated genital infection is present
    • Tetracycline 1% or erythromycin 1% eye ointment
    • Azithromycin orally

TI: Trachamatous Inflammation- Intense

Pronounced inflammatory thickening of the tarsal conjunctiva that obscures more than half of the normal deep tarsal vessels.

TS: Trachamatous Scarring

  • Presence of scarring in tarsal conjunctiva
  • White, bands or sheets of fibrosis in tarsal conjunctiva
  • Concretions removed with a hypodermic needle
  • Conjunctival xerosis with artificial tears (lubricating drops)

TT: Trachamatous Trichiasis

At least one eyelash rub on eyeball or evidence of recent removal of inturned eyelashes.
  • Permanent lash removal:
    • Electrolysis
    • Cryolysis
    • Radiofrequency epilation
    • Bilamellar tarsal resection
  • Cicatricial entropion surgery

CO: Corneal Opacity
  • Easily visible corneal opacity over the pupil
  • Part of the pupil margin is blurred when seen through the opacity as it is very dense corneal scarring
  • After treatment of other trachoma sequelae
  • Penetrating keratoplasty for significant corneal scarring
  • Keratoprosthesis for bilateral blind cases with extensive scarring and surface problems
  • Punctal occlusion and lateral tarsorrhaphy for coexistent eye surface problems

Mycoplasma (Option B): Although Mycoplasma can cause some ocular infections, it is not the causative agent of trachoma.

Pseudomonas (Option C): This is a common pathogen in corneal ulcers or infections, but it is not responsible for trachoma.

Staphylococcus (Option D: Staphylococcus infections can cause conjunctivitis and other eye conditions, but it is not the causative agent of trachoma.

questions.text: In the cervical smear below, which of the following stains are used
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Papanicolaou stain

Explanation:

  • Papanicolaou stain is the standard stain used in cervical smears to detect cellular abnormalities.
  • The Pap stain results in:
    • Well-stained nuclear chromatin
    • Differential polychromatic counterstaining of the cytoplasm
    • Cytoplasmic transparency

H & E stain (Option B) (hematoxylin and eosin) staining procedure uses two dyes to stain tissue samples, making it easier to see cell structure under a microscope; this is commonly used for histopathological tissue sections, not for cervical smears.

Giemsa stain (Option C) is used to stain blood and bone marrow smears, as well as some parasites, but it is not used in cervical cytology.

Toluidine blue (Option D) is a basic metachromatic dye primarily used to stain acidic components of tissues, such as nucleic acids and mast cell granules. It is not used for routine cervical cytology.

questions.text: What is the interpretation of the given pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Autosomal dominant

Explanation:

  • The interpretation of the pedigree chart given reveals Autosomal dominant inheritance, which means that an individual only needs one copy of the mutated gene to express the condition.
  • The affected individuals appear in every generation, as one parent passes on the mutated gene to their offspring.
  • Both males and females can be affected equally because the gene is located on one of the autosomes.
  • If an affected person has children, there is a 50% chance that each child will inherit the mutated gene and be affected.

Incomplete penetrance (Option A) refers to a situation where some individuals inherit the mutant gene but are phenotypically normal.

Autosomal Recessive (Option C) inheritance requires two copies of the mutation for the trait to be expressed. It typically shows horizontal transmission and can skip generations.

Pseudo dominance (Option D) occurs when a recessive allele appears to be expressed in the heterozygous condition due to the limited number of crossovers between linked genes.

questions.text: How does Total plasma exchange help in the management of TTP

choices.text: TPE removes the Von Willebrand factor
TPE removes Anti ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases the ADAMTS protease activity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) TPE removes Anti ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases the ADAMTS protease activity

Explanation:

  • Total plasma exchange (TPE) is a key treatment for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP); it removes the autoantibodies against ADAMTS13. (Option B ruled out)
  • ADAMTS13 is a protease that cleaves von Willebrand factor, preventing the formation of large, thrombogenic von Willebrand factor multimers. (Option A ruled out)
  • This helps restore normal ADAMTS13 activity and reduces the microvascular clotting that characterizes TTP.

Treatment of TTP

Plasma exchange (PEX) with high-dose corticosteroid therapy.
  • It is the mainstay of treatment in TTP.
  • Corticosteroids operate by decreasing the activity of the reticuloendothelial system as well as decreasing autoantibody production.
  • Both the ultra-large VWF multimers and the ADAMTS13 autoantibodies are effectively removed from circulation by plasma exchange therapy.
  • The recommended volume of exchange is one estimated plasma volume (usually 40 mL/kg of body weight) with each treatment.
  • The recommended dose for corticosteroids is 1 mg/kg per day of prednisolone.

Rituximab

An anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody was found to help treat TTP refractory to PEX. It targets B-lymphocytes and has a good response rate in refractory and relapsed TTP.

Caplacizumab
  • It has a high potential for TTP.
  • It is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment (a bivalent, variable-domain-only fragment) that attacks the A1 section of VWF and prevents platelet adhesion.

Others
  • Splenectomy,
  • Vincristine,
  • Cyclosporine and
  • Cyclophosphamide.

TPE replenishes the coagulation factor (Option D): TPE does not replenish coagulation factors; instead, it removes harmful substances like autoantibodies against ADAMTS13 in TTP, where clotting issues stem from defective vWF cleavage, not coagulation factor deficiencies.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hairy cell

Explanation:

  • The given image depicts a Hairy cell, which is characterised by the presence of fine, hair-like projections on the surface of the cell.
  • It is a characteristic type of cell found in Hairy Cell Leukemia, which involves abnormal proliferation of Mature B cells.
  • These cells have a round, oblong, or reniform nucleus and pale blue cytoplasm.

Gaucher cells (Option B) are lipid-laden macrophages found in Gaucher's disease, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the GBA1 gene, resulting in deficient glucocerebrosidase enzyme activity. These cells appear as foamy macrophages with a crumpled tissue-paper appearance due to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in the cytoplasm.

Crinkled paper macrophages in the marrow space

Sickle cells (Option C) are abnormally shaped red blood cells that resemble a crescent or sickle due to the presence of abnormal haemoglobin (haemoglobin S). These cells are not characterized by cytoplasmic projections like hairy cells.

Target cells (Option D) are red blood cells that have a bull's-eye appearance due to an increase in cell membrane relative to the volume of the cytoplasm. This condition can occur in several disorders, such as thalassemia, but they do not have the cytoplasmic projections seen in hairy cells.

questions.text: A 38-year-old multigravida presents with 2 years of infertility, dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and adnexal tenderness. What would be the initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B - Transvaginal USG 

The given scenario with dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea points to endometriosis and also shows adnexal involvement, which needs a transvaginal ultrasound for detecting the precise anatomic details of adnexal structures.

  • Ultrasound is the first line of investigation for pelvic pathology. It can be done by transabdominal (TAS) or transvaginal route (TVS).
  • Adnexal tenderness requires precise anatomic details of adnexal structures, which is provided by the transvaginal ultrasound.
  • A vaginal probe is an extension of bimanual palpation with better resolution of pelvic findings.
  • Advantages of TVS over TAS:
    • Full bladder not required
    • Better details (superior resolution)
    • Better images in obese women
  • Investigation of choice: Laparoscopy
  • Gold standard investigation: HPE

Laparotomy (Option A) can help confirm the diagnosis made on ultrasound and determine if the origin of the lesion is in doubt. However, it is an invasive procedure and hence not preferred over ultrasound.

Colposcopy (Option C) can help in identifying vaginal and cervical abnormalities. However, for adnexal pathology, transvaginal ultrasound is recommended.

Transabdominal pelvic ultrasound (Option D) is the first line of investigation. However, the transvaginal route is preferred over the transabdominal route for the reasons given in the explanation.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			A. Caplan’s syndrome
			
			
			1. Found first in coal worker
			
		
		
			
			B. Asbestosis
			
			
			2. Crazy pavement
			
		
		
			
			C. Mesothelioma
			
			
			3. Involves lower lobe
			
		
		
			
			D. Silicosis
			
			
			4. Pleural effusion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2

Explanation:

A. Caplan’s syndrome     
  • It is characterised by the formation of multiple well-defined pulmonary nodules, typically located in the lung periphery, in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis who have been exposed to inorganic dust.
  • It is primarily associated with coal worker's pneumoconiosis but can also occur in other forms of pneumoconiosis.

B. Asbestosis
  • It primarily affects the lower lobes of the lungs and increases the risk of laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung, and pleural cancers, with lung cancer risk significantly heightened in smokers.
  • Asbestos-related lung carcinoma typically targets the lower lobes, unlike other occupational lung diseases that affect the upper lobes.

C. Mesothelioma
  • It is a rare cancer originating from mesothelial cells, most commonly affecting the pleura.
  • CT scan typically shows pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax.
  • It can also involve the peritoneum, pericardium, and tunica vaginalis.

D. Silicosis
  • It is the most prevalent occupational lung disease and is caused by inhaling proinflammatory crystalline silica.
  • After decades of exposure, it typically presents as slowly progressing, nodular, fibrosing pneumoconiosis.
  • The CT scan shows a "crazy pavement" pattern and interstitial fibrosis.

questions.text: The below-given ANA pattern on immunofluorescence (IF) is seen; identify the pattern.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Centromeric

Explanation:

  • The image shows a centromeric ANA pattern, which refers to the staining of the centromere region of chromosomes, producing a pattern of discrete speckles or dots concentrated in the centre of the nucleus.
  • This pattern is seen in conditions such as Limited Scleroderma or CREST syndrome.

Homogeneous or diffuse staining of nuclei

(Option D ruled out)
  • Antibodies reactive with dsDNA, nucleosomes, and histones,
  • This is seen in SLE,
    • Drug-induced lupus
    • Mixed connective tissue disorder

Speckled pattern

(Option B ruled out)

 
  • Antibodies against various nuclear antigens, including Sm and RNPs
  • It is seen in SLE
    • Scleroderma
    • Sjogren’s syndrome

Nucleolar pattern

(Option A ruled out)
  • Antibodies against nucleolar proteins.
  • It is seen in Scleroderma and Polymyositis.

Anti-centromere antibodies

(Option C)

Systemic sclerosis, Sjögren syndrome, and other diseases

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement?

choices.text: Gonads are bipotential at 8 weeks of gestational age
DHT is necessary for the development of external genitals
MIS inhibits the formation of Mullerian duct
Wolffian duct forms male internal genitalia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Gonads are bipotential at 8 weeks of gestational age

The gonads are bipotential only till 6th week post-fertilization. Before 7 weeks of embryonic development, embryos of male and female sex cannot be differentiated.

  • Gonads originate from the genital ridge, which develops in 4th-week post-fertilization.
  • This remains undifferentiated and can form the ovary or testis, called the bipotential stage. This stage remains till the 6th week post-fertilization.
  • During this time, the coelomic epithelium is formed from the genital ridge.
  • The epithelium proliferates and invaginates into the mesenchyme to form the primitive sex cords.

In males, the SRY gene on the Y chromosome triggers the development of testes, accompanied by the formation of Sertoli cells and Leydig cells. Leydig cells secrete testosterone, a hormone crucial for sexual differentiation.

Through the action of 5-alpha reductase, testosterone is converted into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a more potent form. Testosterone guides the differentiation of the Wolffian duct for the internal male genitalia, while DHT is instrumental in the development of the male external genitalia (Option B).

Sertoli cells produce anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH), also known as Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS), which halts the development of the Müllerian system (Option C) comprising the uterus, fallopian tubes, and vagina.

Testosterone guides the differentiation of the Wolffian duct for the internal male genitalia (Option D), while DHT is instrumental in the development of the male external genitalia.

questions.text: Which type of amyloidosis is seen in patients undergoing dialysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) β2-microglobulin

Explanation:

In dialysis patients, the most common amyloidosis is β2-microglobulin-associated amyloidosis (dialysis-related amyloidosis, DRA). Normally cleared by the kidneys, β2-microglobulin accumulates in dialysis patients,

Important amyloid-disease associations

Disease

Amyloid

Multiple myeloma and other monoclonal plasma cell disorders

AL (Option D ruled out)

Chronic inflammation

AA

Alzheimer’s disease

Aβ (Option A ruled out)

Familial amyloid polyneuropathy

ATTR (mutated form of transthyretin) (Option C ruled out)

Diabetes mellitus

AIAPP

Hemodialysis associated amyloidosis

Aβ2m (Option B)

Familial Mediterranean Fever

AA

Senile systemic amyloidosis

ATTR (Increased quantity of TTR, no mutation is seen)

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid

Acal

Isolated atrial amyloidosis

AANF

leading to amyloid fibril deposition in bones and joints, causing pain, stiffness, and deformities.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is caused by abnormal folding of proteins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Creutzfelt Jakob disease

Explanation:

  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a type of prion disease caused by the abnormal folding of proteins, specifically prion proteins (PrP), which leads to neurodegeneration.
  • It is irreversible and fatal.
  • The disease progresses quickly, and death usually occurs within a year.
  • It is characterised by
    • Rapidly progressive dementia
    • Myoclonus
    • Ataxia
    • Visual disturbances
  • Diagnosis: It is confirmed via MRI (increased signal in basal ganglia) and EEG findings

Cirrhosis (Option B) is liver scarring typically caused by chronic liver diseases (e.g., hepatitis, alcoholism), not protein misfolding.

Nephritic syndrome (Option C) is a kidney disorder involving inflammation, typically due to immune complex deposition, not protein misfolding.

Sickle cell anaemia (Option D) is caused by a genetic mutation in the haemoglobin gene (HbS) that leads to abnormal haemoglobin, but not a misfolding of proteins in the same sense as prion diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is specific for scleroderma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anti-centromere antibody

Explanation:

  • Anti-centromere antibodies are highly specific for scleroderma, especially limited scleroderma (also known as CREST syndrome).
  • These antibodies target proteins associated with the centromere of chromosomes.
  • Scleroderma (systemic sclerosis) is an autoimmune disease characterized by fibrosis of the skin and internal organs.

Diffuse & Limited Systemic Sclerosis

Features

Diffuse

Limited

Skin involvement

Proximal & Distal extremities, face, trunk

Distal to elbows, face

Raynaud’s Phenomenon

Onset <1 year/at the time of skin changes

Precede skin diseases by years

Organ Involvement

Pulmonary (Interstitial fibrosis),

Renal (Renovascular hypertensive crisis),

GI & Cardiac

GI, Biliary cirrhosis, Pulmonary artery hypertension

Nail fold capillaries

Dilatation and dropout

Dilatation without significant dropout

Antinuclear antibodies

Anti-topoisomerase 1

Anticentromere

 

Antibodies

Conditions

Anti-La antibody (Option B)

Sjogren’s syndrome

Anti-Jo-1 antibody (Option C)

Dermatomyositis

Anti-U1 RNP antibodies (Option D)

Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the sign seen on the given USG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Spina bifida

  • The given ultrasound image shows the abnormalities seen in cases of spina bifida.

Spina bifida

  • It is one of the most common neural tube defects
  • Types of spina bifida:
    • Occulta
    • Closed
    • Menigocoele
    • Myelomenigocoele

Ultrasound findings in spina bifida

Cranial abnormalities

  • Cisterna magna obliteration
  • Banana sign: Compression or flattening of posterior cerebellar surface, giving a crescentic appearance
  • Lemon sign: Concave deformity of the frontal bones
  • Hydrocephaly

Fetal face

  • Cleft lip
  • Cleft palate

Rectal prolapse (Option B) is usually diagnosed clinically. Dynamic cystocolpoproctography can be used for detection.

Uterine prolapse (Option C) is seen by the weakness of supporting structures in the USG.

Cervical carcinoma (Option D) is diagnosed more precisely with the help of CT and MRI.

questions.text:
Match the following genetic abnormalities with their disorders.


	
		
			
			A. Trinucleotide repeat
			
			
			
				Patau syndrome
			
			
		
		
			
			B. Trisomy 18
			
			
			2. Huntington
			
		
		
			
			C. Trisomy 13
			
			
			3. Sickle cell anemia
			
		
		
			
			D. Hb beta chain Glu
			
			
			4. Edward syndrome
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

Explanation:

Trinucleotide repeat

Huntington

Trisomy 18

Edward syndrome

Trisomy 13

Patau syndrome

Hb beta chain Glu

Sickle cell anemia

Trinucleotide repeat disorders :

  • These are caused by the expansion of specific three-nucleotide sequences in genes.
  • They are characterized by the instability of repeat numbers, which can increase across generations or even within an individual’s lifetime, a key feature of these conditions.
  • Examples of Trinucleotide repeat and the disease-associated are:
    • Huntington's disease: CAG
    • Fragile X syndrome: CGG
    • Myotonic dystrophy type 1: CTG

Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome): Features include

  • Low birth weight
  • Closed fists with overlapping fingers
  • Rocker-bottom feet
  • Microcephaly
  • Micrognathia
  • Cardiac and renal malformations
  • Mental retardation
  • 95% of cases die in the 1st year of life

Trisomy 13 (Patau Syndrome): Features include

  • Rocker-bottom feet
  • Severe intellectual disability
  • Keyhole/ Coloboma (eyes)
  • Microphthalmia, microcephaly, holoprosencephaly
  • Cleft lip/palate
  • Polydactyly
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Renal defects-Polycystic kidney disease
  • Umbilical hernia, Omphalocele

Hb beta chain Glu

This mutation is seen in sickle cell anaemia and produces haemoglobin S (HbS), making red blood cells prone to hemolysis. This leads to complications such as splenic fibrosis, organ infarcts, and bone pain due to HbS polymerization and vaso-occlusion.

questions.text: Which of the following genes is responsible for the regulation of T lymphocytes by the thymus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) AIRE

Explanation:

  • AIRE (autoimmune regulator) is a gene responsible for regulating T cell selection in the thymus.
  • During negative selection, T cells that recognize self-antigens are eliminated through apoptosis.
  • AIRE plays a crucial role in this process by promoting the deletion of self-reactive T cells.
  • A defect in AIRE results in autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (APS).

Notch 1 (Option B) is involved in the initial development of T cells, including determining whether a progenitor cell will become a T cell, but it does not regulate the elimination of self-reactive T cells, which is the role of AIRE.

E2A (Option C) is a transcription factor more relevant to B cell development and not directly related to T cell selection in the thymus.

Rag1/2 (Option D) are enzymes responsible for the rearrangement of T cell receptor (TCR) genes during T cell development, but they do not directly regulate negative selection.

questions.text: What are clue cells?

choices.text: Vaginal epithelial cells lined by bacteria
Cervical epithelial cells lined by bacteria
Uterine endothelial cells lined by bacteria

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Vaginal epithelial cells lined by bacteria

Clue cells are epithelial cells in the vagina that have bacterial growth on them, giving them a unique stippled look.

  • These are found in bacterial vaginosis and are one of the criteria for its diagnosis.
  • They are cells with attached bacteria creating a poorly defined, stippled cellular border.

The Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis require the presence of at least three out of the following five criteria:

1. Presence of clue cells (>20%) on microscopic examination

  • Clue cells: Epithelial cells lined with bacilli

2. Vaginal pH greater than 4.5

3. Positive whiff test with KOH (fishy odor)

4. Thin, white homogeneous vaginal discharge

5. Fishy odour

questions.text: What is the commonest cause of a hypercoagulable state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Factor V Leiden mutation

Explanation:

  • The most common inherited cause of a hypercoagulable state (predisposing to thrombosis) is the Factor V Leiden mutation.
  • Mutation: Factor V becomes resistant to cleavage and inactivation by protein C, disrupting the antithrombotic pathway.
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant.

Primary causes of Hypercoagulable states

Common causes
  • Factor V mutation (Factor V Leiden)
  • Prothrombin mutation (G20210A) - It is comparatively less common than Factor V mutation (Option D ruled out)
  • Elevated factor levels (VIII, IX, XI, or fibrinogen)

Rare causes
  • Antithrombin III deficiency (Option A ruled out)
  • Protein C deficiency (Option B ruled out)
  • Protein S deficiency

Very rare causes
  • Fibrinolysis Defects
  • Homozygous Homocystinuria

Secondary causes of Hypercoagulable states

Major risk factors
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Tissue injury (surgery, fracture, burn)
  • Cancer
  • Prosthetic cardiac valves
  • DIC
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Prolonged rest or immobilisation

Additional risk factors for thrombosis
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Hyperestrogenic states (pregnancy and postpartum)
  • Oral contraceptive use
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Smoking

questions.text: A lady on OCPs presents with white discharge per vagina with no itching or foul smell. It stains her underwear yellow and shows normal lactobacilli with an acidic pH on examination of the discharge. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Increased normal vaginal discharge

  • The lady is experiencing an odourless and white discharge, without itching or redness, with normal flora leading to the diagnosis of a physiological increase of normal vaginal discharge, which is a minor complication associated with OCP usage.

Complications associated with oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)

Complication

Details

Minor Complications

Nausea, Vomiting, Headache

Common initial side effects due to hormonal changes; usually resolve over time. Consider dose adjustment if persistent.

Mastalgia

Breast tenderness or pain; typically resolves within a few cycles.

Weight Gain

Minimal long-term weight gain

Menstrual Abnormalities

Includes breakthrough bleeding, hypomenorrhea, menorrhagia, and amenorrhea; often resolves with continued use.

Libido

Changes in sexual desire can occur

Leukorrhea

Increase in vaginal discharge

Major Complications

Depression

Mood changes or depression related to hormonal fluctuations

Hypertension

Elevated blood pressure; requires regular monitoring and possible medication adjustment.

Vascular Complications
  • Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): Increases risk three to fivefold, especially in those with hypertension, diabetes, obesity, or smoking.
  • Arterial Thrombosis: Increased risk of stroke and myocardial infarction

Cholestatic Jaundice

Liver dysfunction resulting in jaundice; Resolves after discontinuation of OCPs.

Neoplasia

Association with cervical cancer; regular Pap smears recommended for screening.

Candidiasis (Option A), commonly known as a yeast infection, can cause a thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge. It is often associated with itching, redness, and swelling of the vulva. The pH level is typically normal or slightly acidic.

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) (Option C) is a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance of bacteria in the vagina and often presents with a thin, milky-white vaginal discharge that can sometimes appear greyish or yellowish. BV is not usually associated with itching, redness, or pain, and the pH level of the vagina is often elevated but can have a characteristic fishy order, especially after intercourse.

Trichomoniasis (Option D) is a sexually transmitted infection that can cause a frothy, greenish-yellow, foul-smelling discharge. It is often associated with itching, redness, and discomfort. The pH level is usually elevated.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features describing necrosis?


	Cell swelling
	Disrupted cell membrane
	Induces inflammation
	Physiological
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 2 and 3

Explanation:

  • Necrosis is a form of pathological cell death (Statement 4 ruled out), often occurring due to various injuries, such as physical trauma, ischemia, infection, or exposure to toxic substances.
  • It is characterized by cell swelling, membrane rupture, organelle damage, and nuclear changes (Pyknosis, Karyorrhexis, Karyolysis).
  • Cell swelling occurs because of the loss of cellular integrity and failure of ion pumps (such as the Na+/K+ ATPase pump), leading to an influx of water into the cell.
  • In necrosis, the plasma membrane of the cell is disrupted, allowing the release of intracellular contents.
  • The released substances trigger an immune response, leading to an inflammatory reaction, which is a characteristic of necrosis.

questions.text: The recombinant form of vaccine to prevent cervical cancer has which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - L1

  • The vaccine to prevent cervical cancer is the HPV vaccine, which targets the L1 protein, a major capsid protein of HPV.

HPV vaccine

  • It is made using recombinant technologies.
  • Synthetic L1 capsid proteins of each type of HPV are made and included in the vaccine.
  • These virus-like particles are highly immunogenic but not infectious.

Indian Guidelines for HPV Vaccination:

Girls aged 9–14 years:
  • Two doses : Cervarix (0 and 6 months)

Girls aged 15 years and older:
  • Three doses:
    • Cervarix: 0, 1, and 6 months.
    • Gardasil: 0, 2, and 6 months.

Immunocompromised individuals (any age):
  • Three doses:
    • Cervarix: 0, 1, and 6 months.
    • Gardasil: 0, 2, and 6 months

WHO Guidelines for HPV Vaccination:

Girls aged 9–14 years:

One or two doses.

Girls and women aged 15–20 years:

One or two doses.

Women older than 21 years:

Two doses, 6 months apart.

 

Types and Administration of Gardasil:

Vaccine Type

Targeted HPV Types

Administration Schedule

Quadrivalent Gardasil

6, 11, 16, 18

Intramuscularly at 0, 2, and 6 months

Nonavalent Gardasil 9

Made from the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

Intramuscularly at 0, 2, and 6 months

E1 and E2 (Option A) are early proteins of HPV, involved in the regulation of the viral replication process.

E6 and E7 (Option B) are also early proteins of HPV, and they are associated with the oncogenic potential of high-risk HPV types.

L2 (Option D) is another minor capsid protein of HPV, and while it is expressed in infected cells, the primary focus of the HPV vaccine is on the major capsid protein, L1.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not required for Turner mosaic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - ANA

Turner’s syndrome is caused by monosomy of the X chromosomes; hence, ANA is not a suitable test for this.

  • ANA or Antinuclear antibody test is done for autoimmune diseases like SLE, scleroderma, rheumatoid arthritis, etc.
  • Autoimmune diseases associated with Turner’s syndrome include autoimmune thyroiditis, celiac disease, and rarely Type 1 diabetes.

Turner mosaic syndrome

  • Turner’s syndrome is due to the deletion or non-functioning of one of the X chromosomes in females and is a /genetic condition.
  • 50% of the population has a mosaic chromosomal component (45, X mosaicism).
  • Mosaic Turner syndrome is not an inherited condition.
  • Cause: Random event during the cell division at the early fetal stage.
  • As a result of this process, some cells of the person have normal 2 sex chromosomes while other cells have only one copy of the X chromosome.

ECHO or echocardiography (Option A) is a type of imaging of the heart for the detection of cardiovascular abnormalities. Cardiac anomalies like the bicuspid aortic valve and coarctation of the aorta are seen in Turner’s syndrome. Even though milder forms are associated with Mosaic Turner syndrome, regular screening with echocardiography is advised.

Periodic audiometry (Option B) is recommended to be done every 3-5 years to detect sensorineural hearing loss since hearing loss and cholesteatoma are seen with Turner’s syndrome.

Oral glucose tolerance test (Option C) is done as the majority of patients with Turner’s syndrome have abnormalities in glucose metabolism, including insulin resistance. Screening for diabetes in Turner’s syndrome can be done by estimation of HbA1C or by oral glucose tolerance test. Amongst these, oral glucose tolerance tests are considered more sensitive.

questions.text: What does luminal type A tumour refer to?

choices.text: ER+ / HER2 neu- ; mild to moderate proliferation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ER+ / HER2 neu- ; mild to moderate proliferation

Explanation:

  • Luminal type A tumours refer to a subtype of breast cancer with ER-positive, HER2 neu negative and mild to moderate proliferation.
  • These tumours tend to grow slowly and have a better prognosis compared to other subtypes.
  • Molecular classification of breast cancer is based on the results of receptor status such as ER, PR and HER2.

Molecular classification of breast cancer

(Options A & D ruled out)

Positive (either or both ER/PR)

Negative/ positive

Basal type (triple -ve)

(Option C ruled out)

Negative

Negative

questions.text: What does CD40 deficiency in a person signify?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) B cell absent

Explanation:

  • In individuals with CD40 deficiency, B cell activation is impaired.
  • CD40 is a crucial co-stimulatory molecule involved in the activation and regulation of the immune response, particularly between T cells and B cells
  • CD40L (also known as CD154) on antigen-activated CD4+ helper T cells binds to CD40 on B cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells (DCs).
  • In the absence of CD40, B cells cannot receive the necessary co-stimulatory signals required for proper activation and class switching.
  • It results in a lack of IgG production (Option D ruled out) despite the presence of IgM. It leads to a condition known as Hyper-IgM syndrome.

T cell absent (Option B): CD40 deficiency does not lead to an absence of T cells. T cells are present, but the CD40 deficiency impairs the interaction between T cells and B cells.

IgM increase (Option C): Although IgM levels may be elevated in some cases due to lack of class switching, the key feature is failure to produce IgG and other antibody isotypes, leading to impaired immunity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant female at 28 weeks of gestation presents with fever, acute pain abdomen, and mild leukocytosis. On examination, she has tenderness over the lower abdomen, and the uterus feels enlarged. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows no abnormalities. What is the most probable diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Red degeneration of fibroid:

  • The clinical features of acute abdominal pain, fever, and mild leukocytosis at 28 weeks of gestation suggest the diagnosis of red degeneration of fibroid.

Red degeneration

  • Red degeneration, also known as carneous degeneration, is a complication of uterine fibroids that can occur during pregnancy.
  • This condition is most likely to arise during the second half of pregnancy and the puerperium, impacting an estimated 5-10% of women with uterine fibroids.
  • Pathophysiology: Blood supply is redirected to the developing fetus, resulting in decreased blood supply to the fibroid and subsequent degeneration.
  • Conservative management with pain relief and supportive care is the best course of management. It involves pain relief with NSAIDs or acetaminophen, hydration, and bed rest.

Uterine torsion (Option B) When a myoma rotates at the site of attachment to the uterus, causing occlusion of veins, it leads to torsion. Usually associated with subserosal pedunculated myoma and causes very severe abdominal pain. Fever is not noted and has no particular association with pregnancy.

Infection of the fibroid (Option C) is common in submucosal polyps that protrude in the cervix or vagina, leading to infection. Blood-stained purulent discharge may be noted.

Preterm labour (Option D) is characterized by progressively increasing painful uterine contractions, which are associated with cervical dilatation and cervical discharge.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-apoptotic gene?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) MCL1

Explanation:

  • MCL1 is an anti-apoptotic gene and part of the BCL-2 family.
  • Apoptosis is a key process for maintaining cell balance and eliminating damaged cells, regulated by the interplay between pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic genes.
  • MCL1 inhibits apoptosis by preventing the activation of pro-apoptotic proteins, thereby promoting cell survival.

Apoptotic genes:

  • Anti Apoptotic genes :- BCL-2 , BCL-XL , MCL-1
  • Pro Apoptotic genes:- BAX and BAK (Option A ruled out)
  • Apoptosis initiators:- BAD, BIM, BID, Noxa and Puma (Option C & D ruled out)

questions.text: The SRY gene is present on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Y-chromosome short arm

Explanation:

  • The SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene is crucial for male sex determination. It is located on the distal short arm of the Y chromosome.
  • Yp11.3 is the precise genetic locus where "Yp" refers to the short arm ("p") of the Y chromosome.
  • Mutations in this gene can lead to disorders of sex development (DSDs), such as Swyer syndrome (46, XY gonadal dysgenesis).

Y-chromosome long arm (Option B) is rich in genes related to male reproductive functions, but the SRY gene is located on the short arm (Yp).

X-chromosome short arm (Option C) & X-chromosome long arm (Option D): The X chromosome plays no role in initiating male sex determination. Instead, it carries genes like DAX1 (Xp21), which antagonizes SRY function, and XIST (Xq13), which regulates X-inactivation.

questions.text: In puberty, what is the most common cause of menorrhagia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Anovulation

  • Anovulation is the most common cause of pubertal menorrhagia.

Physiology of pubertal amenorrhea:

  • During puberty, maturation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis causes an increase in GnRH, which induces the secretion of pituitary gonadotropins (LH and FSH).
  • The timing of LH pulses is crucial in establishing normal ovulatory cycles.
  • Anovulatory cycles are due to hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis dysfunction.
  • Immaturity of the hypothalamus leads to lower levels of LH and FSH, which are sufficient to induce follicular development and estrogen production but inadequate to induce follicular maturation and ovulation.
  • Inadequate positive feedback results in sustained high levels of estrogen causing endometrial hyperplasia. This ultimately outgrows its blood supply and architectural support, causing partial breakdown and irregular shedding.

Endometriosis (Option A) is the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue away from the cavity of the uterus. Endometriosis and adenomyosis are causes of abnormal uterine bleeding more commonly in the reproductive age group rather than around puberty.

Malignancy (Option C) causing menorrhagia is rare but may occur in women with chronic anovulation, especially due to polycystic ovarian disease. Genitourinary malignancies are extremely rare in adolescents.

Adenomyosis (Option D) is ectopic endometrial tissue within the wall of the uterus. Endometriosis and adenomyosis are causes of abnormal uterine bleeding, more commonly in the reproductive age group rather than around puberty.

questions.text: The following image is obtained from a 45-year-old woman with a left ovarian mass. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Granulosa cell tumor

  • The image here shows a granulosa cell tumour due to characteristic Call-Exner bodies in the image given.

Granulosa Cell Tumors

Incidence
  • 70% of all ovarian sex cord tumours are granulosa cell tumors
  • 2% of all ovarian neoplasms

Types
  • Adult form (95%)
  • Juvenile form (5%)

Characteristics
  • Slow growing
  • Solid or cystic or mixed
  • The cut section shows yellow/orange due to lipid content

HPE Appearance
  • Round/polygonal cells with granular eosinophilic cytoplasm
  • Coffee bean nuclei
  • Call-Exner bodies (Pathognomonic)

 

Hormonal Activity & Markers
  • Secrete inhibin B, estrogen, and AMH

Clinical Features

  • Prior to puberty: Precocious puberty
  • Childbearing period: Abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Postmenopausal: Bleeding often with endometrial hyperplasia or adenocarcinoma

Prognosis
  • Good overall prognosis
  • The 5-year survival rate for stage I disease is about 95%

 

Dysgerminoma (Option A) is a rare malignant germ cell tumour of the ovary that often affects women of reproductive age.

 

Dermoid (Option B) or teratoma forms from reproductive cells that make eggs in the ovary (germ cells). The cyst can contain tissue like hair, skin, or teeth. This type of cyst is rarely cancer.

 

Brenner tumors (Option C) are rare ovarian neoplasms made of ovarian transition cells surrounded by dense fibrous tissue. Most of them are small tumors (<2 cm) detected incidentally in asymptomatic women.

questions.text: In the management of a 65-year-old woman diagnosed with epithelial ovarian cancer accompanied by peritoneal metastasis and massive ascites, which treatment sequence is typically recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Chemotherapy followed by debulking

The ovarian cancer in this scenario appears to be of a more advanced stage (stage 3) with ascites, and the most suitable treatment for such tumours is chemotherapy to shrink the tumour followed by a debulking surgery to remove the remaining tumour.

  • Following primary debulking surgery, the standard first-line adjuvant chemotherapy regimen for epithelial ovarian cancer includes a combination of paclitaxel and carboplatin.

Role of Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy (NACT):

For patients with advanced ovarian cancer, especially those who may not be ideal candidates for immediate surgery due to extensive disease, neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NACT) is an option.

  • NACT involves administering chemotherapy before surgical intervention.
  • Given as 3 cycles before surgery and 3 cycles after surgery.
  • It increases the chances of optimal debulking - This surgery after initial neoadjuvant chemotherapy is called interval debulking.

Note:

  • Women relapsing after 6 months of primary chemotherapy - Platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer
  • Women relapsing within 6 months of primary chemotherapy - Platinum-resistant ovarian cancer

Debulking followed by radiotherapy (Option A) sequence is not typically recommended as the primary approach. Debulking surgery is often performed after chemotherapy to remove as much tumour tissue as possible.

Debulking followed by chemotherapy (Option C): While debulking surgery is an important component of treatment, initiating chemotherapy first is generally more effective in reducing the tumour burden before surgery.

Radiotherapy followed by debulking (Option D): Radiotherapy is not a standard primary treatment for advanced ovarian cancer. Debulking surgery and chemotherapy are the mainstays of treatment, and radiation therapy may be considered in specific situations, but it is not typically the initial approach.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female comes for her routine gynaecological examination. A cervical smear is done, as shown below. Identify the stain used here.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Papanicolaou stain

  • The cervical smear, also known as Pap smear, is stained using Papanicolaou stain that contains hematoxylin, eosin Y, Bismarck brown, orange green 6, and light green SF.

Contents of a Pap Stain:

  1. Hematoxylin: Stains nuclei blue.
  2. Eosin Y: Stains acidophilic cells red.
  3. Bismarck brown: Stains basophilic cells blue-green
  4. Orange green 6: Stains erythrocytes orange-red to dark pink.
  5. Light green SF: Stains keratin orange-red.

The staining pattern of different cells:

  • Nuclei: Blue
  • Acidophilic cells: Red
  • Basophilic cells: Blue-green
  • Erythrocytes: Orange-red to dark pink
  • Keratin: Orange-red
  • Superficial cells: Pink
  • Intermediate and parabasal cells: Blue-green
  • Eosinophil: Orange-red
  • Metaplastic cells: Contain both blue/green and pink
  • Candida: Red
  • Trichomonas: Grey-green

Normal PAP Smear

Infections detected using pap smear:

  1. Human Papillomavirus (HPV): Identifies cellular changes, specifically dysplasia, at the transformation zone, often caused by HPV infection. HPV is determined through further testing, such as HPV DNA testing.
  2. Trichomonas: Grey-green color.
  3. Candida (Yeast Infection): Stains red.
  4. Herpes simplex virus (HSV): Identified by the presence of multinucleated giant cells and other cytopathic effects.

Giemsa stain (Option A) is commonly used in microbiology to stain blood cells and microorganisms. It is not typically used in cervical cytology.

H & E stain (Option B) is commonly used in histology to visualize tissue structures. It is not the primary stain used in Pap smears, which focus on cellular morphology.

Congo red (Option D) is a stain primarily used for detecting amyloid deposits in tissues. It is not used in the staining process for cervical cytology.

questions.text: A patient visited the outpatient department reporting symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) accompanied by hirsutism. Among the following choices, which one does NOT align with appropriate management strategies for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - OCP alone

  • While OCPs are effective in regulating menstrual cycles and lowering androgen levels, OCPs alone may not be sufficient to fully address hirsutism, especially in cases where symptoms are more pronounced. Most clinical guidelines recommend a combination approach for managing hirsutism, integrating OCPs with antiandrogens or other supportive therapies to achieve better results.

Combining OCPs with metformin (Option C) is effective, particularly for managing insulin resistance and menstrual irregularities, while also addressing hirsutism through the hormonal effects of oral contraceptives (OCPs)

Combining OCP with antiandrogen medications (spironolactone) (Option B) is often recommended when OCPs alone do not sufficiently control hirsutism. Antiandrogens can block the effects of androgens, providing additional benefit

Combining OCP and lifestyle modifications (Option D), including dietary changes, regular exercise, and weight management, are recommended as part of PCOS management. Weight reduction leads to ovulation [in 30% of cases]; loss of even 5-10% weight increases insulin sensitivity and can regularize cycles.

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing tumour of the ovary?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Arrhenoblastoma

  • Arrhenoblastoma, also known as sertoli leydig tumours, these are virilizing ovarian tumours that cause symptoms like hoarseness, breast atrophy, and clitoromegaly.

Sertoli Leydig Tumors / Arrhenoblastomas

Incidence

0.5% of all ovarian tumours, 5% of all SCST’s

Characteristics

Small, solid, unilateral tumours and HPE Reinke crystals are pathognomonic.

Hormonal Activity & Markers

Androgens, Inhibin, AFP

 

Clinical Features
  • Hirsutism (Male pattern baldness, excessive hair growth) - Reversible
  • Virilization (Hoarseness, Breast atrophy, Clitoromegaly) - Permanent
  • Oligomenorrhea to Amenorrhea

Theca cell tumours (Option A) of the ovary primarily produce estrogen but can also produce androgens (male hormones) but are not typically associated with significant virilization.

Carcinoid tumours (Option C) typically arise from neuroendocrine cells and can occur in various organs, including the ovaries, but their hormonal effects are not typically characterized by virilization.

Brenner tumours (Option D) are ovarian neoplasms composed of transitional epithelial cells, are linked to postmenopausal bleeding and are occasionally associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei (commonly seen in Brenner tumours with mucinous differentiation, presenting as ascites and pleural effusion).
